A bill for publication costs shall be presented to the company by the appropriate city officials upon the granting of this franchise and the publication costs shall be paid at that time by the company. 
(Ord. 964 § 15, 1994) 
5.08.190 - Police powers. 
    Company's rights are subject to the police powers of the city to adopt and enforce ordinances necessary to the health, safety and welfare of the public. Company shall comply with all applicable laws and ordinances enacted by the city pursuant to that power. 
(Ord. 964 § 16, 1994) 
5.08.200 - Use of company facilities. 
    The city shall have the right to install and maintain, free of charge to the city, upon the poles and within the underground pipes and conduits of the company, any wires and fixtures designated by the city to the extent that such installation and maintenance does not interfere with existing and future operations of the company. The city shall indemnify and hold the company, its officers, directors, shareholders, employees and agents harmless from and against all claims, losses, damages, cost and expenses (including but not limited to reasonable attorneys' fees) related to the city's negligence in the installation, operation and maintenance of such wires and fixtures. 
(Ord. 964 § 17, 1994) 
5.08.210 - Written notice. 
    All reasonable notices, reports or demands required to be given in writing under this franchise shall be deemed to be given when delivered personally to the person designated below, or when five days have elapsed after it is deposited in the United States mail in a sealed envelope, with registered or certified mail postage prepaid thereon, or on the next addressed business day if sent by express mail or overnight air courier addressed to the party to which notice is being given, as follows: 
If to City: Mayor 

City of Benbrook 

P.O. Box 26569 

911 Winscott Road 

Benbrook, Texas 76126 If to Company: Marcus Cable Associates, L.P. 
4528 W. Vickery Street 
Fort Worth, Texas 76107 
Attn: General Manager 
cc: General Counsel 
Marcus Cable Associates, L.P. 
4528 W. Vickery Street 
Ft.Worth, Texas 76107  
    Such addresses may be changed by either party upon written notice to the other party given as provided in this section. (Amended during 5-98 supplement; Ord. 964 § 18, 1994) 
5.08.220 - Monthly testing. 
    Company shall conduct technical performance tests as required by the FCC and shall provide the city copies of the test results within fourteen calendar days of a written request from the city. 
(Ord. 964 § 19, 1994) 
5.08.230 - Programming. 
    Company shall, at a minimum, provide the following categories of programming: 
    Local broadcasting channels 
    Sports programming 
    Music programming 
    Childrens programming 
    National news 
    Educational programming 
    Religious programming 
(Ord. 964 § 20, 1994) 
5.08.240 - Communications with regulatory agencies. 
    Copies of all petitions, applications, communications and reports submitted by company on behalf of or relating to company to the FCC, Securities and Exchange Commission or any other federal or state regulatory commission or agency having jurisdiction in respect to any matters affecting the cable system authorized pursuant to this franchise shall be made available to the city upon request. Company shall provide city with a list of all such above-referenced communications within sixty days of the date of adoption of this franchise to be updated, as necessary throughout the term of this franchise. The city shall have the right to request copies of any and all communications referenced above, as well as responses from such regulatory agencies. Company shall provide such copies within fourteen days from the date of request. 
(Ord. 964 § 21, 1994) 
5.08.250 - Periodic inspection. 
    The city may, and company shall, at the request of the city, undertake inspection of the cable system to ascertain that the cable system performance at preselected addresses based on complaints received indicating an unresolved technical controversy or problem. Company shall have fifteen days to inspect and report to the city of any findings concerning unresolved technical controversy or problem before initiating an inspection of the cable system. 
A.  The city shall give written notice to company of a possible technical controversy or problem and request an explanation within fifteen days of company's receipt of such notice. 
B.  If the technical controversy or problem has not been corrected, the city may, in its sole discretion, give company written notice of city's intention to undertake an inspection of homes where complaints were received and the name of the representative who participated in the investigation for the city. 
C.  Company shall, within five business days of receipt of the city's notice, select one person who will participate for the company and so notify the city. 
D.  The representatives of the city and company shall, within fifteen days of the selection of the company's representative select a third representative trained in cable television technology. If city and company cannot mutually agree upon a third party representative, inspection shall begin without third party representation. 
E.  Within ten days after the appointment of all representatives, the representatives shall commence an inspection of the preselected drops in accordance with the following procedures: 
1.  The representatives shall commence the inspection of the preselected drops viewing channels of technical controversy or problem and, by decision of the majority, assign a rating one to five for the quality of the signal of each channel viewed. 
2.  In assigning a rating for each channel of programming so viewed, the representatives shall use the following scale: 
    1-Poor picture, unacceptable viewing 
    2-Poor picture, degradation problem 
    3-Good picture, degradation noticeable 
    4-Very good picture, small amount of impairment noticeable. 
    5-Excellent picture, no visible impairment. 
F.  The representatives shall then submit to the city and company a written report of its findings and any appropriate recommendations. 
G.  Upon request of the city, company shall attend a regular or specially scheduled meeting of the city to discuss results and findings from representatives. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, the city may use the findings from representatives as a basis to or not to order special testing of the cable system. 
(Ord. 964 § 22, 1994) 
5.08.260 - Approval of changes in rates. 
    The city reserves the right to regulate rates for basic service and any other services offered over the cable system, to the extent permitted by federal or state law. Company shall maintain on file with the city at all times a current schedule of all rates and charges. To the extent applicable and required, the city shall comply with the rules relating to cable rate regulation promulgated by the FCC at 47 C.F.R., Part 76.900, Subpart N, or such other applicable laws, rules or regulations with respect to the regulation of the rates charged by company. 
(Ord. 964 § 23, 1994) 
5.08.270 - Performance bond. 
    At the time the franchise is accepted, company shall furnish and file with the city a performance bond in the amount of thirty-seven thousand five hundred dollars. The performance bond is conditioned upon the faithful performance of company of all the terms and conditions of this franchise. The rights reserved to the city with respect to the performance bond or other security are in addition to all other rights the city may have under the franchise or any other law. 
(Ord. 964 § 24, 1994) 
5.08.280 - City's right to revoke. 
    In addition to all other rights which the city has pursuant to law or equity, the city reserves the right to revoke, terminate or cancel this franchise, and all rights and privileges pertaining thereto after affording company due process. 
(Ord. 964 § 25, 1994) 
5.08.290 - Foreclosure. 
    Upon the foreclosure or any other judicial sale of the cable system, company shall notify the city of such fact and such notification shall be treated as a notification that a change in control of the company has taken place, and the provisions of this franchise governing the consent to transfer or change in ownership shall apply without regard to how such transfer or change of ownership occurred. 
(Ord. 964 § 26, 1994) 
5.08.300 - Receivership. 
    The city shall have the right to cancel this franchise subject to any applicable provisions of state law, including the Bankruptcy Act, one hundred twenty days after the appointment of a receiver or trustee to take over and conduct the business of company, whether in receivership, reorganization, bankruptcy or other action or proceeding, unless such receivership or trusteeship shall have been vacated prior to the expiration of the one hundred twenty days. 
(Ord. 964 § 27, 1994) 
5.08.310 - Removal of system. 
    In the event the company abandons the system, the company shall remove all visible cable plant from city rights-of-way at company's expense. Prior to such removal, the city shall have an option to purchase the system at its fair market value. 
(Ord. 964 § 28, 1994) 
5.08.320 - Franchise renewal. 
    This franchise may be renewed in accordance with applicable state and federal laws. 
(Ord. 964 § 29, 1994) 
5.08.330 - Work performed by others. 
A.  The provisions of this franchise shall remain the responsibility of company, and company shall be responsible for and hold the city harmless, for any claims or liability arising out of work performed by persons authorized by company. 
B.  All applicable provisions of this franchise shall apply to any subcontractor or authorized persons performing any work or services pursuant to the provisions of this franchise. 
(Ord. 964 § 30, 1994) 
5.08.340 - Franchise enforcement. 
A.  All complaints regarding company's service shall initially be directed to the company and shall be resolved within forty-eight hours where practical. Upon request, the company shall supply the city with copies of all complaints indicating the disposition of each complaint. The report shall indicate the day and hour on which it was received and resolved. When a complaint is received on the day preceding a holiday or a weekend, it shall be serviced on the next working day. This section shall be subject to applicable subscriber privacy provisions. 
B.  The city shall notify the company of each complaint reported to the city. Company shall have the duty of taking whatever reasonable steps are necessary to remedy the cause of the complaint and notify the city of complaint. The city may document such complaints to the company and the company must document the response to logged complaints. 
C.  The company shall notify all customers about complaint procedures, rules and regulations, in compliance with applicable FCC regulations and whenever there is a change in such procedure. 
D.  The company shall comply with the customer service standards promulgated by the FCC pursuant to the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, as amended. 
E.  Failure to remedy the cause of the complaint shall be considered a violation of this franchise and city and company agree that city may, upon final determination of a violation, collect from company the following amounts, adjusted annually by the percentage increase or decrease of the consumer price index, as liquidated damages: 
1.  Failure to comply with the customer service provisions identified with this franchise or applicable customer service provisions under state and federal law-each incident seventy-five dollars; 
2.  Failure to complete system construction as identified in Section 5.08.130 of the franchise-seventy-five dollars per day until completed; 
3.  Failure to comply with any applicable provision of this franchise-fifty dollars per incident per day until corrected. 
F.  In the event the company disagrees with the city's decision regarding a violation subject to the above referenced penalties, the company may submit the dispute to an unaffiliated party, knowledgeable in the cable industry, for nonbinding arbitration. 
G.  It is understood and agreed by and between city and company that if any subscriber, through their own negligence, damages a portion of company's system or otherwise renders company's ability to perform impossible, company may notify city and subscriber which notification shall temporarily stay imposition of any fines until such situation is corrected. 
H.  Company shall not be liable for any delay or failure in performance of any obligation under this franchise when such failure or delay results from acts or omissions of the other party or its subscribers or third parties, Acts of God, acts of any civil or military authority, governmental regulations or requirements, war, terrorist acts, riots, insurrections, explosions, fires, earthquakes, nuclear accidents, flooding, other environmental disturbances, abnormal weather conditions, power blackouts, embargoes, strikes or other labor related disputes, failures of subcontractors or suppliers, or other acts or events beyond the reasonable control of such party. 
(Ord. 964 § 31, 1994) 
5.08.350 - Nonenforcement by city. 
    Subject to applicable federal, state and local laws, company shall not be released of its obligation to comply with any of the provisions of this franchise for reason for any failure of the city to enforce prompt compliance. 
(Ord. 964 § 32, 1994) 
5.08.360 - Acceptance by company. 
A.  Company shall have thirty days from the date of adoption of this franchise to accept this franchise utilizing the acceptance agreement attached as Exhibit C to the ordinance codified in this chapter. Such acceptance by company shall be deemed the grant of this franchise for all purposes. In the event acceptance does not take place within the thirty days or such other time the city might allow, this franchise shall be null and void. 
B.  Upon acceptance of this franchise, company shall be bound by all terms and conditions contained in this chapter. Company shall provide all services and offerings specifically set forth in this chapter to provide cable television services within the city. 
(Ord. 964 § 33, 1994) 
5.08.370 - Activities prohibited. 
    The company shall not allow its cable or other operations to interfere with television reception of persons not served by the company. 
(Ord. 964 § 34, 1994) 
5.08.380 - Not franchise fees. 
    The company agrees that the payments, contributions, services, equipment or other activities to be performed by the company as described in Sections 5.08.130, 5.08.180, 5.08.200, 5.08.270 or otherwise specifically stated in this franchise shall not be considered as franchise fees payable to the city. 
(Ord. 964 § 35, 1994) 
Chapter 5.12 - MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS 
Sections: 

5.12.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Health service operator" means: 
1.  Any person, physical educator or physical director who is qualified by education and training in health services and who is approved by an educational institution to give massage services in any establishment operated by a public school, private school or other educational institution approved by the chief of police and director of the department of public health and welfare; 
2.  Any person, physical educator or physical director who is qualified by education and experience and who has passed the standards and requirements of the Health Service Operators Society of the Y.M.C.A. qualifying the operator to administer massage in an establishment operated by the Fort Worth Y.M.C.A.; 
3.  Any person qualified by education and training to give massage subject to the approval of the chief of police and the director of the department of public health and welfare. 
    "Massage" means and includes any process consisting of kneading, rubbing or otherwise manipulating the skin of the body of a human being, either with the hand or by means of electrical or mechanical instruments or apparatus, but shall not include massage by licensed physicians, osteopaths, chiropractors and naturopaths, physical therapists and health service operators and employees under their supervision and shall not include massage of the face by duly licensed barbers and beauticians. 
    "Massage establishment" means any house, building, room or establishment where massage or manipulated exercises are practiced upon the human body by any person and shall include the use of any modalities in electrotherapy, hydrotherapy and exercise therapy and shall include Turkish and Swedish bath houses but shall not include duly licensed hospitals and offices of physicians, osteopaths, chiropractors and naturopaths, beauty parlors and barbershops licensed under ordinances of the city and the state, and educational institutions, health clubs and private clubs approved by the chief of police and the director of public health and welfare. 
    "Physical therapist" means a graduate of a school approved by the Council on Medical Education and hospitals of the American Registry of Physical Therapists, or a member of the American Physical Therapy Association. 
(Ord. 104 § 1, 1957) 
5.12.020 - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate a massage establishment, as defined in Section 5.12.010, without first having obtained a license therefor from the assessor and collector of taxes, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, and paying the fee provided for in this chapter. Such license shall only be issued upon the approval in writing of the chief of police and the director of the department of public health and welfare. 
(Ord. 104 § 2, 1957) 
5.12.030 - License-Fee. 
    The annual license fee shall be in accordance with Section 1.12.040 for each such establishment. If the license is obtained between January 1st and June 30th of any year, the full amount of the fee shall be paid. If the license is obtained between July 1st and December 31st of any year, the fee shall be one-half of the amount. No refund shall ever be made of any such license fee. 
(Ord. 1032 § 3 (part), 1998: Ord. 104 § 3, 1957) 
5.12.040 - Health certificate required. 
    At the time of making application for such license, the applicant shall furnish to the city health department the names and addresses of all employees of such establishment. The operator and all such employees of the establishment shall secure from the director of the department of public health and welfare a certificate of health stating that such person does not have, or is not a carrier of, any contagious or communicable diseases. The operator and each employee shall have in his possession at all times the certificate of health. Health certificates shall be renewed semiannually. No person who operates any massage establishment shall employ any person to work in such massage establishment who does not have in his possession a certificate of health issued by the director of the department of public health and welfare, the certificate having been issued within the six months preceding. The director may cancel a health certificate of any person when, after examination, such person is found to have some contagious or communicable disease, or is a carrier of such disease. The director may, at his discretion, require the reexamination of any person employed by a massage establishment at any time. 
(Ord. 104 § 4, 1957) 
5.12.050 - Health certificate. 
    Every person who operates a massage establishment is required to have a certificate of health issued by the Tarrant County Health Department. 
(Ord. 1032 § 3 (part), 1998: Ord. 104 § 5, 1957) 
5.12.070 - Registration and identification of applicants and employees. 
    The chief of police shall register the name (including assumed name used or in use), address, place of birth, place of former residence and features of identification, including fingerprints, of the applicant for such license and all employees of such establishment. 
(Ord. 104 § 7, 1957) 
5.12.080 - Employment of prostitutes. 
    It is unlawful for any person operating a massage establishment to employ a known prostitute in any capacity therein. The chief of police shall refuse to approve the issuance of a license to any establishment which employs any person convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude in any state, municipal or federal court, or who employs a woman who has been convicted of vagrancy or prostitution, or who is a known prostitute. The employment of any such person shall be grounds for the revocation by the chief of police of the license issued under this chapter. No massage establishment shall be kept open for any purpose between the hours of ten p.m. and eight a.m., and no such establishment shall be operated or conducted in connection, either directly or indirectly, with any place used for living or sleeping quarters. 
(Ord. 104 § 8, 1957) 
5.12.090 - List of employees. 
    The manager of the establishment or person in charge of such establishment shall keep a list of the names and addresses of all employees, both on duty and off duty, and such list shall be shown to all proper authorities of the police and health departments upon request, and the license required by this chapter shall be exhibited at all times in such establishment. 
(Ord. 104 § 9, 1957) 
5.12.100 - Unlawful to operate in violation of zoning. 
    It is unlawful for any massage establishment to be operated in any section of the city in violation of the zoning ordinance of the city. All applicants shall present evidence of compliance with the zoning ordinance at the time of making application for a license. 
(Ord. 104 § 10, 1957) 
5.12.110 - Sanitation standards. 
A.  It shall be the duty of every person conducting or operating a massage establishment to keep the same at all times in a clean and sanitary condition. All towels and linens furnished for use of one patron shall not be furnished for use of another until thoroughly laundered. 
B.  All operators and employees shall wash their hands thoroughly before administering massage manipulations to each patron accommodated. 
C.  No person suffering from a communicable disease to the knowledge of the owner, custodian or employees of a massage establishment shall be accommodated as a patron therein. 
(Ord. 104 § 11, 1957) 
5.12.120 - Responsibility. 
    The person, firm, corporation or individual managing, keeping or operating a massage establishment shall be responsible for the acts of their employees in the conduct of the business. 
(Ord. 104 § 12, 1957) 
5.12.130 - Violation-Penalty. 
    A person violating any provisions of this chapter shall be fined in any sum not exceeding two hundred dollars for each offense, and each day that such violation continues shall be a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. 104 § 13, 1957) 
Chapter 5.16 - DOOR-TO-DOOR SOLICITORS* 
Sections: 

5.16.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the ordinance codified in this chapter is to protect the citizens against crime, including deceptive practices, fraud and burglary, minimize the unwelcome disturbance of citizens and the disruption of citizens' privacy, and to preserve the public health, safety and general welfare by registering and regulating solicitors. 
(Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1998) 
5.16.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Chief" means the chief of police of the city. 
    "City" means the city of Benbrook, Texas. 
    "Commercial home distribution" means the door-to-door distribution of advertisements or handbills. 
    "Handbill" means any printed sheet or pamphlet, including printed or written matter, any sample or device, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature. 
    "Minor" means a person under the age of eighteen. 
    "Peddler" means one who sells or offers for sale tangible merchandise from a location on private premises for profit and delivery is made at or soon after the time of the sale. 
    "Solicitation activities" means traveling either by foot or vehicle, going door-to-door, house-to-house, building-to-building, or along any street in the city, personally contacting occupants or other persons within residential dwellings or commercial business establishments, selling or taking orders for or offering to sell or take orders for goods or services for commercial purposes. 
    "Solicitor" means a person who engages in solicitation activities. 
    "Traffic safety vest" means a high visibility vest made of fluorescent orange or yellow material that may be clearly seen at any time of the day. 
(Ord. 1090 § 1 (part), 2001; Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1998) 
(Ord. No. 1325, § 1, 8-18-2011) 
5.16.030 - Registration required. 
    A person, other than a minor, shall not engage in solicitation activities in the city without first registering with the city and obtaining a registration certificate and identification badge from the city secretary. 
(Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1998) 
5.16.040 - Application for registration. 
    A separate application for a solicitor's registration is required for each solicitor. An application must contain the following information: 
A.  Proof of age, address and identification of the applicant, to be provided through the applicant's driver's license, articles of incorporation, or other legally recognized form of identification; 
B.  If the solicitor is employed by another, the name and business address of the employer; if acting as an agent, the name, address and telephone number of the principal who is being represented, with credentials in written form establishing the relationship and the authority of the employee or agent to act for the employer or principal; 
C.  A brief description of the goods or services to be sold or offered for sale; 
D.  The hours and location of the solicitation activities; 
E.  Proof of possession of any license or permit which, under federal, state or local laws or regulations, the applicant is required to have in order to conduct the proposed business, or which, under any law or regulation, would exempt the applicant from the registration requirements of this chapter; 
F.  Two photographs of the applicant, measuring at least one and one-half by two inches and showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner, which was taken within the preceding sixty days before the filing of the application; 
G.  It shall be unlawful for any door-to-door solicitor to engage in business within the city without having obtained and presented a sales tax permit issued by the State of Texas, if applicable; and 
H.  Peddler or roadside vendors are not allowed to operate within the city. 
(Ord. 1141 § 1 (part), 2003; Ord. 1090 § 1 (part), 2001; Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1998) 
5.16.050 - Bond. 
A.  Solicitors that require cash deposits or payment for future delivery or who require a contract or agreement to finance the sale of goods or services for future delivery, or for services to be performed in the future, shall furnish to the city a bond with the application in the amount determined in subsection C of this section, signed by the applicant and surety company authorized to do business in Texas, conditioned: 
1.  For the final delivery of goods or services in accordance with the terms of any order obtained; 
2.  To indemnify purchases for defects in material or workmanship that may exist in the goods sold and that are discovered within thirty days after delivery; 
3.  For the use and benefit of persons that make a purchase or give an order to the principal of the bond or to the agent or employee of the principal of the bond. 
B.  If the applicant is a person, firm or corporation engaging in solicitation activities through one or more agents or employees, only one bond is required for the activities of all the agent or employee solicitors. 
C.  The amount of the bond is determined by the number of solicitors acting as agents or employees of the same person, firm or corporation as follows: 
1-3 solicitors $500.00 4-6 solicitors 750.00 7 or more solicitors 1,000.00  
(Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1998) 
5.16.060 - Fees and duration. 
    An applicant for registration shall pay an annual fee in accordance with Section 1.12.040 for each solicitor. A solicitation registration is valid for one year. 
(Ord. 1141 § 1 (part), 2003; Ord. 1090 § 1 (part), 2001; Ord. 1032 § 3 (part), 1998: Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1998) 
5.16.070 - Application review and approval. 
A.  Upon receipt of an application, the city secretary and the chief shall review the application to ensure the protection of the public health, safety and general welfare. 
B.  If the city secretary and the chief find that none of the reasons for denial listed in Section 5.16.090, exists, the city secretary shall approve the application. 
(Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1998) 
5.16.080 - Registration certificate and identification badge. 
A.  Upon approval of the application and applicant's payment of the fee, the city secretary shall deliver a registration certificate and identification badge for each registered solicitor. 
B.  The registration certificate shall show the name, address and photograph of the solicitor, the kind of goods or services to be sold or offered for sale, a description of any vehicle to be used in carrying on the solicitation activities, the registration number, and the dates of issuance and expiration of the certificate. 
C.  The registration certificate must be carried by the solicitor while engaging in solicitation activities. 
D.  While engaging in solicitation activities, a solicitor shall wear the identification badge so that it may be easily read by those being solicited. If a badge becomes damaged, the solicitor shall return it to the city and receive a replacement badge. 
E.  A registration certificate and an identification badge shall be used only by the person to whom they were issued and may not be transferred to another person. 
(Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1998) 
5.16.090 - Denial of registration. 
A.  The city secretary shall deny an application for registration if the city secretary or the chief finds any of the following to be true: 
1.  An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on the application. 
2.  Within five years preceding the date of application, the applicant or an employee or agent of the applicant, has been convicted of a felony, misdemeanor or ordinance violation involving a sex offense, controlled substances, or any violent acts against persons or property. 
3.  The applicant is a person against whom a judgment, conviction or deferred adjudication has been entered within five years preceding the date of application, based upon fraud, deceit or misrepresentation. 
4.  The applicant provided no proof of authority to serve as agent for the principal. 
5.  The type of solicitation activity requires a bond, and the applicant has not complied with the bond requirements. 
6.  The applicant has been denied registration under this chapter within the previous twelve months and the applicant has now shown to the satisfaction of the city secretary and the chief that the reasons for the earlier denial no longer exist. 
B.  The city secretary shall note the reasons for a denial on the application, and notify the applicant of the denial by notice mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the application or the last known address. 
(Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1998) 
5.16.110 - Regulations. 
A.  A solicitor shall not engage in solicitation activities: 
1.  Between the hours of nine p.m. and nine a.m.; or 
2.  At a residence or business that has a sign posted giving notice that solicitors are not welcome, such as "no solicitors," or words of similar meaning. 
B.  If a person uses a vehicle in solicitation activities, there must be a sign located in a conspicuous place on the vehicle, identifying the name of the person or the company or organization that the person represents. If the name is an individual, it must be followed by the word "solicitor." The letter on the sign must be at least two and one-half inches high. 
C.  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct themselves as a solicitor or to engage in commercial home distribution without wearing a traffic safety vest. 
(Ord. 1141 § 1 (part), 2003; Ord. 1090 § 1 (part), 2001; Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1998) 
(Ord. No. 1325, § 1, 8-18-2011) 
5.16.120 - Revocation or suspension of registration. 
    A registration certificate issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked or suspended by the chief, after notice and hearing, for any of the following reasons: 
A.  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for registration; 
B.  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made by a solicitor in the course of conducting solicitation activities; 
C.  Conducting solicitation activities which were not described in the application; 
D.  Conviction for a crime described in Section 5.16.090A2; or 
E.  Conducting solicitation activities in such a manner as to create a public nuisance, constitute disorderly conduct, or endanger the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1998) 
5.16.130 - Appeals. 
A.  A person who is denied registration or whose registration is revoked or suspended by the chief, may appeal the decision to the city manager by filing notice of appeal with the city secretary within fifteen days after the notice of the decision is mailed to the address indicated on the application or the last known address of the solicitor. 
B.  Within ten days of the receipt of the notice of appeal, the city manager shall set a time and place for a hearing on the appeal which shall be not later than thirty days from the date of receipt of the notice of appeal. 
C.  Notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be delivered to the applicant by mail, sent to the address indicated on the application or the last known address of the applicant. 
D.  The decision of the city manager on the appeal is final. No other administrative procedures are provided by the city. 
(Ord. 1014 § 1 (part), 1998) 
Chapter 5.20 - RECREATIONAL FACILITIES 
Sections: 

5.20.010 - Generally. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall, after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, operate or maintain a place of recreation within the corporate limits of the city without first having obtained a permit as specified by this chapter. 
(Ord. 324 § 1, 1973) 
5.20.020 - Place of recreation defined. 
    "Place of recreation" means a dance hall, pool hall, domino parlor, carnival, amusement hall, arcade, establishment for amusement purposes, or establishment providing more than an aggregate total of one mechanical game of skill, including pinball machines, marble machines, table shuffleboard or table-type nine and ten pin alley and shooting gallery machines. 
(Ord. 468 § 2, 1976: Ord. 324 § 2, 1973) 
5.20.030 - License required-Location restriction. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm, association of persons, corporations, or any other organization, save and except a religious, educational, charitable, benevolent and/or nonprofit association or corporation, to own, operate or maintain any place of recreation, as such term is defined in Section 5.20.020, within six blocks (a block being defined as six hundred feet in length) of any school property, inhabited residential area, or church property within the city, without having first obtained an appropriate license from the city secretary, as provided in this chapter, which license shall at all times be displayed in some conspicuous place within the licensed place of business. 
(Ord. 468 § 1, 1976: Ord. 427 § 1, 1976: Ord. 324 § 1, 1973) 
5.20.040 - Compliance with standards required. 
    No license shall be granted pursuant to this chapter unless it appears, upon investigation by the city manager, that the premises to be used for the purpose of operating a place of recreation comply with the laws of the state and the ordinances of the city regulating health and sanitation, the fire regulations, the zoning regulations and the building code. 
(Ord. 324 § 4, 1973) 
5.20.050 - License-Application. 
A.  Any person desiring a license to operate a place of recreation shall file with the city secretary a written, sworn application for such license, which application shall state: 
1.  The location, by street and number, of the place, space or building and room or floor, and the size of such room or space, which is proposed to be used for such purpose, and the name and address of the applicant; 
2.  If the applicant is an individual, that he is a law-abiding, tax-paying citizen of the state; that he has not been convicted of a felony, or, if he has, the nature of the offense; and the length of his residence in the city; 
3.  If the applicant is a firm, association or partnership, all of the information prescribed in subdivision 2 of this subsection as to each individual composing the firm, association or partnership; 
4.  If the applicant is a corporation, that the applicant is organized and chartered under the corporation laws of the state applicable to such corporation, or, if a foreign corporation, that such corporation has complied with the laws of the state applicable to such corporation and the same information with reference to the operator or person in charge of the operation of the place of recreation to be licensed as is prescribed in subdivision 2 of this subsection; 
5.  The previous occupation or employment of the applicant for a period of five years next preceding the filing of his application; 
6.  The number and type of games of skill, mechanical games, pool tables, etc., or if the applicant desires to operate a dance hall, domino parlor or carnival, a narrative description of the activities to be carried out within the location specified; 
7.  The owner or supplier of all mechanical games of skill with specific indications as to any commissions to be paid from income from each or all machines for use of such machines, save and except jukeboxes, music boxes or food and beverage machines; 
8.  Any religious, educational, benevolent, charitable or other nonprofit association shall be required upon request by the city manager to furnish proof at any time of its religious, educational, charitable, benevolent and nonprofit status. Failure to respond to such request in the affirmative within ten days shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
B.  The information given in such application is for the purpose of determining whether or not the applicant is a fit and proper person to operate a place of recreation. It is unlawful to misrepresent the kind and character of the place of recreation to be operated, or any other fact or statement made in such application, and any misrepresentation of any person, club or organization for the purpose of avoiding the provisions of this chapter shall, in addition to the other penalties prescribed by law, be cause for revocation of the license. 
(Ord. 468 § 3, 1976; Ord. 324 § 5, 1973) 
5.20.060 - License-Fee. 
A.  In addition to all legal taxes, certificate fees and occupational taxes levied or charged by the city, state, or other jurisdictions, there shall be an annual license fee charged by the city to the owner or operator of any approved place of recreation, and such license fee shall be based on the schedule in Section 1.12.040. 
B.  No annual license fee charged under this chapter by the city will be in excess of the maximum specified in Section 1.12.040 if a combination of types of machines, pool tables or uses of any single place of recreation would yield a total aggregate annual license fee of more than the maximum specified. 
(Ord. 1032 § 3 (part), 1998: Ord. 324 § 6, 1973) 
5.20.070 - License-Term-Nontransferable. 
    The city secretary is authorized to collect the annual license fee for each location approved as a place of recreation and the term of the license shall be for one year from the date of issuance. Any license issued under the terms of this chapter shall be nontransferable. 
(Ord. 324 § 7 (part), 1973) 
5.20.080 - Appeal. 
    In the event the city manager fails to approve the issuance of a license to any applicant under this chapter, the action of such official shall be final, unless the applicant shall, within ten days after the refusal to grant such license, file a written appeal with the city secretary, addressed to the city council, requesting a hearing by the council upon the question as to whether or not his application shall be granted. In the event such appeal is filed, the chief of police shall provide the council with a record of all proceedings theretofore had with reference to the application in question, including the written application, together with the action of the city manager and the reasons for such action. The city council shall, within thirty days, grant a hearing thereon to determine the correctness of such action, at which hearing the council may make such investigation as it may see fit, whether or not all the pertinent facts appear in the application. It shall be discretionary with the council as to whether or not a license shall be granted and such action as the council may take thereon shall be final and conclusive. Any applicant aggrieved by the action of the city council incident to its application shall have the right within thirty days after the council has so acted to appeal to the district courts of the county, on the grounds that the city council has acted arbitrarily or capriciously with regard to the proposed application. 
(Ord. 324 § 7 (part), 1973) 
5.20.090 - License subject to revocation. 
    The granting of any license under the terms of this chapter shall in no event be construed as the granting or conferring of any vested right to the licensee or operator, but shall be subject to revocation, cancellation or suspension as further provided. 
(Ord. 324 § 8, 1973) 
5.20.100 - License-Renewal. 
    Before a place-of-recreation license shall be renewed, the person requesting such renewal shall make application for such renewal and the renewal thereof shall be subject to all of the requirements and conditions as an original application for the original license, and the renewal of the license shall not be granted without the approval of the city manager, as is required in the case of original applications, and without the payment of the fee as provided in Section 5.20.060. 
(Ord. 324 § 9, 1973) 
5.20.110 - License-Revocation, cancellation or suspension. 
A.  If a place of recreation licensed under the provisions of this chapter is not being conducted in accordance with the laws of the state or this chapter, or is being conducted in violation of the laws of this state or this chapter, the chief of police may, at any time, give notice in writing to the operator, licensee, manager or other person in control of the operation and maintenance of such place of recreation that the license issued for the operation and maintenance of such place of recreation has been revoked, canceled or suspended. 
B.  The notice of revocation, cancellation or suspension shall become a final revocation, cancellation or suspension after the expiration of ten days from the date of the service of same upon the operator, licensee, manager or other person in charge, unless, on or before the expiration of such ten days, the licensee, operator or manager or other person in charge shall file with the city secretary a written appeal addressed to the city council in which it is requested that the council grant him a hearing upon the question of whether or not the license shall be canceled, revoked or suspended. 
C.  Such appeal shall operate as a stay or postponement of the revocation, cancellation or suspension of the license issued, until such time as the council shall grant a hearing and make a final decision. Such hearing shall be held within thirty days after the date of the filing of such appeal, and the action and judgment of the council, after hearing all of the evidence and facts, shall be final and conclusive as to all parties. 
D.  Any applicant aggrieved by the action of the city council incident to his application shall have the right within thirty days after the city council has so acted to appeal to the district courts of the county on the grounds that the city council has acted arbitrarily or capriciously with regard to the proposed application. 
(Ord. 324 § 10, 1973) 
5.20.120 - Hours of operation. 
    No place of recreation shall be operated within the city between the hours of twelve midnight and twelve noon on any day; provided, however, that such places of recreation may not be operated on Sundays, except during the hours of one p.m. to twelve midnight. 
(Ord. 324 § 11, 1973) 
5.20.130 - Alcoholic beverages and drugs prohibited. 
A.  No person, firm, association of persons, corporations or any other organizations authorized under the laws of the state, licensed under this chapter, shall knowingly permit the use, consumption or possession of any kind of alcoholic beverage or beverages in or upon the premises for which a license has been issued as provided in this chapter. No person, firm, association of persons, corporation, etc., licensed under this chapter, shall knowingly permit the use, consumption or possession of addictive or mind-altering drugs, narcotics or any other substances that are illegal to use or possess by federal, state or local laws. 
B.  It shall be the duty and responsibility of the owner, operator and agents in control of the place of recreation to exercise diligent and extreme supervisory powers to assure that persons under the influence of alcoholic beverages, addictive or mind-altering drugs, narcotics or any other illegal substance are not admitted to the place of recreation and that such persons are not permitted to loiter, stand, stay or remain within a vehicle in areas surrounding the place of recreation, which areas are under the ownership, control or dominion of the owner, operator or their agents, and which is normally used as public parking for either the place of recreation or any surrounding commercial businesses or residential dwellings. 
(Ord. 324 § 12, 1973) 
5.20.140 - Certain activities and persons prohibited. 
A.  It is unlawful for any owner or operator to knowingly permit or allow any known prostitute, beggar, drunkard or criminal character to be present or participate at or in any place of business licensed under this chapter. 
B.  It is likewise unlawful for any owner or operator to knowingly permit or allow on the premises any person who is under parole or probation for any felony criminal offense. 
C.  It is unlawful for any owner or operator to knowingly employ any person on the premises who has been convicted of a felony. 
D.  The owner, operator or person in charge of any place of business licensed under this chapter shall not allow gambling or profane, loud or abusive language on the premises. The conduct described in this subsection shall and does constitute disorderly conduct detrimental to the health, morals and general welfare of the citizens of the city. 
E.  Free access and entrance into any premises licensed under this chapter shall at all times be accorded and granted to police and other officers of the city. 
(Ord. 324 § 13, 1973) 
5.20.150 - Responsibility of licensee. 
    It shall be the duty of each licensee to prevent violations of the terms of this chapter, and a failure to do so shall constitute sufficient cause for revocation of any license granted under this chapter. The owner and/or operator of the establishment is to be responsible that good order is maintained, and it shall be the duty of the owner, keeper or proprietor to keep good order within the establishment and to prevent all persons who may be therein from disturbing the peace and tranquility of the inhabitants of the building, the inhabitants of the neighborhood or passersby of the establishment, by loud, profane or indecent language or by any noise or disturbance whatsoever. 
(Ord. 324 § 14, 1973) 
5.20.160 - Majority ownership required. 
A.  No place of recreation shall be operated unless the applicant for license owns and maintains ownership of a majority of the equipment, machines and fixtures utilized for recreational purposes, exclusive of the building and realty occupied by the recreational center. 
B.  "Ownership" means the applicant for license having purchased or contracted to purchase such equipment, machines and fixtures wherein payment for same is not based upon the direct revenue produced from the equipment, machines and fixtures, or wherein placement of same is not based on a commission to be retained by the applicant for license while ownership of the equipment, machines and fixtures is retained by a supplier. "Ownership" is not defined as to include a lease with an option to buy. 
(Ord. 324 § 15, 1973) 
5.20.170 - Inspection of premises. 
    The city manager shall have the authority to appoint or designate a person to make periodic inspections of the premises licensed under this chapter for the purpose of determining whether or not such premises are in compliance with the health, plumbing and sanitary and other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. 324 § 16, 1973) 
5.20.180 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter, shall be fined not less than five dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate and distinct offense and shall be punishable as such. 
B.  The city may also bring suit for injunction against any person, firm or corporation that shall violate, or threaten to violate, any of the provisions of this chapter, in order to prevent a continued violation or such threatened violation. 
(Ord. 324 § 19, 1973) 
Chapter 5.24 - TAXICABS 
Sections: 

5.24.010 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions are adopted and declared for the construction of this chapter: 
A.  "Person" includes both singular and plural and means any person, firm or corporation, their or its agents, servants and employees. 
B.  "Public vehicle" means and includes any motor vehicle operated within the corporate limits of the city for the purpose of carrying passengers for hire, except such vehicles as are exempted from the definition of the word "taxicab," as defined in this section, it being the intention to make the words "taxicab" and "public vehicle" synonymous for the purposes of this chapter. 
C.  "Street" means and includes any street, alley, avenue, lane, public place or highway within the corporate limits of the city. 
D.  "Taxicab" means and includes every vehicle used for transportation of passengers over the streets of the city, with the following exceptions: 
1.  A vehicle being operated pursuant to a franchise or permit issued by the city, or pursuant to a franchise or permit legally issued by the Railroad Commission of the state, or pursuant to permission duly granted by proper authority of the city for a vehicle to operate over a regular route upon a set schedule, or pursuant to any permission duly granted by the city council, or a vehicle being operated as a chartered bus under a contract to carry a group of passengers; 
2.  A vehicle being used as an ambulance; 
3.  Vehicles rented or leased for self-operation by the person actually driving the same, unless such vehicle is transporting for compensation persons other than the one who actually is renting or leasing the same; 
4.  Taxicabs duly licensed in other municipalities when entering the corporate limits of the city for the purpose of discharging a passenger or passengers on rides which have originated outside of the corporate limits; provided, that such taxicab does not pick up or solicit passengers within the corporate limits of the city; and provided further, such taxicab immediately departs from the city by the most direct route after discharge of a passenger or passengers within the corporate limits of the city. 
E.  "Taximeter" means and includes a mechanical instrument or device by which the charge for hire of a taxicab is mechanically calculated either for distance traveled or for waiting time, or for both, and upon which charge is plainly registered by means of figures indicating dollars and cents. 
(Ord. 77 § 1, 1955) 
5.24.020 - Certificate and license required. 
    No taxicab or public vehicle shall be operated for the transportation of persons as passengers for compensation or hire within the corporate limits of the city, nor shall any person operate the same, without first having obtained from the city council a certificate declaring that the public convenience and necessity require such operation, and without first having a license therefor, as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 77 § 2, 1955) 
5.24.030 - Certificate-Application. 
    Application for a certificate of public convenience and necessity for the operation of taxicabs or public vehicles within the city shall be made to the city council and shall set forth in writing: 
A.  The name and address of the applicant and the trade name under which the applicant proposes to do business; 
B.  The number of vehicles the applicant desires to operate, the class, seating capacity, design and color scheme of each vehicle, and the lettering and marks to be used thereon; 
C.  Whether or not the applicant has been convicted of the violation of any national, state or municipal law, and whether or not the applicant or any person, firm or corporation with whom he has been associated or employed has claims or judgments against him or them for damages resulting from the negligent operation of a public vehicle; 
D.  The financial ability and responsibility of the applicant, and his or its ability to respond in damages in the event of injury to persons or damage to property by reason of the negligent operation of a public vehicle; 
E.  If the applicant is a firm or corporation, its organization and personnel; 
F.  The nature and character of service that the applicant proposes to render, together with facts showing the demand for such service; 
G.  The experience the applicant has had in rendering such service; 
H.  Facts showing that adequate and dependable service can be rendered for the price stipulated and that such price is a fair and reasonable charge for the service to be rendered; and 
I.  Any other information that may be required by the city council. 
(Ord. 77 § 3, 1955) 
5.24.040 - Investigation of applicant. 
A.  The city council shall make or cause to be made such investigation as it may consider necessary, including any hearings that it may deem advisable, as to any applications for such certificates, and the city council shall determine whether or not the public convenience and necessity require the operation of such vehicle or vehicles and whether or not the applicant is a fit and proper person to conduct business; and in making such determination, the city council shall give weight and due regard, among other things, to the following: 
1.  Probable permanence and quality of service offered by the applicant, his experience in rendering such service, and his experience in adjusting claims and paying judgments, if any, to claimants as a result of injuries received from the negligent operation of public vehicles; 
2.  The financial ability of the applicant to respond in damages in the event of negligent operation of a public vehicle; 
3.  The prices the applicant proposes to charge for service to be rendered, and whether or not such proposed prices are reasonable; and 
4.  The character and condition of the vehicles proposed by the applicant to be used. 
B.  The evidence in any investigation, inquiry or hearing may be taken by the city council or by any member, agent or employee of the council to whom such duty is assigned, and every finding, opinion and order made by the council, or by its authorized member, agent or employee, pursuant to such investigation, inquiry or hearing, when adopted, approved or affirmed by the council, shall be the finding, opinion or order of the city council. 
(Ord. 77 § 4, 1955) 
5.24.050 - Certificate-Issuance or denial. 
A.  If the city council finds that the public convenience and necessity require the operation of a public vehicle or vehicles as requested in the application, or the operation of a greater or lesser number of vehicles than that for which the certificate has been applied for, and that the applicant is fit to conduct such business, and that other requirements have been complied with, the mayor, under the attest of the city secretary, shall issue to the applicant a certificate of public necessity and convenience accordingly. 
B.  If the city council finds that the public convenience and necessity do not require the operation of such vehicle or vehicles, or that the applicant is not a fit and proper person to conduct such business, it shall forthwith refuse such application, and no certificate or license shall be issued to such applicant. 
C.  Such certificate shall not be transferable without the consent and approval of the city council, after application and hearing as provided upon original application by the person to whom the certificate was issued, but an applicant may, by appropriate endorsement made on such certificate under the direction of the city council, substitute another vehicle or vehicles in the place of that for which the certificate was granted. 
(Ord. 77 § 5, 1955) 
5.24.060 - License approval and issuance-Term of certificate. 
    Upon presentation of the certificate of public convenience and necessity within thirty days of its date, and satisfactory evidence that all rental fees have been paid to the city and that such other fees and taxes as may be required by law have been fully paid, the mayor, under the attest of the city secretary, shall issue to the applicant a license for each and every vehicle specified in the certificate; provided, however, that any certificate issued hereunder shall be effective until canceled, and no additional certificate or certificates shall be required for the purpose of obtaining a license so long as the original certificate remains in effect and the applicant strictly complies with all the requirements and provisions of this chapter; and provided further, that such owner or operator of a public vehicle for hire shall be strictly limited to the character and type of operation as evidenced by such application and as specified in such certificate and license. No license for the operation of a public vehicle shall be issued, nor shall any public vehicle be operated within the city, unless and until the city council has issued a certificate of public convenience and necessity under the terms and provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 77 § 6, 1955) 
5.24.070 - Application fee. 
    Every applicant for a certificate of public convenience and necessity with reference to the operation of a vehicle or vehicles shall be accompanied by an application fee as specified in Section 1.12.040, to partially defray the expense of investigating such application. If the certificate is subsequently granted, and the applicant thereafter engages in the business of transporting passengers for hire within the city, such application fee shall be applied as a credit on the street rental fee becoming due under subsequent provisions of this chapter. If the certificate is denied, or if the applicant fails to engage in such business after the granting of such certificate, then the application fee shall be forfeited to partially defray the expense of such investigation. 
(Ord. 1032 § 3 (part), 1998: Ord. 77 § 7, 1955) 
5.24.080 - Inspection of vehicle prior to license issuance. 
    Before any license is issued for the operation of a public vehicle, the chief of police of the city shall cause to be made an inspection of such vehicle, and the chief of police shall from time to time thereafter cause to be made an inspection of all public vehicles licensed by the city, and if any vehicle shall be found unfit or unsafe for operation, notice shall be given to the holder of the certificate and license therefor, and such vehicle shall not be operated within the corporate limits thereafter until the same has been put in a safe and fit condition. 
(Ord. 77 § 8, 1955) 
5.24.090 - Operation without certificate and license prohibited. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated upon the public streets or within the corporate limits of the city any taxicab or public vehicle unless the city council has issued a certificate of public convenience and necessity therefor, and unless a license has been issued for the particular vehicle pursuant to the certificate, and after inspection of such vehicle as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 77 § 9, 1955) 
5.24.100 - Waiting on public street prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any taxicab or public vehicle to stand waiting employment upon any public street or public property within the corporate limits of the city, but the same must stand and remain, except while in the immediate act of discharging or taking on passengers, or awaiting a passenger upon instructions by the passenger, upon and within private depots and grounds or upon private premises. 
(Ord. 77 § 10, 1955) 
5.24.110 - Restrictions upon methods of soliciting business. 
    No owner, employee or other person in behalf of the owner or operator of any public vehicle shall solicit by word, signal or otherwise, patronage for such public vehicle on any public street or public property, or the sidewalks of the municipality, and public vehicles are prohibited from cruising, seeking employment or in any manner soliciting by word, signal or otherwise, patronage for such vehicle while in operation or in use upon any public street or public property. 
(Ord. 77 § 11, 1955) 
5.24.120 - Unauthorized operation prohibited. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall use the terms "taxi" or "taxicab" or "for-hire automobile" or "for-hire car" or "auto rental," or in any way advertise or hold themselves out as a taxicab or for-hire automobile company or operator, or represent themselves to be such by means of any advertisement, sign, trade name or otherwise, unless they have previously thereto complied with the conditions, regulations and restrictions prescribed by this chapter. 
(Ord. 77 § 12, 1955) 
5.24.130 - Record of daily operation-Application for additional taxicabs. 
    The owner or operator of any taxicab or public vehicle shall keep a daily record of the transportation or trips of each vehicle, and such record shall show in detail the hour and place of departure and return of each trip, its destination and the name of the operator of the vehicle, as well as the revenue derived therefor. The owner of any certificate of necessity and convenience issued upon the terms of this chapter shall be authorized to operate in the city only the number of taxicabs specified on such certificate. If the public necessity and convenience require the operation of additional taxicabs at any time, then, after formal application to the city council, the council may authorize such holder to add additional taxicabs to his fleet. An application for additional taxicabs shall be accompanied by a fee of fifteen dollars, which shall be applied in the same manner as the fee accompanying an original application. If the city council finds that the public necessity and convenience require additional taxicabs, then it shall authorize the applicant to add to its fleet a designated number of taxicabs. 
(Ord. 77 § 13, 1955) 
5.24.140 - Revocation of certificate. 
A.  If the holder of any certificate of necessity and convenience shall show by his actions that he is not a fit and proper person to operate taxicabs in the city, or if the financial position of the holder shall reach such condition that the city council does not deem the holder able to pay in full reasonable claims for damages which might be legally established, or if for good and sufficient reasons, the general welfare of the city will be best served by such action, the city council may, after hearing, revoke and cancel any certificate of necessity and convenience issued by it under the terms of this chapter. 
B.  The city council shall have the right, for any reason, to suspend any certificate of necessity and convenience issued under the terms of this chapter for a period not to exceed thirty days, pending investigation and hearing to revoke and cancel such certificate, which suspension may be without prior notice. 
(Ord. 77 § 14, 1955) 
5.24.150 - Hearing. 
    The hearing specified in Section 5.24.140 shall not be held until notice has been given to the holder of the certificate in question by registered mail addressed to him at the address shown on the records of the city at least five days before the date set for such hearing. Such notice shall specify the time and place of the hearing and shall list the reasons why the general welfare of the city requires the revocation and cancellation of the certificate. The holder of the certificate in question shall be allowed to be present at such hearing, which shall be public, and shall be allowed to be represented by counsel if he so desires. He shall have full opportunity to disprove any and all charges and allegations set forth in the notice. Such hearing may be conducted by the city council or any agent designated by it. Upon approval and adoption by the city council of findings of fact pursuant to such hearing that the holder of a certificate is not a fit and proper person to conduct such business, or is unable to pay in full reasonable claims for damages which might be asserted, or for any reason the general welfare of the city will be served best by such action, then the city council shall revoke and cancel the certificate of necessity and convenience in question, and there shall be no appeal of any nature from such action. 
(Ord. 77 § 15, 1955) 
5.24.160 - Street rental fee. 
    As compensation or rental or license fee for the privilege of operating upon and using the public streets and thoroughfares of the city in conducting and carrying on the business of transporting passengers for hire over the streets and thoroughfares of the city, each holder of a certificate of necessity and convenience issued under the terms of this chapter shall pay to the city at the office of the city secretary an amount specified in Section 1.12.040. Such amount shall be paid monthly for each calendar month on or before the fifteenth day of the succeeding month. Such compensation shall be in lieu of all other fees to be paid by taxicab operators, but shall not be construed to be in lieu of any validly assessed ad valorem taxes. 
(Ord. 1032 § 3 (part), 1998: Ord. 77 § 16, 1955) 
5.24.170 - Statement of monthly receipts. 
    Each holder of a certificate of necessity and convenience shall file with the city secretary a sworn statement showing all receipts for each calendar month, such sworn statement to be filed prior to the tenth day of the succeeding calendar month. 
(Ord. 77 § 17, 1955) 
5.24.180 - Failure to report or pay fee-Penalty. 
    The failure of any holder of a certificate of necessity and convenience to file with the city secretary a sworn statement showing all receipts from taxicab operations as required by this chapter, or the failure of such holder to pay the street rental fee of two percent of the gross revenues derived from its operations as provided by this chapter, shall automatically suspend the certificate of necessity and convenience issued to the person that is in default, and such suspension shall continue and be in full force and effect until such omission or default has been corrected. 
(Ord. 77 § 18, 1955) 
5.24.190 - Taximeter required. 
A.  It is unlawful for the owner, operator or driver of any taxicab or public vehicle to operate or cause to be operated, or drive or cause to be driven, any taxicab on the streets of the city unless the taxicab is equipped with a taximeter to keep the same accurate at all times, and the taximeter shall be subject to inspection by the chief of police or his assistants at any time. 
B.  It is unlawful for the driver of a taxicab, while carrying passengers, to operate the taxicab unless the taximeter is in a recording position. 
(Ord. 77 § 19, 1955) 
5.24.200 - Display of license and permit required. 
    Both the owner's license for the particular vehicle and the driver's permit shall be attached to each taxicab or public vehicle in some conspicuous place where it may be easily seen by the passenger or passengers using the same, and upon request, the driver or owner of any taxicab shall furnish full particulars to any passenger with respect to the name of the driver, name of the owner of the vehicle, license number and dates of licenses pertaining to the vehicle or the driver. 
(Ord. 77 § 22, 1955) 
5.24.210 - Rate schedule. 
    A schedule of rates to be charged the public by any person, firm or corporation operating taxicabs or public vehicles within the city shall be filed by such person, firm or corporation with the city secretary, and such rates shall be subject to the approval of the city council. Such schedule of rates shall be subject to change by the city council as conditions seem to the council to warrant, provided that the council shall not enforce or compel lower rates than will allow a fair return on the investment of the operator. The issuance of a certificate of convenience and necessity shall not convey any vested right to the applicant to charge rates as proposed in his application, but such rates shall be subject to regulation as provided in this section. 
(Ord. 77 § 26, 1955) 
5.24.220 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be fined in any amount not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense, and each day that a violation of this chapter continues is declared to constitute a separate offense. 
B.  Continued or wilful violation of any provision of this chapter shall be sufficient cause for the city to revoke and cancel any license, permit or certificate under which the person guilty of such wilful or continued violation is acting; and in addition to all other remedies provided in this chapter, the city shall have the right to institute any appropriate actions or proceedings in any competent court having jurisdiction thereof to restrain, correct or abate such violations, the penalties provided in this section being merely cumulative of all other remedies available to the city for such violations. 
(Ord. 77 §§ 24, 25, 1955) 
Chapter 5.28 - MOTOR VEHICLE JUNKYARDS 
Sections: 

5.28.010 - Certificate of approval and license required. 
    No motor vehicle junkyard or business shall be established, operated or maintained in the city, unless a certificate of approval has been procured from the city council and a license for the motor vehicle junkyard or business has been obtained from the city secretary. 
(Ord. 293 § 1 (part), 1971) 
5.28.020 - Motor vehicle junkyard or business defined. 
    "Motor vehicle junkyard or business," as used in this chapter, is defined as any business and any place of storage or deposit which displays, or in or upon which there are displayed, one or more vehicles which are unfit for reconditioning for use on the public highways, or used parts of motor vehicles or old iron, metal, glass, paper, cordage or other waste, discarded or secondhand material which has been a part, or is intended to be a part, of any motor vehicle, the sum of which parts or material shall be equal in bulk to one or more motor vehicles. 
(Ord. 293 § 1 (part), 1971) 
5.28.030 - Vehicles unfit for reconditioning. 
A.  A vehicle which does not bear a current year's license plate evidencing registration, and in addition a current year's state inspection sticker evidencing inspection, shall be prima facie deemed to be a vehicle which is unfit for reconditioning for use on the public highways. 
B.  A vehicle which remains in inoperable condition for a period of six weeks or more, although it bears a current year's license plate and a current year's state inspection sticker, shall likewise be prima facie deemed to be a vehicle which is unfit for reconditioning for use on the public highways. 
(Ord. 293 § 1 (part), 1971) 
5.28.040 - Certificate-Application. 
    Application for a certificate of approval required by Section 5.28.010 shall be made to the city council and shall set forth the following information: 
A.  The name and address of the applicant; 
B.  The trade name under which the applicant does or proposes to do business; 
C.  The location where such business is to be conducted; 
D.  If the applicant is a firm or corporation, its organization and personnel; 
E.  The size of the territory the applicant proposes to allot such business; 
F.  That the interest of the city requires the establishing, operating or maintaining of such yard or business at the location designated; and 
G.  Any other information as may be required by the city council. 
(Ord. 293 § 2, 1971) 
5.28.050 - Investigation of applicant. 
    The city council shall make or cause to be made such investigations as it may deem desirable, as to any application for a certificate of approval under this chapter, and shall determine whether or not, in the interest of the safety, health, decency, comfort, convenience, necessity and welfare of the inhabitants of the city, or requirement for the operation of such a business exists, and whether or not the applicant is a fit and proper person or concern to conduct such business; and such investigation may extend to the fitness of the stockholders and officers of any corporation making such application. The city council, in considering such application, shall take into account the nature and development of surrounding property, the proximity of churches, schools, hospitals, public buildings and other places of public gathering, the sufficiency in number of such other yards or businesses in the vicinity, the health, safety and general welfare of the public, and the suitability of the applicant to establish, maintain or operate such yard or business and receive a license therefor. 
(Ord. 293 § 3, 1971) 
5.28.060 - Approval or denial of application. 
    If the city council finds that the convenience, necessity, welfare and comfort of the public requires the operation of a motor vehicle junkyard and that the applicant is fit to conduct the business and that its establishment, operation and/or maintenance will not be harmful to the public health, safety and welfare, and that any other ordinance or laws affecting the same and the other requirements of this chapter have been complied with, it shall notify the applicant of its findings. If it finds that the public convenience, necessity, welfare and comfort does not require the establishment, operation and/or maintenance of such business in the location applied for, or that the applicant is not fit to conduct such business, or that the public health, safety or welfare will be or is likely to be harmed by the establishment, operation and/or maintenance of such business, or that any other ordinance or law prohibits such establishment, operation and/or maintenance, it shall forthwith refuse such application, and no certificate of approval or license shall issue to such applicant. 
(Ord. 293 § 4, 1971) 
5.28.070 - Certificate and license issuance. 
    Upon presentation of the certificate of approval required under this chapter within thirty days from its date and satisfactory evidence that all license fees have been paid to the city, and that such other fees and taxes as may be required by law have been fully paid, the city secretary shall issue to such applicant a license to operate a motor vehicle junkyard; provided, however, that any certificate issued under this chapter shall be effective until cancelled, and no additional certificate shall be required for the purpose of obtaining a license so long as the original certificate remains in effect and the applicant strictly complies with all the requirements and provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 293 § 5, 1971) 
5.28.080 - License fee. 
A.  In order to defray a part of the expense necessary to provide for the surveillance, supervision and inspection of motor vehicle junkyards required under the terms of this chapter, there is a fixed license fee, which shall be collected from any person operating a motor vehicle junkyard in the city, in the amount specified in Section 1.12.040. 
B.  No license for the operation of a motor vehicle junkyard shall be issued unless and until the city council has issued the certificate of approval under the terms of this chapter. 
C.  The license required by this chapter may be renewed from year to year, upon payment of the same fee as required for the original license, so long as the original certificate of approval remains in effect and the licensee strictly complies with all the requirements and provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1032 § 3 (part), 1998: Ord. 293 § 6, 1971) 
5.28.090 - Nontransferability. 
    The certificate of approval and the license, when issued, shall not be transferable without the written consent and approval of the city council, had after application and hearing as provided upon original application by the person to whom the certificate is issued. 
(Ord. 293 § 7, 1971) 
5.28.100 - Unlawful operation. 
    It is unlawful for any person to establish, operate or maintain a motor vehicle junkyard or business without procuring a certificate of approval and holding a license therefor, as hereinabove provided, and each day of such operation without such certificate or license shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 293 § 8, 1971) 
5.28.110 - Fencing requirement. 
    Each motor vehicle junkyard in the city shall be completely surrounded by a fence or structure at least six feet in height and of material which obscures the public view. 
(Ord. 293 § 9, 1971) 
5.28.120 - Height and access requirements. 
    No motor vehicles, or parts thereof, shall be piled or stacked in any such motor vehicle junkyard in any manner as to exceed six feet in height, or six hundred twenty-five square feet in floor or lot area. An aisle of at least four feet shall be maintained at all times between piles or stacks of motor vehicles or parts thereof, in such a manner as to allow free access on the part of the fire department of the city. 
(Ord. 293 § 10, 1971) 
5.28.130 - Gas tanks to be drained. 
    All gasoline shall be drained from the gasoline reservoirs of all motor vehicles stored or kept on the premises of any such motor vehicle junkyard, unless such motor vehicles are in such state of repair as to enable them to be removed from the premises under their own power. 
(Ord. 293 § 11, 1971) 
5.28.140 - Violation-Penalty.
