(Ord. 991 § 23 (part), 1996) 
6.04.010 - Pigs and hogs. 
    Except for miniature pigs meeting the definition of restricted animal under Section 6.12.010 below, pigs and hogs are prohibited within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. 991 § 23 (part), 1996: Ord. 783 § 1, 1986: Ord. 157 Art. 6 § 5(a), 1961) 
6.04.020 - Livestock permits. 
A.  All persons having horses, other livestock (cattle, sheep, goats, etc.) or ratites (emus, ostriches, etc.) must obtain a city permit by January 15th of each calendar year which permits the keeping and maintaining of domestic livestock. The permit shall grant the animal control officer permission to inspect at any reasonable time during the day the lot or parcel of land on which the horses and other livestock will be contained. Such permit may be revoked or withheld by the animal control officer if: 
1.  The facilities (both land and structures), upon inspection, show that they are inadequate for the number of animals sought to be kept. Such facilities must meet but not be limited to the following requirements: 
a.  The facility shall be of sufficient size as specified in the zoning ordinance to allow the animal to move about freely. 
b.  Adequate food and water must be provided so that each and every animal kept shall be maintained in good health and free of malnutrition and/or dehydration. 
c.  The premises shall be kept in a sanitary condition and reasonably free of animal waste parasites, insects and flies that could be harmful to the animals' health and/or to the health of the general public. 
d.  The premises must provide adequate protection (as determined by the animal control officer) from the common elements, i.e., rain, heat, cold; 
2.  The animals kept were causing a stench or odor which is offensive to a person of ordinary sensibilities on adjoining, adjacent or neighboring premises; or 
3.  The animals are maintained in a manner which is dangerous to the health of the animals themselves or adjacent animals; or 
4.  The animals are causing noise which is offensive or disturbing to a person of ordinary sensibilities on adjoining, adjacent or neighboring premises. 
B.  A property owner shall be permitted to maintain a horse or other livestock upon his or her property only if he or she is in the possession of a valid permit issued by the city. Revocation of a permit by the animal control officer will require removal of the animal or animals from the property owner's lot or tract within twenty-four hours. 
C.  In the event that the animal control officer shall identify a violation of any provision of the terms of this chapter, he or she may in his or her sole discretion cite the property owner for a misdemeanor violation of the terms of this chapter rather than revoking the permit itself. At the time that a citation is issued, the animal control officer shall notify the property owner of the provision of this chapter allegedly violated and shall provide the property owner with a list in writing of those deficiencies which must be corrected. The animal control officer may then at his or her sole discretion make follow-up reinspections to ensure that corrective action has been taken to resolve the violation. At such point in time as the animal control officer determines that the issuance of misdemeanor citations is not producing corrective action to eliminate the alleged violation of this chapter, the animal control officer may revoke the permit. 
D.  If a permit for the keeping and maintenance of horses and other livestock has been revoked by the animal control officer, the property owner affected may undertake one or more of the following actions: 
1.  Apply for a new permit by making application to the community services department; 
2.  Give written notice of appeal to the city secretary within twenty-four hours of permit revocation or notice hereof. If a written appeal of permit revocation is filed with the city secretary, a hearing shall be held before a committee composed of the city manager, the director of community services and the director of public safety. The hearing shall occur within seven working days of the receipt of the written appeal. The property owner appealing the decision of the animal control officer shall be entitled to appear and present such evidence and witnesses as the property owner deems appropriate to demonstrate that the permit was improperly revoked. The animal control officer will appear and present such evidence and/or witnesses as he or she deems appropriate to demonstrate why the revocation of the permit was necessary. At the conclusion of the appeal hearing, a decision will be rendered by the review committee and such decision shall be binding on all parties. 
E.  The animal control officer shall be authorized to reissue or authorize the reissuance of a permit for the keeping of domestic livestock on an individual property owner's property in those cases where a previous permit has been revoked, providing that such reissuance by the animal control officer is based on a finding that previously identified violations have been fully corrected. The authority of the animal control officer to allow reissuance of a previously revoked permit shall be subject to the restriction that if any property owner's permit to maintain domestic livestock has been revoked three times previously, it may not be reissued irrespective of subsequent corrective action take by the property owner. 
(Ord. 991 § 23 (part), 1996: Ord. 783 § 4, 1986: Ord. 157 Art. 6 § 5(b), 1961) 
6.04.030 - Stock barns. 
    All barns, sheds and enclosures in which livestock is kept or has been kept shall be maintained in a clean, sanitary manner and no accumulations of animal excreta or filth shall be permissible. 
(Ord. 991 § 23 (part), 1996: Ord. 157 Art. 6 § 5(c), 1961) 
6.04.040 - Poultry and rabbits. 
A.  It is unlawful to keep and maintain more than two poultry or rabbits at a distance closer than one hundred fifty feet from any building located on property under separate ownership that is used for human habitation. All poultry must be kept in a structure, pen or fence. Such structure, pen or fence must be kept in a sanitary manner. 
B.  All persons having more than two poultry or rabbits must obtain a city permit by January 15th of each calendar year which permits the keeping and maintaining of poultry and rabbits. The permit shall grant the animal control officer permission to inspect at any reasonable time during the day the lot or parcel of land on which the poultry or rabbits will be contained. Such permit may be revoked or withheld by the animal control officer if: 
1.  The facilities (both land and structures), upon inspection, show that they are inadequate for the number of animals sought to be kept. Such facilities must meet but not be limited to the following requirements: 
a.  The facility shall be of sufficient size as specified in the zoning ordinance to allow the animal to move about freely. 
b.  Adequate food and water must be provided so that each and every animal kept shall be maintained in good health and free of malnutrition and/or dehydration. 
c.  The premises shall be kept in a sanitary condition and reasonably free of animal waste parasites, insects and flies that could be harmful to the animals' health and/or to the health of the general public. 
d.  The premises must provide adequate protection (as determined by the animal control officer) from the common elements, i.e., rain, heat, cold; 
2.  The animals kept were causing a stench or odor which is offensive to a person of ordinary sensibilities on adjoining, adjacent or neighboring premises; or 
3.  The animals are maintained in a manner which is dangerous to the health of the animals themselves or adjacent animals; or 
4.  The animals are causing noise which is offensive or disturbing to a person of ordinary sensibilities on adjoining, adjacent or neighboring premises. 
(Ord. 991 § 23 (part), 1996: Ord. 783 § 4, 1986: Ord. 157 Art. 6 § 5(d), 1961) 
6.04.050 - Dead animal disposal. 
    The carcass of any animal dead of disease or other cause not slaughtered for food shall be removed and disposed of by the owner, if known and, if not known, by the owner of the premises where such animal is found, at his own expense within twenty-four hours after such death, according to such method as may be approved of by the health officer. 
(Ord. 991 § 23 (part), 1996: Ord. 157 Art. 6 § 5(e), 1961) 
6.04.060 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine of not less than ten dollars nor more than two thousand dollars. Each and every day that such violations continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 991 § 23 (part), 1996: Ord. 691 § 1 (part), 1984: Ord. 157 Art. 14 § 1, 1961) 
6.04.070 - Multiple pet limitations. 
    It is unlawful in all areas of the city to keep or harbor more than three dogs and two cats or three cats and two dogs contemporaneously. A restricted animal which is kept or harbored shall count as one animal (cat or dog) so that the combined total of dogs, cats and restricted animals shall not exceed five in total. Puppies and kittens under three months of age shall not be counted for purposes of this section. 
(Ord. 991 § 23 (part), 1996: Ord. 911 § 3, 1992: Ord. 783 § 4, 1986) 
Chapter 6.12 - REGULATION AND CONTROL OF ANIMALS 
Sections: 

6.12.010 - Definitions. 
    When used in this chapter, the following words and terms, unless the context indicates a different meaning, shall be interpreted as follows: 
    "Animal control officer" means a person designated by the city to enforce the animal regulations and to receive reports of animal bites, investigate bite reports, ensure quarantine of possible rabid animals and otherwise carry out provisions of the Texas law pertaining to control and eradication of rabies. 
    "Cat" means any live or dead member of the feline family (felis catus). 
    "Currently vaccinated" means vaccinated and satisfying the following criteria: 
1.  The animal must have been at least three months of age at the time of vaccination. 
2.  At least thirty days have elapsed since the initial vaccination. 
3.  Not more than twelve months have elapsed since the most recent vaccination. 
    "Dangerous dog" means a dog that: 
1.  Makes an unprovoked attack on a person that causes bodily injury and occurs in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own; or 
2.  Commits unprovoked acts in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own and those acts cause a person to reasonably believe that the dog will attack and cause bodily injury to that person. 
    "Dangerous wild animal" means: 
1.  A lion; 
2.  A tiger; 
3.  An ocelot; 
4.  A cougar; 
5.  A leopard; 
6.  A cheetah; 
7.  A jaguar; 
8.  A bobcat; 
9.  A lynx; 
10.  A serval; 
11.  A caracal; 
12.  A hyena; 
13.  A bear; 
14.  A coyote; 
15.  A jackal; 
16.  A baboon; 
17.  A chimpanzee; 
18.  An orangutan; 
19.  A gorilla; or 
20.  Any hybrid of an animal listed in this subdivision. 
    "Dog" means any live or dead member of the canine family (canis familiaris). 
    "Domestic animal" means all species of animals commonly and universally accepted as being domesticated. 
    "Harboring" means the act of keeping and caring for an animal or of providing a premises to which the animal returns for food, shelter or care for a period of ten days. 
    "Owner" means any person, firm or corporation who owns, has custody or control, has right of property in an animal or who harbors an animal or allows an animal to remain about his premises for a period of ten days. 
    "Pet animal" means dogs, cats, rabbits, rodents, birds, reptiles, and any other species of animal which is sold or retained as a household pet, but shall not include skunks, primates and any other species of wild, exotic or carnivorous animal that may be further restricted in this law. 
    "Restricted animal" means registered miniature livestock such as horses, mules, jacks, jennets, cattle, pigs, sheep, goats or similar animals meeting the published breed definition for registration by the recognized association for breeding such miniature animals. 
    "Running at large" means not completely confined by a building, wall or fence of sufficient strength or construction to restrain the animal, except when such animal is either on a leash or held in the hands of the owner or keeper, or under direct supervision of the owner within the limits of the owner's private property. An animal within an automobile or other vehicle of its owner, shall not be deemed running at large. 
    "Secure enclosure" means a fenced area or structure that is: 
1.  Locked; 
2.  Capable of preventing the entry of the general public, including children; 
3.  Capable of preventing the escape or release of a dog; 
4.  Clearly marked as containing a dangerous dog; and 
5.  In conformance with the requirements for enclosures established by the animal control officer. 
    "Stray animal" means any animal for which there is not an identifiable owner or harborer. 
    "Vaccinated" means properly injected with a rabies vaccine licensed for use in that species by the United States Department of Agriculture and administered by a veterinarian licensed to practice in the state of Texas. 
    "Vicious animal" means any individual animal of any species that has without provocation attacked or bitten any person or other animal, or any individual animal which the local health authority has reason to believe has a dangerous disposition, or any species of animal which the local health authority has reason to believe has a dangerous disposition likely to be harmful to humans or other animals. 
    "Wild animal" means all species of animals which commonly exist in a natural unconfined state and are usually not domesticated. This shall apply regardless of state or duration of captivity. 
(Ord. 1109 § 1 (part), 2001; Ord. 991 § 24 (part), 1996: Ord. 911 § 1, 1992; Ord. 754 § 1, 1985) 
6.12.020 - Rabies control. 
A.  Vaccinations. Every owner of a dog or cat three months of age or older shall have such animal vaccinated against rabies. All dogs or cats vaccinated at three months of age or older shall be revaccinated at one year of age. The same animal must be revaccinated against rabies at a minimum of at least once every three years. Animals receiving one- or two-year rabies vaccines must be revaccinated as recommended by the manufacturer at the same one- or two-year intervals. Any person moving into the city from a location outside the city shall comply with this chapter within ten days after having moved into the city. If the dog or cat has inflicted a bite on any person, or another animal, within the last ten days, the owner of said dog or cat shall report such fact to the veterinarian, and no rabies vaccine shall be administered until after the ten-day observation period. 
B.  Certificate of Vaccination. Upon vaccination, the veterinarian shall execute and furnish to the owner of the dog or cat as evidence thereof, a certificate upon a form furnished by the veterinarian. The veterinarian shall retain a duplicate copy of such certificate. Such certificate shall contain the following information: 
1.  The name, address and telephone number of the owner of the vaccinated dog or cat; 
2.  The date of vaccination; 
3.  The type of rabies vaccine used; 
4.  The year and number of the rabies tag; and 
5.  The breed, age, color and sex of the vaccinated dog or cat. 
C.  Rabies Tags. Concurrently with the issuance and delivery of the certificate of vaccination referred to in subsection B of this section, the owner of the dog or cat shall cause to be attached to the collar or harness of the vaccinated dog or cat a metal tag, serially numbered to correspond with the vaccination certificate number, and bearing the year of issuance and the name of the issuing veterinarian and his address. The owner shall cause the collar or harness, with the attached metal tag, to be worn by his dog or cat at all times. 
D.  Duplicate Tags. In the event of loss or destruction of the original tag provided in subsection C of this section, the owner of the dog shall obtain a duplicate tag. Vaccination certificates (and tags) shall be valid only for the animal for which it was originally issued. 
E.  Proof. It is unlawful for any person who owns or harbors a vaccinated dog or cat to fail or refuse to exhibit his copy of the certificate of vaccination upon demand to any person charged with the enforcement of this chapter. 
F.  Harboring Unvaccinated Animals. It is unlawful for any person to harbor any dog or cat which has not been vaccinated against rabies, as provided herein, or which cannot be identified as having a current vaccination certificate. 
G.  Animals Exposed to Rabies. Any person having knowledge of the existence of any animal known to have been, or suspected of being, exposed to rabies must immediately report such knowledge to the city, giving any information which may be required. For any animal known to have been, or suspected ofbeing, exposed to rabies, the following rules must apply: 
1.  Animals having a current vaccination must be revaccinated immediately and confined according to the method prescribed by the city for not less than ninety days. 
2.  Animals not having a current vaccination should be humanely destroyed. However, if the owner of such an animal elects, he may, at his expense and in a manner prescribed by the city, confine said animal. Such animal must be vaccinated immediately following exposure and quarantined for not less than six months. A revaccination shall be done one month prior to release from quarantine. 
(Ord. 1183 § 1, 2005; Ord. 754 § 2, 1985) 
6.12.030 - Reporting human bites from animals susceptible to rabies-Related procedures. 
A.  Any person having knowledge of an animal bite to a human will report the incident to the city as soon as possible, but not later than twenty-four hours from the time of the incident. 
B.  The owner of the biting animal will place that animal in quarantine as prescribed in Section 6.12.040 under the supervision of the city. 
C.  The local health authority will investigate each bite incident, utilizing standardized reporting forms provided by the Texas Department of Health. 
D.  Human bites from rodents, rabbits, birds and reptiles are excluded from the reporting requirements of this section. 
(Ord. 754 § 3, 1985) 
6.12.040 - Quarantine procedures for animals. 
A.  When a dog or cat which has bitten a human has been identified, the owner will be required to produce the animal for ten days' confinement at the owner's expense. Refusal to produce such dog or cat constitutes a violation of this section and each day of such refusal constitutes a separate and individual violation. The ten-day observation period will begin on the day of the bite incident. The animal must be placed in the animal control facilities specified for this purpose, if available. However, the owner of the animal may request permission from the city for home quarantine if the following criteria can be met: 
1.  Secure facilities must be available at the home of the animal's owner and must be approved by the city. 
2.  The animal is currently vaccinated against rabies. 
3.  The animal control officer of the city or a licensed veterinarian must observe the animal at least on the first and last days of the quarantine period. If the animal becomes ill during the observation period, the city must be notified by the person having possession of the animal. At the end of the observation period, the release from quarantine must be accomplished in writing. 
4.  The animal was not in violation of any laws at the time of the bite. 
5.  If the biting animal cannot be maintained in secure quarantine it shall be humanely destroyed and the brain submitted to a Texas Department of Health certified laboratory for rabies diagnosis. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to interrupt the ten-day observation period. 
C.  No wild animal will be placed in quarantine. All wild animals involved in biting incidents will be humanely killed in such a manner that the brain is not mutilated. The brain shall be submitted to a Texas Department of Health certified laboratory for rabies diagnosis. 
(Ord. 754 § 4, 1985) 
6.12.050 - Animal registration. 
    No owner shall have within the city any dog or cat three months of age or older unless such dog or cat is currently registered with the animal control officer. A current metal registration certificate issued by animal control or a veterinarian authorized by the animal control officer to issue the certificate must be affixed to a collar or harness that must be worn by the dog or cat at all times. No dog or cat shall be registered until it has a current vaccination. 
A.  Application for initial issuance or renewal of each registration must be made by the owner in writing or in person, and be accompanied by a fee as specified in Section 1.12.050. If the original current registration is lost or destroyed, the owner may obtain a duplicate registration from the animal control officer by paying a fee as specified in Section 1.12.050. 
B.  Registration certificates shall be renewed annually. The registration period will be from January 1st to December 31st. Certificates for the new period shall be available for sale at City Hall during regular business hours. 
C.  Registration and/or vaccination certificates (and tags) shall be valid only for the animal for which they were originally issued. 
D.  If there is a change in ownership of a registered dog or cat, the new owner shall have the registration transferred to his name. There shall be no charge for such transfer. Application for such transfer shall be made to the animal control officer in writing or in person. 
E.  Fee-exempt registrations may be issued for the following: 
1.  Police department dogs; and 
2.  Dogs trained to assist the audibly or visually impaired person. 
    Eligibility for fee-exempt registration does not relieve the owner of his responsibility under other provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1032 § 3 (part), 1998; Ord. 991 § 24 (part), 1996: Ord. 754 § 5, 1985) 
6.12.060 - Running at large. 
A.  It is unlawful for any dog or other animal possessed, kept or harbored, other than a cat, to run at large, as defined in subsection I of Section 6.12.010. 
B.  The animal control officer is authorized to impound such animals running at large, other than a cat, and may impound a cat under conditions specified in Section 6.12.100, or when he has received a complaint that the cat has caused a nuisance or hazard to the health or welfare of the human or animal population. 
(Ord. 754 § 6, 1985) 
6.12.070 - Animal nuisances. 
    The following acts are declared to be nuisances and constitute violations of this chapter: 
A.  The keeping of any animal which, by causing frequent or long continued barking, cry or noise shall disturb any person of ordinary sensibilities in the vicinity; 
B.  The keeping of any animal in such a manner as to endanger the public health, to annoy neighbors by the accumulation of animal wastes which cause foul and offensive odors, or are considered to be a hazard to any other animal or human being, or by continued presence on the premises of another; 
C.  The keeping of bees in such a manner as to deny the lawful use of adjacent property or endanger personal health and welfare. 
(Ord. 754 § 7, 1985) 
6.12.075 - Restricted animals. 
A.  1.  Restricted animals are prohibited unless the owner obtains a permit as required in this section. Any person who wishes to possess a restricted animal in the city limits must apply for an annually renewable permit at city hall and provide the following information and documentation: 
a.  Copies of applicable state or federal permits or licenses as required by either of those entities for the keeping of the particular animal in question if any are required; 
b.  A health certificate from a local veterinarian stating that the animal is free of disease and is current on all vaccinations as required by the animal control officer; 
c.  Owner information including emergency telephone numbers and telephone numbers of their veterinarian in case of emergencies; 
d.  Proof of registration of restricted animal; 
2.  Application for permit shall cost ten dollars to be paid by check, cash or money order. 
B.  Limitations. 
1.  Ownership shall be limited to one restricted animal, or one restricted animal per acre available, whichever is greater. 
2.  A potbellied pig must be neutered whether male or female. Other restricted animals may be required to be neutered at the animal control officer's discretion. 
3.  Owners must provide enclosure with adequate exercise areas in good repair to prevent escape and injury. 
4.  Miniature horses, mules, jacks, jennets, cattle, sheep and goats shall be limited to thirty-six inches in height at the top of the shoulders. Miniature or potbellied pigs shall be limited to eighty-five pounds in weight and eighteen inches in height. The permit shall be revoked if the restrictive animal fails to meet this requirement. 
5.  Restricted animals shall be subject to Section 6.12.060, Running at Large and Section 6.12.070, Animal Nuisances. Violations may result in cancellation of a restricted animal permit and required removal of the restricted animal from the city. 
(Ord. 991 § 24 (part), 1996; Ord. 911 § 2, 1992) 
6.12.080 - Prohibited animals. 
A.  It is unlawful to color, dye, stain or otherwise change the natural color of any chickens, ducklings, other fowl, or rabbits, or to possess for the purpose of sale or to be given away any of the above mentioned animals which have been so colored. 
B.  It is unlawful to keep any wild animals and/or dangerous animals inside the city. 
C.  It is unlawful to release or to allow to run at large any wild or vicious animal. 
(Ord. 1109 § 1 (part), 2001; Ord. 754 § 8, 1985) 
6.12.085 - Dangerous dogs. 
A.  Requirements for Owner of Dangerous Dog. 
1.  Not later than the thirtieth day after a person learns that the person is the owner of a dangerous dog, the person shall: 
a.  Register the dangerous dog with the animal control authority for the area in which the dog is kept; 
b.  Restrain the dangerous dog at all times on a leash in the immediate control of a person or in a secure enclosure; and 
c.  Obtain liability insurance coverage or show financial responsibility in an amount of at least one hundred thousand dollars, to cover damages resulting from an attack by the dangerous dog causing bodily injury to a person. 
2.  For purposes of this section, a person learns that the person is the owner of a dangerous dog when: 
a.  The owner knows of an attack described in the definition of dangerous dog above; or 
b.  The owner is informed by the animal control officer that the dog is a dangerous dog. 
3.  If a person reports an incident described in the definition of dangerous dog above, the animal control officer may investigate the incident. If, after receiving the sworn statements of any witnesses, the animal control authority determines the dog is a dangerous dog, it shall notify the owner of that fact. 
4.  An owner, not later than the thirtieth day after the date an owner is notified that a dog owned by the owner is a dangerous dog, may appeal the determination of the animal control officer to a justice or municipal court of competent jurisdiction. An owner may appeal the decision of the justice or municipal court in the same manner as appeal for other civil cases. 
B.  Registration. 
1.  The animal control officer shall annually register a dangerous dog if the owner: 
a.  Presents proof of: 
i.  Liability insurance or financial responsibility, as required by Section 6.12.085A1c above, 
ii.  Current rabies vaccination of the dangerous dog, and 
iii.  The secure enclosure in which the dangerous dog will be kept; and 
b.  Pays an annual registration fee in accordance with Section 1.12.050. 
2.  The animal control officer shall provide to the owner registering a dangerous dog a registration tag. The owner must place the tag on the dog's collar. 
3.  If an owner of a registered dangerous dog sells or moves the dog to a new address in Benbrook, the owner, not later than the fourteenth day after the date of the sale or move, shall notify the animal control officer. On presentation by the current owner of the dangerous dog's prior registration tag and payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars, the animal control officer shall issue a new registration tag to be placed on the dangerous dog's collar. 
4.  An owner of a registered dangerous dog shall notify the animal control officer of any attacks the dangerous dog makes on people. 
C.  Attack by Dangerous Dog. 
1.  A person commits an offense if the person is the owner of a dangerous dog and the dog makes an unprovoked attack on another person outside the dog's enclosure and causes bodily injury to the other person. 
2.  An offense under this section is a Class C misdemeanor, unless the attack causes serious bodily injury or death, in which event the offense is a Class A misdemeanor. 
3.  If a person is found guilty of an offense under this section, the court may order the dangerous dog destroyed. 
4.  In addition to criminal prosecution, a person who commits an offense under this section is liable for a civil penalty not to exceed ten thousand dollars. The city attorney may file suit in a court of competent jurisdiction to collect the penalty. Penalties collected under this subsection shall be retained by the municipality. 
D.  Violations. 
1.  A person who owns or keeps custody or control of a dangerous dog commits an offense if the person fails to comply with Section 6.12.085A. 
2.  An offense under this section is a Class C misdemeanor. 
E.  Defense. 
1.  It is a defense to prosecution under Section 6.12.085C or Section 6.12.085D that the person is a veterinarian, a peace officer, a person employed by a recognized animal shelter, or a person employed by the state or a political subdivision of the state to deal with stray animals and has temporary ownership, custody or control of the dog in connection with that position. 
2.  It is a defense to prosecution under Section 6.12.085C or Section 6.12.085D that the person is an employee of the institutional division of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice or a law enforcement agency and trains or uses dogs for law enforcement or corrections purposes. 
3.  It is a defense to prosecution under Section 6.12.085C or Section 6.12.085D that the person is a dog trainer or an employee of a guard dog company under the Private Investigators and Private Security Agencies Act (Article 4413(29bb), Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes). 
(Ord. 1032 § 4 (part), 1998; Ord. 991 § 24 (part), 1996) 
6.12.090 - Vicious animals. 
A.  Any vicious animal found running at large may be destroyed by any peace officer or animal control officer in the interest of public safety. 
B.  The animal control officer may order any owner or person having care, custody or control of any vicious animal to take such animal permanently from the city. This animal must be removed immediately following receipt of such an order, even if an appeal is initiated. This order may be appealed in writing within ten days to a committee made up of the chief of police or his representative, the city manager or his representative, and the director of community services or his representative. Such committee may uphold, reverse or modify the animal control officer's order, and may stipulate restrictions on the animal as a condition to allowing the animal to remain in the city. If the committee upholds the animal control officer's order, the owner or person having care, custody or control shall not bring the animal back inside the city limits. 
C.  If the owner or person having care, custody or control of a vicious animal fails to remove such animal as provided for in subsections A and B of this section, such animal may be impounded and/or destroyed. 
D.  The owner or person having care, custody or control of a vicious animal must report the disposition and relocation of such animal to the animal control officer in writing, within ten days after the expiration date for removal of such animal from the city. Each day thereafter such information is not provided shall constitute a separate offense. 
E.  The animal control officer shall be authorized to obtain a search and seizure warrant if there is a reason to believe that an animal ordered removed from the city for being vicious has not been so removed. 
(Ord. 754 § 9, 1985) 
6.12.100 - Impoundment. 
A.  The following animals may be impounded: 
1.  Cats and dogs not exhibiting evidence of being vaccinated as described in Section 6.12.020 or registered as described in Section 6.12.050; 
2.  Any animal infected or kept under conditions which could endanger the public or animal health; 
3.  Any animal that creates a nuisance, as defined in Section 6.12.070; 
4.  Any animal running at large, as stipulated in Section 6.12.060; 
5.  Any animal treated in a manner determined by the animal control officer to be cruel or inhumane; 
6.  Any animal that has bitten a human being or needs to be placed under observation for rabies determination, as determined by the local health authority; 
7.  Any animal violating any provision of this chapter. 
B.  If any of the animals named in this chapter are found upon the premises of any person, the owner or occupant of the premises shall have the right to confine such animal in a humane manner until he can notify the animal control officer to come and impound such animal. When so notified, it shall be the duty of the animal control officer to have such animal impounded as provided in this chapter. 
C.  Reasonable effort shall be made by the animal control officer to contact the owner of any animal impounded which is wearing a current vaccination tag; however, final responsibility for location of an impounded animal is that of the owner. 
D.  The owner can resume possession of any impounded animal upon payment of impoundment fees, and any veterinary bills incurred by the animal control officer for the welfare of the animal, and upon compliance with the vaccination and registration provisions of this chapter, except where prohibited in subsections E and F of this section. 
E.  Disposition of animals impounded on the grounds of cruel or inhumane treatment shall be determined by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
F.  If any animal is being held under quarantine or observation for rabies, the owner shall not be entitled to possession until it has been released from quarantine. 
G.  The city manager shall select and establish a place for impounding all animals impounded under any provision of this chapter. 
H.  Any animal, except vicious or wild animals, not reclaimed by the owner shall become the property of the city and may be humanely euthanized after being impounded for five days. 
I.  Any impounded vicious or wild animal, unless there is reason to believe that it has an owner, shall become the property of the city and may be immediately disposed of as may be deemed appropriate by the animal control officer upon approval by the city manager. 
J.  Any nursing baby animal impounded without the mother, or where the mother cannot or refuses to provide nutritious milk, shall become the property of the city and may be immediately euthanized to prevent further suffering. 
K.  Any impounded animal that appears to be suffering from extreme injury or illness shall become the property of the city and may be euthanized or given to a nonprofit humane organization for the purpose of veterinary medical care, as determined by the animal control officer. 
(Ord. 754 § 10, 1985) 
(Ord. No. 1403 , § 1, 12-1-2016) 
6.12.110 - Impoundment fees. 
    Impoundment fees, daily handling fees and daily quarantine fees shall be charged as specified in Section 1.12.050. 
(Ord. 1169 § 1, 2004; Ord. 754 § 11, 1985) 
6.12.120 - Enforcement. 
A.  Enforcement of this chapter shall be the responsibility of the city of Benbrook. 
B.  The city animal control officer shall have the authority to issue citations for any violation of this chapter. 
C.  If the person being cited is not present, the city animal control officer may send the citation to the alleged offender by registered or certified mail. 
D.  It is unlawful for any person to interfere with the city animal control officer in the performance of his or her duties. 
(Ord. 754 § 12, 1985) 
6.12.130 - Penalty. 
    It is unlawful for any person, organization, association or corporation to violate any of the provisions of this chapter. Any person, organization, association or corporation violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars. 
(Ord. 754 § 13, 1985) 
Title 8 - HEALTH AND SAFETY 
Chapters: 
Chapter 8.04 - GARBAGE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
Sections: 

8.04.010 - Definitions. 
    The following words, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings as defined in this section: 
    "Brush" means tree and shrub trimmings in bulk which exceed three feet in length and cannot be loaded readily into regular refuse compaction equipment. 
    "Bulky waste" means stoves, refrigerators, water tanks, washing machines, furniture and other waste materials other than construction debris, hazardous waste or stable matter. 
    "Bundle" or "boxed bundle" means tree, shrub and brush trimmings or newspapers and magazines securely tied together forming an easily handled package not exceeding three feet in length or fifty pounds in weight. 
    "City" means the city of Benbrook, Texas. 
    "Commercial container" means metal containers supplied by the contractor affording adequate capacity to service of customer so as to prevent spillage, unsightly and unsanitary conditions. 
    "Construction debris" means waste building materials resulting from construction, reroofing, remodeling, repair or demolition operations; also earthen materials. 
    "Containers" means plastic bags designed to store refuse with sufficient wall strength to maintain physical integrity when lifted by the top. Total weight of a bag and its contents shall not exceed fifty pounds. 
    "Contractor" means the person, partnership, corporation or other business entity performing refuse collection under contract with the city. 
    "Disposal site" means a refuse depository, physically located in the city or close proximity thereto, including, but not limited to, the landfill and other sanitary landfills, transfer stations, incinerators and waste processing/separation centers licensed, permitted or approved to receive for processing or final disposal of refuse by all governmental bodies and agencies having jurisdiction and requiring such licenses, permits or approvals. 
    "Hazardous waste" means any chemical, compound, mixture, substance or article which is designated by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or approprivate agency of the state to be "hazardous," as that term is defined by or pursuant to federal or state law. 
    "Producer" means an occupant of a residential unit who generates refuse. 
    "Recycling container" means plastic or similar containers supplied by the contractor and designed to store recycled materials for collection. 
    "Refuse" means every accumulation of waste (vegetable and/or other matter) that results from the preparation, processing, consumption, dealing in, handling, packing, canning, storage, transportation, decay or decomposition of meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits, grains, or other animal or vegetable matter (including, but not by way of limitation, used in tin cans and other food containers; and all easily decomposable animal waste or vegetable matter which is likely to attract flies or rodents); except (in all cases) any matter included in the definition of "bulky waste," "construction debris," "hazardous waste" or "stable matter" generated by a producer at a residential unit. 
    "Residential unit" means a dwelling within the corporate limits of the city occupied by a person or group of persons comprising not more than four families. A "residential unit" shall be defined when either water or domestic light and power services are being supplied thereto. A condominium dwelling, whether of a single or multi-level construction, consisting of four or less continuous or separate single-family dwelling units, shall be treated as a residential unit, except that each single-family dwelling within such residential unit shall be billed separately as a residential unit. 
    "Rubbish" means all waste wood, wood, wood products, tree trimmings, grass cuttings, dead plants, weeds, leaves, dead trees or branches thereof, chips, shavings, sawdust, printed matter, paper, pasteboard, rags, straw, used and discarded mattresses, pulp and other products such as are used for packaging or wrapping crockery and glass, ashes, cinders, floor sweepings, glass, mineral or metallic substances, and any and all other waste materials not included in the definition of "bulky waste," "construction debris," "hazardous waste" or "stable matter." 
(Ord. 1064-00 § 1, 2000; Ord. 642 § 1, 1983) 
8.04.020 - Depositing refuse on streets or vacant lots prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or association of persons to sweep, throw or deposit, or cause to be swept, thrown or deposited, any refuse upon or along any drain, gutter, alley, sidewalk, street, drainage easement, public right-of-way, or vacant lot, or upon any publicly or privately owned premises within the corporate boundaries of the city. Every dwelling, unit, business place, manufacturing concern, wholesale distributor, retailer or apartment unit must have refuse service by the city. The director and code enforcement officer are authorized to sign complaints against persons not in compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. 642 § 2, 1983) 
8.04.030 - Collection requirements and prohibitions. 
    The following special requirements and prohibitions shall govern the collection of the types of refuse indicated: 
A.  Placing Refuse Containers for Collection. All single-family and two-family residences, duplexes, triplexes and fourplexes shall place garbage in plastic bags at the curbline no earlier than the evening before the proper day for collection. No such plastic bags shall be placed on the curb itself, but rather immediately behind the curb on the property owner's side thereon. On other days containers will not be stored in front of the front building line of the particular property involved. Maximum contents of any container shall not exceed fifty pounds in weight. 
B.  Garbage, commercial and industrial, is to be placed in regulation containers as specified in this chapter, and collected from the agreed collection point between the customer and director. 
C.  Brush, tree trimmings and cuttings shall be reduced to shapes that can be readily handled by collectors and shall be placed at the point specified by the director (generally at the curbline). Brush, tree trimmings and cuttings shall be no longer than three feet and shall be collected on the regularly scheduled collection day unless the amount is excessive. 
D.  All broken glass must be wrapped securely before it is placed in containers to reduce the danger of injury to humans. 
E.  All ashes must be allowed to stand until cold before being placed in pasteboard boxes and sealed. Ashes which have been allowed to cool completely shall be placed in pasteboard boxes and will be collected from the point specified in this chapter. 
F.  Earth, rocks, concrete, shingles and similar materials will not be collected by sanitation crews. Solid waste materials resulting from construction or remodeling by a building contractor and materials from an unimproved lot will not be collected. 
G.  Wet Refuse. All refuse that is mixed with water or other liquids shall be drained and placed in proper plastic bags before being placed for collection. 
H.  Animal Excrement. All animal excrement shall be wrapped and securely tied before being deposited for collection. 
I.  Papers. Where large accumulations of paper such as newspapers are put out for collection, such papers shall be securely bound or placed in containers to prevent scattering of paper on privately and publicly owned premises. 
J.  There shall be no carry-out service furnished within the corporate limits of the city; all garbage shall be placed in plastic bags behind the curbline as specified in this section. 
(Ord. 642 § 3, 1983) 
8.04.040 - Residential refuse removal. 
    Garbage and trash removal, brush and bulky waste removal, and recyclable materials collection will be provided to residential premises in accordance with the latest refuse contract adopted by city council. Monthly fees for this service shall also be established by the latest refuse contract. 
(Ord. 1032 § 5 (part), 1998: Ord. 776 § 1, 1986; Ord. 642 § 4, 1983) 
8.04.045 - Sales tax requirements. 
    There shall be charged, assessed and collected from each person within the city a sales tax as may be imposed in the State Tax Code in connection with the collection and disposal of garbage, refuse, trash and rubbish. 
(Ord. 805 § 1, 1987) 
8.04.050 - Mandatory service. 
    To promote the safest and most sanitary conditions for the residents of the city, each residence is required to utilize the garbage and brush service. Refusal to utilize the service may result in the issuance of a citation for each day in which the service is not utilized. All statements for services rendered shall be directed to the address where service is provided and both the owner and occupants at the address shall be jointly and severally liable for payment for the same. 
(Ord. 642 § 5, 1983) 
8.04.060 - Collection of charges-Payment for services rendered. 
A.  A quarterly or monthly bill will be mailed to each owner, occupant, tenant, or lessee; any person who shall fail to pay the charges for services within thirty days from the date the bill shall become due and payable shall be subject to having such services suspended and/or be subject to the issuance of a citation. Upon termination of service, the owner, occupant, tenant or lessee is subject to citation as set forth in Section 8.04.050. When refuse collection service is suspended for any reason, the director of community services of the city, or his designate, shall make or cause to be made an investigation of the circumstances and, if required, may issue citations for each day in which the service is not utilized. 
B.  Accumulation and storage of garbage, filth, waste, refuse, clippings of brush, shrubs or trees, or any other waste material beyond the scheduled garbage and waste pickup times set forth in this chapter is held to be a nuisance which threatens the public health, welfare and well-being of the citizens and a dangerous harboring place for germs, disease-carrying insects and rodents, viruses and other agencies normally associated with the communication of diseases. Any person, firm or corporation who is keeping, maintaining, storing or retaining waste materials, garbage, solid waste or other refuse, as those terms are defined in this chapter, beyond the normal scheduled waste and garbage pickup times shall be deemed to be contributing to an unsanitary, unhealthy and dangerous condition within the city and shall be in violation of the terms and provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1080 § 1, 2000; Ord. 642 § 6, 1983) 
8.04.070 - Permit for collection and disposal required. 
    No person, except a duly authorized agent or employee of the city, shall take the contents of or otherwise remove refuse containers or recycling containers or transport garbage, trash or recycling container contents on the streets, alleys and public thoroughfares of the city without a written permit granted and issued by the public services director. 
(Ord. 1064-00 § 2, 2000: Ord. 642 § 7, 1983) 
8.04.080 - Permit application. 
    The application for a permit required under this chapter shall set forth the name and address of the applicant, the trade name under which the applicant does or proposes to do business, the number of vehicles the applicant desires to operate, the class, size and design of each motor vehicle and container-system equipment, and whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a violation of any nature. 
(Ord. 642 § 8, 1983) 
8.04.090 - Duties and obligations of commercial customers. 
    Every owner, agent, employee or person otherwise in charge of any commercial, institutional, industrial or multifamily premises within the city required to use, or electing to use commercial containers (the "commercial customer") shall have the following duties and obligations: 
A.  Every owner, occupant, tenant, or lessee using or occupying any building or structure within the corporate boundaries of the city for church, school, college, lodge, commercial, business, or any purpose shall provide and maintain standard commercial refuse containers of sufficient number and size, to hold such garbage or trash as will normally accumulate on his premises. The director of community services may determine the need for curbside or mechanical container service for small businesses. 
B.  It shall be the duty of every owner of every multiple housing unit containing more than four units or apartments and shopping centers containing separate commercial units to secure franchised hauler containerized service for the occupants. 
C.  Each commercial customer shall provide for and use a commercial container or containers furnished by the contractor sufficient in size or number to hold the refuse accumulating on the premises. Commercial containers may be used and placed at a location on the premises as arranged between the commercial customer and contractor subject to review of the same by the city at any time. 
D.  Each commercial customer shall keep all commercial containers in use securely closed in such a manner as to prevent the scattering of the contents thereof and to render the contents inaccessible to insects, rodents and other animals. 
E.  Each commercial customer shall drain all refuse mixed with water or other liquids before placing the same into a commercial container, and further, no commercial customer shall place for collection, or permit to be placed for collection, any hazardous wastes. 
F.  Commercial customers shall not place bulky items in front-load containers if such will prevent the lid from being securely closed. 
G.  Commercial customers shall not place bulky items in roll-off containers if such placement will result in any portion of such bulky item exceeding, or penetrating, an imaginary horizontal plane six inches below the water level (brim) of such roll-off containers. 
H.  Commercial customers shall not place bulky items or construction debris in compactor containers. 
I.  Commercial customers shall not place construction debris in front-load containers. 
J.  It is unlawful for individuals to dispose of refuse, brush or bulky wastes in commercial containers not under lease by or provided for the individual making the deposit. 
(Ord. 642 § 9, 1983) 
8.04.100 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
B.  The city may also bring suit for injunction against any person, firm or corporation that violates or threatens to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, in order to prevent a continued violation or such threatened violation. 
(Ord. 642 § 11, 1983) 
Chapter 8.08 - UNSANITARY PROPERTY CONDITIONS* 
Sections: 

8.08.010 - Weeds, rubbish, stagnant water, etc. 
A.  Violations. It is an offense for a person, firm, or corporation owning, occupying, or having control of land within the city, whether occupied or unoccupied, to permit: 
1.  Grass, weeds, or any plant that is not cultivated to grow to a height greater than ten inches on the land or between the property line of the land and curb of an adjacent street or if there is no curb, then between the property line of the land and ten feet outside the property line adjacent to public right-of-way; 
2.  Rubbish, brush, or other unsanitary or unsightly matter, including, but not limited to junk, trash, garbage, refuse, junk appliances, or junk machinery to accumulate or be present upon the property; 
3.  A hole or depression to remain on the land where water accumulates and becomes stagnant; or the accumulation of stagnant water to remain on the land. 
4.  Open Storage. It is an offense for the owner, occupant, or person in charge of property to store openly an item that is not customarily used or stored outside, or that is made of material that is not weather resistant, in an unenclosed outdoor area for more than twenty-four continuous hours. Open storage is prohibited in the front yard, on a front porch, under a carport, or any other unenclosed area. Items stored in this manner are considered a public nuisance if they are visible from a public place or public right-of-way. 
5.  Equipment Storage. It is an offense for the owner, occupant, or person in charge of residential property to: park, stand, or store any farm equipment or light or heavy construction equipment in any residentially zoned area within the city for more than seven consecutive days in a 180-day period, unless the equipment is being used in conjunction with an active construction project and on the property where a building permit has been issued and construction is in progress. 
B.  More Than Two Acres. If a parcel of land consists of two or more acres under single ownership, the provisions of subsection A do not apply to: 
1.  The area that is located in excess of one hundred feet from a public right-of-way; or 
2.  The area that is located in excess of one hundred feet from adjacent property under different ownership on which a building is located. 
C.  Penalty. A person who violates subsection A or who fails to perform an act required by this chapter commits an offense. A person commits a separate offense each day or portion of a day during which a violation is committed, permitted, or continued. Each separate offense under this chapter is punishable by a fine of not more than two thousand dollars and not less than: 
1.  Fifty dollars for the first offense; 
2.  One hundred dollars for the second offense within any twelve-month period; and 
3.  Two hundred fifty dollars for the third offense within any twelve-month period. 
(Ord. 1215 § 1, 2006; Ord. 1023 § 1 (part), 1998) 
( Ord. No. 1394, §1, 1-21-2016 ) 
8.08.020 - Responsibility for cutting, clearing. 
    It is the responsibility of a person, firm or corporation owning, occupying, or having control of land within the city, to cut or cause to be cut, grass, weeds or plants, and to remove or cause to be removed, rubbish, brush, stagnant water, holes and depressions that collect stagnant water, and other unsanitary or unsightly matter as often as necessary to prevent violations of Section 8.08.010. 
(Ord. 1023 § 1 (part), 1998) 
8.08.030 - Abatement of prohibited conditions. 
A.  If an owner of land fails to prevent a violation of Section 8.08.010 or fails to provide for the removal of unsanitary conditions as required by Section 8.08.020, a city official may give notice to the property owner to cut the grass, weeds or other uncultivated plants or to remove the rubbish, brush, stagnant water, holes and depressions that collect stagnant water, or other unsanitary or unsightly matter within ten days of the date of the notice. 
B.  The notice must be given: 
1.  Personally to the owner in writing; or 
2.  By letter addressed to the owner at the owner's post office address; or 
3.  If personal service cannot be obtained or the owner's post office address is unknown: 
a.  By publication in the city's official newspaper at least twice within ten days, 
b.  By posting the notice on or near the front door of each building on the property to which the violation relates, or 
c.  If the property contains no buildings, by posting the notice on a placard attached to a stake driven into the ground on the property to which the violation relates. 
C.  If the owner does not cut the weeds, grass or plants or remove the rubbish, brush, stagnant water, holes and depression that collect stagnant water, or other unsanitary or unsightly matter within ten days of the notice, the city may do the work and charge the expenses to the owner of the property and assess the expenses against the real estate on which the work is done. 
(Ord. 1023 § 1 (part), 1998) 
8.08.040 - Notice for abating continuing violations. 
    Although it is not required, if the notice required by Section 8.08.030 is given by certified mail, return receipt requested: 
A.  The city may include in the notice a statement that if the owner commits another violation of the same kind on or before one year from the date of the notice, the city without further notice, may correct the violation at the owner's expense and assess the expense against the property; and 
B.  If a violation does reoccur within the one-year period, and the city has not been informed in writing of a change in ownership, the city may without additional notice take corrective action and assess the expenses against the owner and the property. 
(Ord. 1023 § 1 (part), 1998) 
8.08.050 - Assessment of expenses-Notice-Lien. 
A.  In order to assess the expenses incurred pursuant to Section 8.08.030C against the real estate on which the work is done, the city shall send the owner of the property upon which the work was done a notice which shall include: 
1.  Identification of the property; 
2.  Description of the violation; 
3.  A statement that the city abated the condition; 
4.  A statement of the city's charges and expenses in abating the condition; 
5.  An explanation of the property owner's right to request a hearing within ten days of the date of the letter; and 
6.  A statement that if the owner fails or refuses to pay the expense within thirty days after the first day of the month following the month in which the work was done, the mayor or the mayor's designee shall obtain a lien against the property by filing with the county clerk of Tarrant County a notice of lien and statement of expenses incurred. 
B.  The city manager or the city manager's designee will conduct a hearing if the property owner submits a written request to the city manager within ten days of the property owner's receipt of the notice. The city manager may, based on a preponderance of the evidence presented at the hearing, affirm or modify the charges. 
C.  If no hearing is requested, or a hearing is held and the charges are determined to be valid, and the owner fails or refuses to pay the expense within thirty days after the first day of the month following the one in which the work is done, the mayor or the mayor's designee shall obtain a lien against the property by filing with the county clerk of Tarrant County a notice of lien and statement of expenses incurred. 
D.  The lien is security for the expenditures made and interest accruing at the rate of ten percent per annum from the date of payment by the city. 
E.  When the statement is filed, the city shall have a privileged lien on that property, second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements. 
F.  The city may institute suit to recover the expenditures with interest and may foreclose on the property. The original or a certified copy of the statement of expenses is prima facia proof of the expenses incurred by the city in doing the work or making the improvements, as specified in 342.007, Texas Health and Safety Code, which is adopted and incorporated into this chapter by reference. 
(Ord. 1023 § 1 (part), 1998) 
Chapter 8.10 - HOTEL LICENSING 

8.10.010 - Purposes. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to ensure the continued availability of transient lodging within the City of Benbrook, the maintenance of clean hotels, and to protect the health, safety and welfare within the City. This chapter is remedial and essential to the public interest, safety, health, and welfare, and this chapter shall be liberally construed to effectuate its purposes. 
(Ord. No. 1411 , § 1, 7-20-2017) 
8.10.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms and words shall have the meaning given below, unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    "Calls for service (CFS)" includes but is not limited to any and all calls to emergency services, (police, fire, medical, code enforcement, and development services) that result in a city employee being dispatched or directed to the hotel. This shall include any calls for service within the surrounding neighborhood that, through information or investigation, can be attributed or traced to the hotel premises. Calls for service include any self-initiated activity or investigation based on the observation(s) of an emergency services representative that result in a written report. Multiple calls regarding the same event shall be treated as a single call for service for purposes of calculating the CFS room ratio. Calls from employees of the hotel are excluded from being used to determine the calls for service room ratio. 
    "Calls for service room ratio" is defined as the number of calls for service divided by the total number of guest rooms in a hotel during the time-period as set forth in Section 8.10.040 herein. 
    "Clean or sanitary condition" means free from: 
1.  Chemical contamination; 
2.  Microbial contamination; 
3.  Insect or rodent contamination; 
4.  Displaying or undergoing spoilage, putrefaction; or 
5.  Trash, debris, dirt, or refuse. 
    Provided, however, such condition shall not be attributable to the hotel unless it exists in a room after it was cleaned according to the schedule maintained by the hotel. 
    "Commissioned security officers" are officers who have successfully undertaken and passed a state and national criminal history check and passed the thirty-hour training class, as may be amended, provided by the Private Security Bureau of the Texas Department of Public Safety. 
    "Dba" means doing business as. 
    "Designated city official" or "DCO" means the city manager or the city manager's designee, delegated staff, or duly authorized representative. 
    "Drug related" includes but is not limited to the manufacture, cultivation, importation into the state, transportation, possession, possession for sale, sale, furnishing, administering, giving away, providing a place to use, or fortification of a place involving any illegal or controlled drug, narcotic, or drug paraphernalia. 
    "Hotel" means, within the meaning of this chapter, any hotel, motel, or inn in the city having three or more rooms where transient guests are lodged for pay. 
    "Hotel room" or "room" means the portion of the hotel that may be used by a guest as a temporary lodging, including single rooms and suites. 
    "Law" means any federal, state, or city ordinance, statute, court decision, or regulation. 
    "Let" or "let for occupancy" means to permit, provide, or offer possession or occupancy of a hotel room as transient lodging. 
    "Lodging license" is an annual license issued by the City of Benbrook to the operator of a hotel necessary for the legal operation of the hotel in the city. 
    "Manager" shall mean any person who manages the business operations of any hotel on behalf of or under the direction of an operator and has a supervisory role or duties at the hotel. 
    "Operator" means any person who is the proprietor of a hotel, whether in the capacity of the owner, lessee, receiver, sub-lessee, franchisee, mortgagee in possession, hotel management company, or agent of any of the aforementioned. 
    "Owner" means any person, agent, operator, firm, or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in the real property where a hotel is located; or recorded in the official records of the state, county, or municipality as holding title to the property where a hotel is located; or otherwise having control of the property where a hotel is located, including the guardian of the estate of any such person and the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if ordered to take possession of real property by a court. 
    "Person" means an individual, corporation, business trust, estate trust, partnership, or any other group acting as a unit. 
    "Prostitution related crimes" includes but is not limited to prostitution and those crimes that involve prostitution or are related to prostitution, such as pimping or pandering, in violation of city or state laws. 
    "Transient lodging" means lodging for a period typically less than thirty days, but in no case more than one hundred eighty days. 
(Ord. No. 1411 , § 1, 7-20-2017) 
8.10.030 - Lodging license to operate. 
A.  It shall be unlawful to operate a hotel in the City of Benbrook without a lodging license. 
B.  The operator of each hotel shall file an application for an annual lodging license with the building permit and inspections department on a yearly basis. The application shall be submitted with the lodging license fee, as identified in Chapter 1.12, fees for city services. The initial deadline for submitting the application shall be within forty-five days upon passage of the ordinance [from which this chapter is derived]. The lodging license shall be issued or denied within sixty days upon receipt of the completed application. This initial license shall be effective until March 31, 2018 unless it is revoked earlier. Applications thereafter must be submitted no later than January 31st of each year, or if this date falls on a Saturday or Sunday, on the next business day. The lodging license shall be issued or denied within sixty days upon receipt of the completed application. All subsequent licenses shall be effective until March 31st of the following year. The operator shall re-apply for additional periods of one year thereafter by January 31st of each year. 
C.  In the event that a new operator applies for a license during the year (after January 31st application deadline), the license will be issued or denied within sixty days and the lodging license shall be effective until March 31st of the subsequent year. The application fee will be prorated based on the number of months remaining before the March 31st expiration of the license. Any subsequent license shall be applied for in accordance with the January 31st deadline above. 
D.  Application for an initial lodging license or annual lodging license renewal shall be filed on forms provided by the city and shall contain the minimum following information: 
1.  Hotel owner's name, address and contact information. 
a.  If an owner is a partnership, provide the name of all partners, the principal business address, and contact information of each partner. 
b.  If an owner is a corporation, the person registering must state whether it is organized under the laws of this state or is a foreign corporation, and must show the mailing address, business location, telephone number, name of the person in charge of the local office of such corporation, if any, and the names of the registered agent, all officers and directors or trustees of such corporation, and, if a foreign corporation, additionally the place of incorporation. 
2.  Name, current and historical addresses, contact information, current driver's license number or identification card number and state of issuance for each operator and manager of the hotel. 
a.  Provide historical address information, including the duration of occupancy of each residence, from each state of residence for the period of ten years prior to the date of the application. 
b.  If an operator is a partnership, provide the name of all partners, the principal business address, and telephone number of each partner. 
c.  If an operator is a corporation, the person registering must state whether it is organized under the laws of this state or is a foreign corporation, and must show the mailing address, business location, telephone number, name of the person in charge of the local office of such corporation, if any, and the names of the registered agent, all officers and directors or trustees of such corporation, and, if a foreign corporation, additionally the place of incorporation. 
3.  Legal and operating name (dba) of hotel. 
4.  Street address of the hotel. 
5.  Total number of hotel guest rooms. 
6.  Maximum number of persons the hotel can accommodate at any given time. 
7.  Signature of the operator. 
8.  All material contained herein on the application must be maintained current with the city at all times by the operator. Any material misrepresentation in the application for the lodging license or a failure to provide the required information shall be grounds for denial or revocation of the application or lodging license. 
E.  The application for a lodging license hereunder shall constitute consent to allow the City of Benbrook to conduct a criminal background check of every operator and manager to uncover, as it directly relates to the operation of a hotel, any convictions of a misdemeanor or felony involving prostitution related crimes, drug related crimes, crimes of moral turpitude, or crimes involving weapons or assault. 
F.  The application for a lodging license hereunder shall further constitute consent to an inspection of the entire hotel premises at reasonable times by the DCO, code enforcement officers, building inspectors, fire inspectors, and other authorized departments of the City of Benbrook for the purpose of determining whether there is any violation on the hotel premises of any ordinance of the city or any law of the State of Texas. 
G.  A lodging license shall not be transferable or assignable from one operator to another operator. Whenever a change in the operator occurs, the new operator shall apply for a lodging license within ten business days after taking over operations of the hotel. If the prior operator's lodging license for the hotel was denied or revoked, a provisional lodging license may be issued to the new operator with special conditions designated by the DCO, while the new operator's application for a lodging license is pending a decision. 
H.  A change in an owner or manager shall not require a new license as long as the updated information is provided to the city within ten business days and the new owner or manager does not make the operator ineligible for licensing under this chapter. 
I.  The operator shall display the lodging license in the hotel in an open and conspicuous public place in the lobby at or near the check in desk. 
J.  Failure to obtain a lodging license or maintain a lodging license at all times may result in revocation of the hotel's certificate of occupancy. 
K.  Once the lodging license is issued, the DCO or other city staff may routinely inspect: 
1.  The exterior of the structures and all of the common grounds of the hotel; 
2.  Any or all storage areas, community buildings, swimming pools, athletic facilities, club rooms, equipment rooms, and all other portions of the facility; 
3.  Any portion or portions of the hotel to determine whether the premises is uninhabitable, dangerous, or otherwise in violation of any applicable laws; 
4.  Any or all unoccupied hotel rooms and any and all occupied hotel rooms with permission of the occupant. The occupant and any representative of the hotel shall be permitted to be present, but may not hinder or interfere, with said inspection. 
5.  The DCO, upon presentation of proper identification to the occupant in charge of any hotel room, may enter, with the occupant's permission, any hotel room; provided, however, that in cases of emergency where extreme hazards are believed to exist that may involve imminent injury to a person, loss of life, or severe property damage, the DCO may, after presentation of proper identification, enter any hotel room at any time. The occupant and a representative of the hotel shall be permitted to be present, but may not hinder, during such entry and inspection. 
L.  In the event the DCO is denied entry by a representative of the hotel, that denial is a violation of this chapter and the DCO may use all resources provided by law to gain entry. 
M.  The DCO shall be allowed to examine records of the hotel, including maintenance logs, housekeeping logs, registration records, and pesticide records. 
N.  Continued maintenance and compliance with this chapter are conditions that are necessary to retain a lodging license and to obtain any renewal of a license. 
(Ord. No. 1411 , § 1, 7-20-2017) 
8.10.040 - Classification of hotels by CFS room ratio. 
A.  A hotel shall be classified in accordance to the following tier system: 
1.  Tier 1. Less than or equal to 1.0 CFS/room/year, or 
2.  Tier 2. Greater than 1.0 CFS/room/year. 
B.  Upon receipt of a lodging license application, the DCO shall determine the calls for service (CFS) room ratio of the hotel during the previous calendar year, or during actual operations if less than twelve months during the previous calendar year. Calls from employees of the hotel are excluded from being used to determine the CFS ratio. 
C.  Upon completion of the annual lodging license inspection and review of all calls for service, the DCO shall notify each operator, in writing by personal service, certified mail, or another method that provides confirmation of delivery, of the CFS room ratio and the tier classification of the hotel for the ensuing lodging license year. 
D.  Regardless of CFS ratio, all hotels operating at the time of the adoption of this ordinance [from which this chapter is derived] shall initially be deemed to be a Tier 1 hotel until the next January 31st registration period or until the DCO re-classifies it. 
E.  A hotel that has not previously operated in Benbrook shall be presumed to be a Tier 1 hotel until the next January 31st registration period or until the DCO re-classifies it. 
F.  The city may monitor the CFS room ratio for each hotel on an ongoing basis. The city may change the status of any hotel during a calendar year upon notice in writing to the operator, by personal service, certified mail, or another method that provides confirmation of delivery, that the CFS room ratio of such hotel has changed proportionately such that the CFS room ratio, if annualized, would fall within a different tier level. This notice shall include: 
1.  The tier designation assigned to the hotel; 
2.  As allowed by law, data specifying the types of CFS identified as having occurred on the property during the period reviewed, including the incident numbers assigned to such CFS, and the date and time of each call to allow the owner to understand the basis of the designation; 
3.  The requirement of a mandatory inspection to be conducted by the DCO; and 
4.  The opportunity and procedures by which the operator may challenge the data provided to the operator pursuant to this subsection upon which the designation is based. 
G.  Upon such notice of initial classification or reclassification, the operator may file a request for reconsideration with the building permit and inspections department for the city on or before the thirtieth calendar day after the date of notice. The request for reconsideration must show proof to the DCO that the DCO's determination is erroneous. After receipt of a request for reconsideration, the DCO shall consider the information provided and determine the CFS room ratio and classify the hotel as a Tier 1 or Tier 2 hotel within ten calendar days of receipt of the request for reconsideration. The DCO shall notify the operator of its determination in writing by personal service, certified mail, or another method that provides confirmation of delivery. The operator may appeal the DCO's decision under this section as provided in Section 8.10.070 of this chapter. The filing of a request for reconsideration under this section is a prerequisite to appealing a tier classification or reclassification under Section 8.10.070. 
H.  Enforcement of the tier classification or reclassification shall be stayed during the pendency of a request for reconsideration under this section or an appeal under Section 8.10.070 of this chapter. 
I.  The operator shall have thirty calendar days from the date of notice of tier classification or reclassification, the date of the DCO's determination after a request for reconsideration under this section, or the date of a final decision after an appeal under Section 8.10.070 of this chapter to implement completely the changes in operation required by the hotel's tier classification or reclassification. Failure to comply with this provision may result in revocation of the lodging license. 
(Ord. No. 1411 , § 1, 7-20-2017) 
8.10.050 - Lodging license-Grounds for denial. 
A.  The DCO may deny the application of an operator for a lodging license for any of the following reasons: 
1.  The hotel as constructed or as proposed to be operated does not comply with all applicable laws, including, but not limited to, the applicable building, zoning, fire, safety, and health regulations and codes, to the extent that the hotel is a public nuisance. 
2.  Tier 2 hotels may also be denied a lodging license if their CFS room ratio fails to meet the Tier 1 CFS room ratio within 12 months of being notified of their Tier 2 standing. 
3.  The operator or a manager is or has been a registered sex offender. 
4.  The operator or a manager has been convicted of a drug related, prostitution related, weapons or assault related crime. 
5.  The operator has knowingly made a material misstatement in the application for the lodging license. 
B.  Upon such notice of denial, the operator may file a request for reconsideration with the building permit and inspections department for the city on or before the thirtieth calendar day after the date of the notice to deny. The request for reconsideration must show proof to the DCO that the DCO's denial is erroneous. After receipt of a request for reconsideration, the DCO shall consider the information provided and determine if the information reverses or sustains the DCO's denial decision within ten calendar days of receipt of the request for reconsideration. The DCO shall notify the operator of its determination in writing by personal service, certified mail, or another method that provides confirmation of delivery. The operator may appeal the DCO's decision under this section as provided in Section 8.10.070 of this chapter.
