The filing of a request for reconsideration under this section is a prerequisite to appealing the DCO's denial of a lodging license under Section 8.10.070. 
C.  Enforcement of the denial shall be stayed during the pendency of an appeal under Section 8.10.070 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1411 , § 1, 7-20-2017) 
8.10.060 - Lodging license-Revocation. 
A.  A hotel's lodging license shall be revoked by the DCO if the operator or a manager, convicted of a drug related, prostitution related, weapons or assault related crime, is not immediately removed from all hotel operational or managerial duties. 
B.  A hotel's lodging license shall be revoked by the DCO upon good cause shown that the operation of the hotel is such that it is or has negatively impacted the health, safety, and/or welfare of its guests or the neighboring community to the extent that it is a public nuisance. In determining whether the operation of the hotel constitutes a public nuisance, the DCO shall consider, in addition to any other relevant factors, the following: 
1.  The operator's non-compliance with federal, state, or city laws, statutes, codes, and ordinances; 
2.  The occurrence of drug related or prostitution related calls for service and arrests at the hotel; 
3.  The existence of uncorrected code violations in the hotel; and 
4.  Any other condition, problem, issue, concern, or fact that is relevant to the owner, operator, or manager of the hotel. 
C.  In processing a revocation, the DCO shall prepare an investigation report that details the justification for the revocation. The investigation report shall include, in addition to any other relevant information, the following: 
1.  The frequency or occurrence of violation(s), arrest(s), or call(s) for service; 
2.  The frequency or occurrence of drug related or prostitution related violation(s), arrests(s), or call(s) for service; 
3.  The hotel's history of code violations(s); 
4.  Any uncorrected code violation(s) currently existing at the hotel; 
5.  Any activity, action, or effort taken by the owner, operator, or manager to obstruct or interfere with the correction of violations at the hotel; 
6.  The impact of the violation(s), arrest(s), or call(s) for service on the surrounding property and community. 
D.  Upon completion of the investigation report, the DCO shall provide a copy of the investigation report to the operator in writing by personal service, certified mail, or another method that provides confirmation of delivery, and notify the operator, in a similar manner, of the pending revocation, and that the operator may file a request for reconsideration with the building permit and inspections department for the city on or before the thirtieth calendar day after the date of the notice to revocation. The request for reconsideration must show proof to the DCO that the DCO's revocation is erroneous. After receipt of a request for reconsideration, the DCO shall consider the information provided and determine if the information reverses or sustains the DCO's revocation decision within ten calendar days of receipt of the request for reconsideration. The DCO shall notify the operator of its determination in writing by personal service, certified mail, or another method that provides confirmation of delivery. The operator may appeal the DCO's decision under this section as provided in Section 8.10.070 of this chapter. The filing of a request for reconsideration under this section is a prerequisite to appealing a tier classification or reclassification under Section 8.10.070. 
E.  Enforcement of the revocation shall be stayed during the pendency of an appeal under Section 8.10.070 of this chapter. 
F.  After the time allowed to appeal the decision of the DCO has elapsed without an appeal, the DCO shall post on the hotel premises a copy or copies of the revocation of the lodging license and shall file in the office of the county clerk of the county where the property is located a certificate describing the hotel property and the final action of the DCO revoking the lodging license. 
G.  A posted notice of the revocation of the lodging license may only be removed by an authorized DCO. Any removal, covering, defacing, altering, or tampering by unauthorized person(s) of a posted notice of the revocation of the lodging license may be prosecuted as a misdemeanor violation of this chapter. 
H.  Whenever a lodging license has been revoked by the city, the operator of the hotel for which the lodging license was issued shall surrender such license to the city. The operations of the hotel shall cease within ten calendar days of the posting of the notice of revocation of the lodging license. 
(Ord. No. 1411 , § 1, 7-20-2017) 
8.10.070 - Appeal. 
A.  Filing appeal. Any operator whose lodging license application has been denied or revoked or who is dissatisfied with the DCO's determination concerning tier classification or reclassification after a request for reconsideration may appeal the action of the DCO to the city council. To perfect an appeal under this section, the operator must file with the building permit and inspections department, on or before the thirtieth day after receiving notice of the action of the DCO, a written appeal containing the following: 
1.  A heading in the words: "Before the City Council." 
2.  A caption reading: "Appeal of Denial for a Lodging License" or "Appeal of Tier Classification," giving the names of all appellants participating in the appeal. 
3.  A brief statement setting forth the legal interest of each of the appellants in the hotel involved in the denial or classification change of a lodging license. 
4.  A brief statement in ordinary and concise language of the action protested, together with any material facts claimed to support the contentions of the appellant. 
5.  A brief statement in ordinary and concise language of the relief sought and reasons why it is claimed the action of the DCO should be reversed, modified, or otherwise set aside. 
6.  The signatures of all parties named as appellants and their official mailing addresses. 
7.  The verification (by declaration under penalty of perjury) of at least one appellant as to the truth of the matters stated in the appeal. 
8.  Produce all documents that the appellants relied upon. 
B.  Processing of appeal. Upon receipt of any appeal filed pursuant to this section, the DCO shall present it at the next available regular or special meeting of the city council. 
1.  Notice of hearing. 
a.  Notice of the hearing before the city council shall be delivered to the operator as listed on the application. 
b.  Notice shall be delivered at least fifteen days prior to the hearing by one of the following methods: 
1.  Personal service; or 
2.  Certified mail, return receipt requested, and regular mail. Notice shall be sufficient if the return receipt is returned; or unsigned for any reason, and the regular mail is not returned; or 
3.  If the operator, cannot be located, by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
2.  Contents of notice. The notice of hearing shall contain the following information: 
a.  The street address or a legal description of the location of the hotel; 
b.  The place, date, and time of the hearing; and 
c.  A brief summary of the action of the DCO related to the hotel, including a copy of the filed revocation request and the investigation report on the hotel. 
C.  Hearing. 
1.  The DCO shall present to the city council evidence to support its denial or revocation of the application for lodging license or its tier classification or reclassification. 
2.  The operator of the hotel may present evidence on any relevant issues. 
3.  Any party may examine or cross-examine any witness before the city council. Strict rules of evidence or procedure are not required, but the city council has the authority to enforce strict decorum and may cause the removal of anyone who causes a disruption. 
D.  Only those matters or issues specifically raised by the appellant shall be considered in the hearing of the appeal. 
E.  Enforcement of the denial or revocation of a lodging license or tier classification or reclassification of a hotel shall be stayed during the pendency of an appeal of the determination in accordance with Section 8.10.070.H. 
F.  Findings and orders of the city council for a denial, revocation, or tier classification or reclassification hearing. After hearing evidence from any interested party, the city council may: 
1.  For a denial hearing: 
a.  Uphold the denial for a lodging license, with or without conditions that, upon completion, would result in the license being granted; or 
b.  Overturn the denial and grant a lodging license. 
2.  For a revocation hearing: 
a.  Uphold the revocation of the lodging license, with or without conditions that, upon completion, would result in the license being reinstated; or 
b.  Overturn the revocation and reinstate the lodging license. 
3.  For a tier classification or reclassification hearing: 
a.  Classify the hotel as a Tier 1 hotel; or 
b.  Classify the hotel as a Tier 2 hotel. 
G.  At the conclusion of the appeal, the DCO shall file in the office of the county clerk of the county where the property is located a certificate describing the hotel property and the final action of the city council. 
H.  The action of the city council under this section may be appealed to a state district court of the county in which the hotel, which is the subject of the action, is located if such appeal is filed within thirty days of the city council's action. Such appeal shall be decided based on a de novo appeal to determine the existence of a public nuisance or proper justification for the denial, the revocation, or the tier classification or reclassification. 
(Ord. No. 1411 , § 1, 7-20-2017) 
8.10.080 - Limitation on continuous and cumulative occupancy. 
A.  Except for caretaker quarters or emergency sheltering situations authorized by the DCO, the sleeping accommodations of a hotel shall be let only for the use of transient occupants and shall not be used or occupied under any permanent basis, and no such occupant shall be deemed a resident of the hotel. 
B.  Except for emergency sheltering situations authorized by the DCO, it shall be unlawful for a hotel to let or otherwise provide any room therein to any person for more than one hundred eighty consecutive days. 
C.  It shall be unlawful for any person to allow registration under a different name in order to avoid the continuous and cumulative occupancy provision defined in this chapter. 
D.  Any property left in a room by a person or party that has checked out shall be removed by the operator of the hotel before the room may be occupied by another guest, and the property shall be stored or disposed of in accordance with applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. 1411 , § 1, 7-20-2017) 
8.10.090 - Premises requirements. 
A.  The operator shall cause to be maintained a complete register for each person to whom any room at a hotel is let. The register shall contain the following information: 
1.  Correct name and permanent address, designating street and number, city, state and country; 
2.  Actual dates of occupancy, indicating check-in time, check-out time, and room number; 
3.  Correct license plate or registration number, state of registration, and make of any vehicle; 
4.  Number of individuals staying in the room; 
5.  Amount of the bill and method of payment; and 
6.  Register records shall be maintained for a period of two years for each person who lets any room at a hotel. 
B.  No operator or manager shall allow or permit any hourly charge for any room in a hotel. 
C.  No operator or manager shall allow or permit any room within the hotel to be rented more than twice in any twenty-four-hour period commencing at 12:01 a.m. 
D.  The operator or manager of a Tier 2 hotel shall require any person to whom a room at the hotel is let to provide evidence of his or her identity and address of residence, and, in addition thereto, the full and true name and address of each member of his or her party. 
E.  It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally or knowingly falsify the information in a hotel register. It shall be unlawful for any person to provide false identifying information to a hotel. 
F.  No operator or manager shall knowingly let any room in the hotel be used for any illegal purpose. 
G.  An operator or manager providing false information to city authorities, regarding the identity of and hours of occupancy by any occupant, shall be prima facie evidence that the premises was being used for illegal purposes. 
H.  Room rates shall be posted in a prominent location in all guest rooms. Guests shall not be charged in excess of posted rates. A range of rates is acceptable in the posting. 
I.  For guest complaints, the telephone number and address for the DCO shall be posted in a prominent location in all guest rooms and the public reception area. 
J.  A representative of the operator shall be present and accessible to the DCO in person, on a twenty-four-hour basis. 
K.  The operator and all managers of a hotel designated Tier 2 are required to annually attend a hotel crime reduction class administered by the Benbrook Police Department. 
L.  All hotels designated Tier 2 are encouraged to have 24-hour, on-site security provided by commissioned security officers. All commissioned security officers working for a Tier 2 hotel must have a Class B security contractor license issued from the Private Security Bureau of the Texas Department of Public Safety. 
(Ord. No. 1411 , § 1, 7-20-2017) 
8.10.100 - Housekeeping and premises conditions. 
A.  The hotel premises and guest rooms shall fully comply with all City of Benbrook adopted building, fire, health and safety, and other adopted codes. 
B.  Mattress condition/cleanliness. Mattresses shall be free of stains, holes, rips, or odors, and be maintained in a sanitary, non-defective condition (e.g., without broken springs, indentations, sags, etc.). Any coverings placed over mattresses to prevent stains and excess wear must be removable and not permanently attached to the mattress or box spring (e.g., not stapled, nailed, or pinned or tied down to the mattress or box spring). 
C.  Linen condition/cleanliness. Linens provided by the hotel shall be maintained in a sanitary condition and be free of stains, holes, rips, or odors. Linens shall be exchanged with fresh linens that have been cleaned with appropriate sanitizing material and/or process to ensure disinfection upon each change of occupancy or at least once a week when occupancy does not change. Linens include but are not restricted to pillow cases, sheets, and towels. 
D.  Outer-linen conditions/cleanliness. Outer-linens provided by the hotel shall be maintained in a sanitary condition and be free of stains, holes, rips, or odors. Outer-linens shall be exchanged with fresh outer-linens that have been cleaned with appropriate sanitizing material and/or process to ensure disinfection as necessary. Outer-linens include but are not restricted to blankets, quilts, bedspreads, comforters, duvet covers. 
E.  Bathroom condition/cleanliness. Bathroom fixtures (e.g., toilet, bathtub, sink, shower, mirror) shall be maintained in a sanitary condition without cracks, chips, or stains. Bathroom floors shall be washed with water and a sanitizer at change of occupancy or at least once a week when occupancy does not change. 
F.  Carpet condition/cleanliness. Carpeting shall be free of stains, holes, rips, or odors in excess of normal wear and tear, and shall be maintained in a sanitary, non-defective condition. 
G.  Floor condition/cleanliness. Non-carpeted floor surfaces shall be made of non-absorbent material. All surfaces and tile grouting shall be maintained in a sanitary condition without cracks, rips, or missing elements. 
H.  Wall condition/cleanliness. Wall surfaces shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, without any holes, rips, or cracks in excess of normal wear and tear. 
I.  Mold/mildew. All surfaces, including carpeting, flooring, furniture, and fixtures shall be free from mold and mildew. 
J.  Electrical equipment. For the purpose of this chapter, electrical equipment shall include electrical items installed by the owner, operator or manager, including air conditioners, televisions, lamps, etc. All electrical items must be properly maintained and be in proper working condition. 
K.  Furniture condition. All furniture items shall be free of stains, holes, rips, and be maintained in a sanitary, non-defective condition. 
L.  Window coverings. Shades, draperies, or blinds shall be appropriately hung to cover all windows and appropriate light fixtures. All shades, draperies, and blinds shall be free of stains, holes, rips, or odors, and be maintained in a sanitary, non-defective condition. 
M.  Storage rooms. No more than ten percent of designed guest rooms may be used for storage room purposes. 
N.  Minimum occupancy. A minimum of ninety percent of all guest rooms must be available or in use for occupancy at all times. 
O.  Windows. All windows designed to be opened shall be operable and have an operable window security or locking device. All windows shall be intact and free of cracks. 
P.  Viewports. Each guest room door shall have a viewport or window convenient to the door. 
Q.  Door locks. All guest rooms are required to be outfitted with exterior electronic or magnetic locks for guests to gain access to their rooms or with other locks that meet with the approval of the DCO. 
R.  Exterior lighting. The exterior of the hotel property, including adjacent public sidewalks and parking lots under the control of the operator shall be illuminated at least between one hour after sundown and one-half hour before sunrise. Illumination shall be a minimum of one-tenth of one foot-candle throughout the property and shall not exceed four-tenths of one foot-candle of light measured at the property line. 
S.  Pest control maintenance. All hotel premises shall be maintained so that they are free from rodents, insects, and vermin and free from conditions that encourage or harbor rodents, insects, and vermin. 
T.  Interference with emergency telephone calls. 
1.  An operator or manager commits an offense if the owner, operator, or manager knowingly prevents or interferes with another individual's ability to place an emergency telephone call or to request assistance from emergency services. 
2.  An operator or manager commits an offense if they recklessly render unusable a telephone that would otherwise be used by another individual to place an emergency telephone call or to request assistance in an emergency from emergency services. 
3.  In this section, "emergency services" means police, fire, medical, code enforcement, and development services. 
U.  A hotel shall maintain a detailed list of the required duties for premises inspection, the employee or position responsible for such inspection, a schedule for performance of premises inspection, and a record of compliance with this section. Such list shall include a requirement for at least weekly inspection of the entire hotel premises for operational safety devices, fire extinguishers, and damage to the exterior of the hotel and parking areas. Such list shall also include a requirement for daily inspection and cleanup of the grounds, including trash and garbage containers and trash and debris not placed within such containers. A hotel shall maintain records that note the date and time of performance of all inspection requirements and the signature or initials of the person carrying out such duties. 
V.  A hotel shall maintain a detailed list of duties for housekeeping personnel and a schedule and log for cleaning rooms, replacing linens, inspecting for damage, and other housekeeping duties. Such list and schedule shall conform to other requirements of this chapter, and the log shall document the date and time of compliance and the initials of the housekeeping staff person who carried out such duties. A hotel shall perform room inspections at least once a week of all guest rooms occupied by guests staying in excess of ten days. 
W.  A hotel shall maintain a list of duties for inspection of rooms and repair of damage and replacement of damaged items. A hotel shall also maintain a schedule for inspection of guest rooms by maintenance personnel, which shall be prior to occupancy by a new guest or otherwise at least weekly. Such list of duties shall include inspection to ensure that smoke alarm devices and telephones are operational, as well as air conditioning units, plumbing, and door locks being operational and in good working condition. A hotel shall maintain a log noting the date and time of such inspection and listing all defects and the repairs or replacements performed. 
X.  A hotel shall inform all guests, by posting rules in the reception area and including such rules in material provided a guest or posting such rules in each room, that if any criminal activity occurs in a guest room or if a guest engages in criminal activity on the hotel premises, such guest will be immediately removed from the hotel premises. These rules shall be strictly enforced. 
(Ord. No. 1411 , § 1, 7-20-2017) 
8.10.110 - Abatement of imminently dangerous conditions. 
A.  Upon reasonable notice provided to the operator of a hotel, conditions that are imminently dangerous to the life, limb, health, or safety of the occupants of a hotel or to the public may be immediately abated by the DCO. Actions taken to abate the imminently dangerous conditions may include, but are not limited to, repair or removal of the condition creating the danger, the restriction of the use or occupancy of the property on which the dangerous condition exists, or any other abatement action determined by the DCO to be necessary to abate the dangerous condition. In the event the use or occupancy is restricted, the operator shall discontinue the use within the time prescribed by the DCO after receipt of such notice. 
B.  If entry onto the property and access to rooms or units constituting an imminently dangerous condition is denied to the DCO by the owner, operator, or manager of the hotel, the DCO may seek a court order or an inspection and abatement warrant from a court of competent jurisdiction to authorize the immediate abatement of the imminently dangerous conditions. 
C.  Costs for any abatement performed by or on behalf of the city, including the cost of police services provided and including the relocation of occupants of the property, shall be recoverable by the city from the hotel. 
D.  Expenses incurred pursuant to this chapter shall be charged against and attached as a lien on the real property on which the work is done or improvements made, and charged to the owner of the property for the same. 
E.  At the option of the city, the city may proceed under the alternative procedure set forth in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, Alternative Procedure for Administrative Hearing, Section 54.044 et seq., or as it may be amended, and the remainder of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, Chapter 54 Enforcement of Municipal Ordinances, Subchapter C Quasi-Judicial Enforcement of Health and Safety Ordinances, Section 54.031 et seq., as amended. The hearing must be held within thirty days after notice of the hearing and shall be conducted in accordance with the statute. Notice of the hearing shall be in accordance with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, Section 54.035, as amended. Pursuant to Section 54.044 et seq., the DCO shall act as the hearing officer who shall have the authority granted by the statute including the authority to set the amount and disposition of the administrative penalties, costs and fees. The hearing officer shall take all action required by statute in these proceedings. Each violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate violation for each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed, continued or permitted, unless otherwise provided. The civil penalty for a violation of a provision of this chapter may not exceed one thousand dollars. Administrative costs and fees shall be established by the city on an actual incurred basis for that specific case. The order of the hearing officer shall comply with Section 54.044(h), as amended. Anyone aggrieved by an order may seek judicial review in accordance with Section 54.044(k), as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1411 , § 1, 7-20-2017) 
8.10.120 - Offense and penalty. 
    An operator, owner, manager, or other person who violates any provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction is punishable as set forth in Section 1.08.010 for each violation and for each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed, continued, or licensed. Each violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. 
    Allegation and evidence of a culpable mental state is not required for proof of an offense defined by this chapter, except where expressly required by this chapter. 
    The provisions herein are cumulative of all other remedies including, but not limited to, abatement, injunctions, and other extraordinary writs. Section 1.08.010 shall govern all penalties for any violation of this chapter, notwithstanding any language to the contrary contained in any other section of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1411 , § 1, 7-20-2017) 
Chapter 8.12 - TOILETS AND PRIVIES 
Sections: 

8.12.010 - Water-flush toilet required where. 
    It is unlawful to permit, maintain or use any ground, lot, yard, residence, place of business, building or other place or structure, within the corporate limits of the city where persons reside, congregate or are employed, which is not provided with means for the disposal of human excreta by a water-flush-type toilet connected with a sewage disposal system which meets the requirements of construction and maintenance set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. 69 § 1, 1955) 
8.12.020 - Private sewage disposal system. 
    Every residence, place of business or other building or structure where persons reside, congregate or are employed, and every ground, lot, yard or other place so used as to require facilities for the disposal of human excreta, shall be provided with a private water-flush-type toilet, to be built or rebuilt, constructed and maintained in such manner as to meet the following requirements: 
A.  At any residence, place of business or other place or building where the customary users during each day do not exceed twenty-five in number, there shall be established or installed a private sewage disposal plant, the disposal plant to consist of a septic tank and a system of underground drains for the disposal of the tank effluent. The tank and drains shall be so constructed and maintained as to meet the minimum requirements of the county health department and the state health department. 
B.  At any residence, place of business or other building or place where the customary users during each day shall exceed twenty-five in number, there shall be established or installed a private sewage disposal plant, the plans and construction of which, in each separate case, shall be approved by the State Department of Health and the county health department. 
(Ord. 69 § 2, 1955) 
8.12.030 - Minimum standards adopted. 
    The city council has determined, after study, that the minimum requirements promulgated by the county and state health departments with respect to septic tank construction and maintenance and sewage disposal in general are minimum standards which are essential to the health and safety of the citizens of the city, and the minimum requirements and standards now set or which may hereafter be set by the departments with respect to the matters are expressly adopted as the minimum standards to be observed within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. 69 § 3, 1955) 
8.12.040 - Defective system. 
    Should any defect occur in the water-flush system of any residence, place of business or other building or place which would cause such system in any way to fail to meet the requirements provided in this chapter, the defect shall be immediately corrected by the owner or agent of the premises on which the defect has occurred, or by the occupant thereof, and it shall be unlawful to continue to use the premises unless and until the defect is corrected; provided, however, the premises on which a defect occurs may be used during the time reasonably necessary to correct the defect. 
(Ord. 69 § 4, 1955) 
8.12.050 - Nonconforming system deemed nuisance. 
    Any private sewage system existing or being maintained which does not conform to the requirements of this chapter shall be, and is declared a nuisance and a danger and menace to the public health, and the city, in addition to the penalties provided for violation of this chapter, shall have the power and authority to abate such nuisance in any other manner provided by law. 
(Ord. 69 § 5, 1955) 
8.12.060 - Outdoor privies and open toilets prohibited. 
    The maintenance or use of outdoor privies, open or pit toilets, within the corporate limits of the city, is expressly forbidden, and the maintenance or use of such toilets by any person, as well as the permitting of others to maintain or use such toilets by the owner of any premises, shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. Any such toilets in existence within the corporate limits of the city shall be immediately abandoned and the pits filled or sealed off. 
(Ord. 69 § 6, 1955) 
8.12.070 - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the city health officer or police chief, in cooperation with the county health officer, to enforce the provisions of this chapter, and in the performance of this duty, the officers are duly authorized to enter, at any reasonable hour, any premises within the city as may be necessary for the inspection of sewage facilities on the premises. 
(Ord. 69 § 7, 1955) 
8.12.080 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who violates the provisions of this chapter, or who refuses or fails to comply with any lawful order issued by the city health officer, police chief or county health officer pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not less than five dollars nor more than two hundred dollars, and each day that a violation of this chapter continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. 69 § 8, 1955) 
Chapter 8.16 - AIR POLLUTION 
Sections: 

8.16.010 - Short title. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter is known as the clean air ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. 241 § 1(100), 1968) 
8.16.020 - Air pollution control division. 
    There is created an air pollution control division in the city. 
(Ord. 241 § 1(101), 1968) 
8.16.030 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
A.  "Act" means the Clean Air Act of Texas, Chapter 727g, 60th Legislature in regular session, 1967. 
B.  "Air contaminant" means any smoke, soot, fly ash, dust, cinders, dirt, noxious or obnoxious acids, fumes, oxides, gases, vapors, odors, toxic or radioactive substances, waste particulate, solid, liquid or gaseous matter, or any other materials in the outdoor atmosphere, but excluding uncombined water. 
C.  "Air pollution" means the presence in the outdoor atmosphere of one or more air contaminants or combinations thereof, in such concentration and of such duration as are or may tend to be injurious to or to adversely affect humans, animal life, vegetation or property, or as to interfere with the normal use and enjoyment of animal life, vegetation or property. 
D.  "Ambient air standards" means the standards for the outdoor atmosphere established in Sections 8.16.080 through 8.16.100 of this chapter. 
E.  "Control director" shall be the person holding the position of city manager of the city. 
F.  "Emission" means the release into the outdoor atmosphere of air contaminants. 
G.  "Person" means any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. 
H.  "Property" means any freehold interest in land. 
I.  "Source" means any and all points of origin of the items defined in subsection B of this section. 
J.  "State board" means the Texas Air Control Board. 
K.  "Waste material" means refuse, garbage, rubbish or other solid or liquid wastes and useless, unused, unwanted or discarded materials. 
(Ord. 241 § 1(102), 1968) 
8.16.040 - Duties of control director. 
    The control director shall perform or cause to be performed the following duties: 
A.  Administer and enforce all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to air pollution as provided in this chapter; 
B.  Request that necessary legal proceedings be instituted to prosecute violations of this chapter and compel the prevention and abatement of air pollution or of a nuisance arising therefrom; 
C.  Examine and approve, or disapprove the plans for: 
1.  Equipment for the commercial burning of waste material or for the burning of waste material collected by the city waste material collection system, 
2.  Equipment designed for burning fuel in commercial and industrial activities, and 
3.  Equipment installed, repaired, constructed, reconstructed, altered or added to, to control or reduce air pollution from commercial, industrial, manufacturing and municipally operated activities, other than from motors and engines used in propelling land, water and air vehicles; 
D.  Make periodic inspections of the equipment described in subsection C of this section to determine whether it is in compliance with the provisions of this chapter; 
E.  Investigate complaints of violations of this chapter, make inspections of sources and ambient air conditions, and maintain a record of the investigations, complaints, inspections and observations conducted; 
F.  Promulgate such rules and regulations as may be reasonable and necessary to carry out the intent of this chapter to insure all sources of air pollution within his jurisdiction comply with the standards in this chapter. A copy of such rules and regulations shall be filed with the city secretary and shall constitute a public record; 
G.  Encourage voluntary cooperation by persons and affected groups in the preservation and regulation of the purity of the outdoor atmosphere; 
H.  Collect and disseminate information to the public on air pollution; 
I.  Work with planning and zoning agencies for the purpose of coordinating activities under the provisions of this chapter with planning and zoning activities, and foster the best possible management of the air resources of the city; 
J.  Cooperate and work with federal, state, county, municipal and other agencies concerned with air pollution to insure that the air resources of the city will be conserved and improved; 
K.  Perform such other functions as may be necessary to carry out effectively the duties and responsibilities imposed on the control director in this chapter. 
(Ord. 241 § 1(201), 1968) 
8.16.050 - Variance by control director-Revocation. 
A.  Whenever it is found by the control director, upon presentation of adequate proof, that compliance with any provision of this chapter will result in an arbitrary or unreasonable taking of property or in the practical closing or elimination of any lawful business, occupation or activity, in either case without corresponding benefit or advantage to the owner, lessee or operator of such business occupation or activity, the control director may grant individual variances beyond the limits provided in this chapter with such variances pertaining only to air contaminants which are not regulated by the Act or rules, regulations or orders of the state board. 
B.  Any variance granted pursuant to this section shall be granted for such period of time as shall be specified by the control director at the time of the grant and may be revoked by the control director upon the failure of the holder of such variance to abide by and operate in accordance with the terms and conditions of such variance. 
(Ord. 241 § 1(202), 1968) 
8.16.060 - Jurisdiction of control director. 
    For the purpose of enforcing the standards prescribed in this chapter, the control director of an incorporated city or town other than a home rule city, has jurisdiction within the corporate limits of such city or town and any extraterrestrial jurisdiction which may be conferred upon such city or town by law. 
(Ord. 241 § 1(203), 1968) 
8.16.070 - Required data and data control. 
A.  The control director may, from time to time, require the owner, lessee or operator of all sources and suspected sources in the city's base area to submit data on the sources for the purpose of evaluating the air pollution potential within the base area. 
B.  Any data and information identified as confidential when submitted, relating to secret processes or methods of manufacture or production, shall not be disclosed without the written consent of the person submitting it. 
(Ord. 241 § 1(204), 1968) 
8.16.080 - Adoption of state board regulations. 
A.  The city adopts as the ambient air and emission standards for the area within the boundaries and jurisdiction of the city the regulations of the state board enumerated in Section 8.16.090. To the extent of any conflict between the regulations and this chapter, the regulations of the state board shall prevail. The following regulations of the state board are incorporated in this chapter by reference as fully and completely as if set forth in full in this chapter: 
1.  General provisions of the board's regulations; 
2.  Regulation I, Control of Air Pollution from Smoke and Suspended Particulate Matter; 
3.  Regulation II, Control of Air Pollution from Outdoor Burning; 
4.  Regulation III, Control of Air Pollution from Sulphur Compounds; 
5.  Regulation IV, Control of Air Pollution from Motor Vehicles. 
B.  On or before the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, the control director shall file a certified copy of each of the foregoing regulations certified by the executive secretary of the Texas Air Control Board with the city secretary, who shall maintain the copy as a public record available for inspection. 
C.  The city expressly reserves the power to adopt regulatory ordinances on any aspect of the subjects dealt with in the foregoing regulations and on any other air contaminant to the extent not covered therein. The city also expressly reserves the privilege of adopting and using such methods of measuring the levels of air contaminants in the atmosphere and the emissions from any source as are authorized in the regulations. 
(Ord. 241 § 1(301), 1968) 
8.16.090 - Air contaminants and activities not covered by state board. 
    The city adopts the ambient air and emission standards for the air contaminants and activities specified in Table 8.16.090 for the base area of the city. 
(Ord. 241 § 1(302), 1968) 


8.16.100 - Methods and procedures for measuring. 
    When not otherwise specified in this chapter, the procedures used for sampling air, determining the concentrations of air contaminants in the atmosphere, and for measuring emissions of air contaminants from any source, and the methods of expressing the findings shall be those commonly accepted and employed by recognized authorities in the air pollution control field. 
(Ord. 241 § 1(303), 1968) 
8.16.110 - General prohibition. 
    No person may cause, suffer, allow or permit the emission of any air contaminant identified in Sections 8.16.080 through 8.16.100 within the jurisdiction area of the city, as defined in Section 8.16.060, except as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 241 § 1(401), 1968) 
8.16.120 - Enforcement-Civil and criminal. 
A.  The city elects to exercise the authority vested in it under the Clean Air Act of Texas, 1967, relative to the enforcement of the Act and this chapter. 
B.  The control director, his agents and employees are authorized to inspect the air and to go in and on public and private property within the area of his jurisdiction, as defined in Section 8.16.060, to determine whether or not the level of any air contaminant in the area meets the level set for the air contaminant by this chapter or by the state board. The director, his agents and employees may make inspections in the same manner and under the same provisions and restrictions as are applicable to the state board to determine whether or not the emission of any air contaminant from any source meets the level set for the air contaminant by this chapter or by the state board, and whether or not a person is complying with this chapter or with the Act or a rule, regulation, order or determination of the state board issued under the provisions of the Act. 
C.  The city attorney is authorized to institute and prosecute civil actions in the appropriate district courts, as provided in Section 13 of the Act, for injunctive relief to prevent any further violations of this chapter or of the Act or rules, regulations, determinations or orders of the board. Nothing in this chapter deprives any official, agent or employee of the city, the same as any other private citizen, of the right to file a misdemeanor complaint for a violation of this chapter. 
D.  It is the policy of the city to the extent possible under applicable laws and ordinances and within budgetary limitations, for the officials, agents and employees of the city to cooperate with the state board in the air pollution control work of the state board. 
(Ord. 241 § 1(501(a,b,d,e)), 1968) 
8.16.130 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine of not less than ten nor more than one thousand dollars. Each and every day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 691 § 1 (part), 1984: Ord. 241 § 1(501(c)), 1968) 
Chapter 8.20 - NOISE POLLUTION 
Sections: 

8.20.010 - Noise nuisance designated. 
A.  Any loud, irritating, vexing or disturbing noise which causes distress, annoyance, discomfort or injury to, or which interferes with the comfort and repose of, any person of normal nervous sensibilities in the vicinity or hearing thereof, is declared to be a noise nuisance and is unlawful and prohibited. 
B.  The following acts, among others not enumerated in this section, are declared to be noise nuisances, unlawful and in violation of the provisions of this chapter when such acts are done or accomplished or carried on in such a manner or with such volume, intensity, or with continued duration, so as to annoy, to distress, or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons of normal nervous sensibilities within the vicinity or hearing thereof: 
1.  The playing of any radio, phonograph, jukebox, nickelodeon, or any musical instrument; 
2.  Any loud or vociferous language or any soliciting for, or description of, any amusement house, moving picture theater, or other like place of amusement, or for the performance therein, in the entrance thereto, the foyer or lobby thereof, or on the sidewalks adjoining the same; 
3.  The keeping of any animal, fowl or bird which makes frequent or long, continued noise; 
4.  The continued or frequent sounding of any horn or other signal device on any automobile or vehicle, motorcycle, minibike, or other vehicle, except as a danger signal; 
5.  The running of any motor of any automobile or vehicle, motorcycle, minibikes, or other motor vehicle so out of repair, or so loaded, or so operated as to create loud, grating, grinding, jarring or rattling noise vibrations; 
6.  The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, automobile, motorcycle, minibike, other motor vehicle or boat, except through a muffler or other device which prevents loud or explosive noises therefrom; 
7.  The erection, including excavation, demolition, alteration, or repair work, on any building or other structure (including public infrastructure) shall be allowed only during the following periods: 
(a)  Construction of structures, other than for public facilities or infrastructure, shall be restricted as follows: 
1)  During Standard Time, Monday through Saturday, 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.; 
2)  During Daylight Savings Time, Monday through Saturday, 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m.; 
3)  Work on Sundays or federal holidays is prohibited. 
(b)  Construction on public projects (including subdivision construction of public infrastructure), as follows: 
1)  During Standard Time, Monday through Friday, 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.; 
2)  During Daylight Savings Time, Monday through Friday, 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m.; 
3)  Work on Saturday, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., only upon: 
i.  Request made at least forty-eight hours prior to commencement of the work; 
ii.  Availability of a city inspector (or authorized representative); 
iii.  Payment for the city's cost of the extra inspection; 
iv.  And upon approval of the city engineer. 
4)  Work on Sundays or federal holidays is prohibited. 
(c)  Exceptions to these limits are allowed only in cases of extreme and urgent necessity in the interest of public safety and convenience, and then only by permit obtained from, and issued by, the building official, city engineer, or any of his duly appointed and acting assistants and employees. Such permits may be renewed during the time the emergency exists; 
8.  The crying, calling or shouting in person or by a mechanical device, or the use of any whistle, rattle, bell, gong, clapper, hammer, drum, horn, loudspeaker or phonograph with or without an amplifier, hand organ, or other devices or instruments, musical or otherwise, for the purpose of advertising any candidates for elective office, any goods, wares or merchandise, or for the purpose of attracting attention to or inviting persons to any political rally, meeting or gathering, to any place of amusement, to any performance or show, or to any business or activity whatsoever; 
9.  The raucous shouting, whistling, yelling, singing, hooting or crying of peddlers, hawkers, vendors, or any other persons; 
10.  No person shall operate (or allow to someone else to operate) an internal combustion engine powered vehicle on any posted public roads within the city while said vehicle is using an engine brake (or Jake brake) without an exhaust muffler sufficient to prevent excessively loud noises by said vehicle, except during emergency operation. 
(Ord. 1250 § 1, 2007; Ord. 359 § 1, 1974) 
(Ord. No. 1360, § 1, 1-16-2014) 
8.20.020 - Creating noise nuisance unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person to create or cause, or any person to permit or allow to be created or caused, a noise nuisance, as that term is defined in this chapter, within the corporate limits of the city or within five thousand feet thereof. 
(Ord. 359 § 2, 1974) 
8.20.030 - Quiet zones designated. 
A.  All territory embraced within a distance of two hundred fifty feet of the real property upon which is situated any school, church or institution of learning, public or private, shall be held to be, and are declared to be, quiet zones during the period of time such schools, churches and institutions of learning are in session. 
B.  All territory embraced within a distance of two hundred fifty feet of the real property upon which is situated any hospital, sanitarium or other like institution for the treatment of sick persons, public and private, shall be held to be, and are declared to be quiet zones. 
(Ord. 359 § 3, 1974) 
8.20.040 - Creating noise nuisance within quiet zones unlawful. 
    The making, causing or creating, or permitting or allowing to be made, caused or created, any loud, vexing, irritating or disturbing noise which interferes with the operations or workings of any school, church or other institution of learning, public or private, or hospital, sanitarium or other like institution for the treatment of sick persons, public or private, situated within an area designated as a quiet zone is declared to be a noise nuisance and is unlawful and prohibited. 
(Ord. 359 § 4, 1974) 
8.20.050 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
B.  The city may also bring suit for injunction against any person, firm or corporation that shall violate or threaten to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, in order to prevent a continued violation or such threatened violation. 
(Ord. 359 § 6, 1974) 
Chapter 8.24 - OUTDOOR MUSIC FESTIVALS 
Sections: 

8.24.010 - Definitions. 
    "Issuing officer" means the mayor of the city of Benbrook, Texas. 
    "Mass gathering" means any meeting or gathering held inside the city limits or within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city which attracts or can be expected to attract more than five hundred persons who will remain at the location of the gathering for a period of more than eight continuous hours. 
    "Outdoor music festival" and "event" mean any form of musical entertainment provided by live performances occurring where: 
1.  More than five hundred persons are in attendance at any one performance; 
2.  Any of the performers or any of the audience are not within a permanent structure; and 
3.  The performance occurs inside the city limits or within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city. 
    "Promoter" means any person, group of persons, firm, corporation, partnership or association that organizes, promotes or solicits funds for the organization or promotion of a mass gathering or an outdoor music festival. 
(Ord. 363 § 1, 1974) 
8.24.020 - Permit-Required. 
    No person may act as a promoter of a mass gathering or outdoor music festival unless he obtains a permit from the issuing officer under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 363 § 2, 1974) 
8.24.030 - Permit-Application. 
A.  A promoter desiring to hold a mass gathering or an outdoor music festival shall file a permit application with the city secretary at least thirty days before the day the mass gathering or event is to be held. 
B.  The permit application must include: 
1.  The name and address of the promoter and the names and addresses of all associates and employees of the promoter assisting in the promotion of the mass gathering or event; 
2.  A financial statement of the promoter and a statement specifying from whom capital for the mass gathering or event is being supplied and in what amounts; 
3.  A description of the place where the mass gathering or event is to be held; 
4.  The name and address of the owner of the place where the mass gathering or event is to be held and a statement describing the terms and conditions of the agreement whereby the promoter is authorized to use the land; 
5.  The dates and times that the mass gathering is to be held; 
6.  The maximum number of persons that the promoter will allow to attend the mass gathering or event and a statement showing how the promoter plans to control the number of persons in attendance at the mass gathering or event; 
7.  A description of the promoter's agreements with performers who are scheduled to appear at the mass gathering or event and the names and addresses of other performers who have agreed to appear and their agents; 
8.  A full and complete statement describing the promoter's preparations for the mass gathering or event to comply with the minimum standards of sanitation and health as prescribed by Chapter 178, Acts of the 49th Legislature, Regular Session, 1945, as amended (Article 4477-1, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes); 
9.  A description of all preparations being made to provide traffic control and to assure that the mass gathering will be conducted in an orderly fashion and that the physical safety of the persons in attendance will be protected; 
10.  A description of the preparations made to provide adequate medical and nursing care; 
11.  A description of the preparations made to supervise minor persons who may attend the mass gathering; 
12.  The application for the permit must be verified by the promoter and be based on his best information and belief; 
13.  A filing fee in accordance with Section 1.12.030 must be submitted with the application for a permit; 
14.  A statement that applicable local zoning ordinances are being fully complied with as well as all other applicable city ordinances, resolutions and regulations. 
(Ord. 1032 § 5 (part), 1998; Ord. 363 § 3, 1974) 
8.24.040 - Investigation of applicant. 
A.  After an application for permit is filed, the city secretary shall send copies to the county health officer, the chief of police and the mayor. 
B.  The county health officer may inquire into preparations for the mass gathering or outdoor music festival and at least five days before the hearing submit a report to the city council stating whether or not he believes that the minimum standards of health and sanitation provided by state and local laws, rules, regulations and orders will be maintained. 
C.  The chief of police shall investigate preparations for the mass gathering and at least five days before the hearing shall submit a report to the city council whether or not he believes the minimum standards provided by state and local laws, rules, regulations and orders for assuring public safety and order will be maintained. 
D.  The issuing officer may conduct any additional investigation which he considers necessary. 
E.  The county health officer and the chief of police or the agent of each shall be available to give testimony relating to their reports at the hearing before the city council. 
(Ord. 363 § 4, 1974) 
8.24.050 - Hearing. 
A.  The issuing officer shall set a date and time for a hearing before the city council on the application for a permit. The hearing may be held not later than thirty days before the day set for the mass gathering to begin or the first performance of the event, and not earlier than fifteen days after the day the application is filed. 
B.  Ten days' notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be given to the promoter by certified mail, at the address shown on the application, and reasonable notice shall be given any persons who have an interest in the gathering or denial of the permit. 
C.  At the hearing before the city council, any person may appear and testify for or against the granting of the permit. 
(Ord. 363 § 5, 1974) 
8.24.060 - Permit-Grounds for denial. 
A.  After the hearing is completed, the city council shall enter its findings in the record and shall grant or deny the permit. 
B.  The city council may deny the permit if it finds that: 
1.  The application contains false or misleading information or required information is omitted; 
2.  The financial backing or stability of the promoter is insufficient to assure that the mass gathering will be conducted in the manner stated in the application; 
3.  The location selected for the mass gathering or event is inadequate for the purpose for which it is to be used; 
4.  The promoter has not made adequate preparations to limit the number of persons attending the mass gathering or event; 
5.  The promoter does not have assurance that performers who are scheduled to appear will appear; 
6.  The preparations for the mass gathering or event do not assure the minimum standards of sanitation and health will be maintained or that the mass gathering or event will be conducted in orderly fashion and the physical safety of persons in attendance will be protected, or that adequate supervision of minor persons will not be provided; 
7.  Adequate arrangements for traffic control have not been provided; 
8.  Adequate medical and nursing care will not be available; 
9.  The time and place for the mass gathering or event create a substantial danger of congestion and disruption of other lawful activities in the immediate vicinity of the mass gathering or event; 
10.  The promoter does not have adequate agreements with performers to insure with reasonable certainty that persons advertised to perform will in fact appear. 
(Ord. 363 § 6, 1974) 
8.24.070 - Permit-Authority. 
    A permit, if issued, shall authorize the promoter to hold a mass gathering or outdoor music festival at a specified place and at specified times. 
(Ord. 363 § 7, 1974) 
8.24.080 - Permit-Revocation. 
    At any time prior to five days before the day of the mass gathering or first performance of the event, the city council may, after reasonable notice to the promoter and a hearing, revoke the permit on a finding by a majority of the city council that the preparations for the mass gathering or event will not be completed in time for the first performance and that the failure to carry out the preparations will result in a serious threat to the health or safety of the community or the persons attending the event. 
(Ord. 363 § 8, 1974) 
8.24.090 - Cash deposit. 
    As a condition precedent to the issuance of a permit under this chapter, the city council may require the promoter to make a cash deposit with the city to provide an adequate fund for the compensation of such security personnel as may be required to insure the physical safety of persons and property of persons in attendance, as well as the persons and property of the community directly affected by the mass gathering or event. 
(Ord. 363 § 9, 1974) 
8.24.100 - Water supply requirements. 
A.  The quality of water to be supplied shall meet the approval of the county health officer, and on his request an evaluation of the supply may be made by the State Department of Health. 
B.  Water shall be provided at the rate of at least one pint per hour for each person present at the site. 
C.  Water shall be delivered to the dispensing points in such a manner as to preclude the possibility of contamination. All water conveyor facilities shall be cleaned and disinfected prior to being used and any containers used for water delivery shall be covered to prevent the entrance of dust, insects or other contaminants. 
D.  A suitable water outlet or water container shall be provided for each one hundred persons and be conveniently located for dispensing the water. If containers are utilized for water distribution, the containers shall be properly covered and provisions made for keeping the covers locked. A chlorine residual of at least 0.2 mg/l shall be maintained at all times at each water distribution point. 
E.  The use of the common drinking cup is prohibited. At least one disposable cup shall be provided for each person per hour of attendance. 
(Ord. 363 § 10.01, 1974) 
8.24.110 - Toilet facilities. 
A.  Toilet facilities, separate for each sex and plainly marked "MEN" and "WOMEN," shall be provided at a rate of no more than fifty persons per toilet seat. Such facilities shall be designed to shield the occupants from public view. 
B.  Privies, if provided, shall be structurally sound and shall be designed to prevent access of flies to deposited excreta. 
C.  Portable-type toilets, if provided, shall have waste therefrom collected at intervals of sufficient frequency to preclude overflow and the wastes therefrom shall be disposed of in a manner that does not create a health hazard or nuisance. 
D.  Hand washing and drying facilities shall be provided in the vicinity of each toilet building or location. Waste produced from such hand washing facilities shall be collected and disposed of either by holding tanks or subsurface absorption fields. 
(Ord. 363 § 10.02, 1974) 
8.24.120 - Vector control. 
    Sufficient equipment and chemicals shall be available to control insect vector problems in a manner approved by the county health officer. 
(Ord. 363 § 10.03, 1974) 
8.24.130 - Minimum area. 
    An area of at least fifty square feet per person shall be provided at the premises. 
(Ord. 363 § 10.04, 1974) 
8.24.140 - Solid waste facilities. 
A.  All solid waste shall be stored in suitable containers with tight-fitting lids and such containers shall be conveniently located throughout the area. 
B.  All solid waste shall be collected twice daily or at such more frequent intervals as may be necessary to maintain sanitary conditions at the site and be disposed of in a facility which has been approved by the county health officer. 
(Ord. 363 § 10.05, 1974) 
8.24.150 - Noise control. 
    Amplifying equipment used shall be designed to control the noise level at the perimeter of the site on which the gathering shall take place and be so operated that at no time more than seventy decibels is registered on the "A" scale at slow response of a standard sound level meter which meets the specifications of the American National Standards Institute. 
(Ord. 363 § 10.06, 1974) 
8.24.160 - Food sanitation. 
A.  All food and beverages sold or furnished shall be obtained from approved sources. 
B.  Foods, while being stored, prepared or served, shall be protected from contamination. 
C.  All perishable food shall be stored at such temperatures as will protect against spoilage. 
D.  All potentially hazardous food which consists in whole or in part of milk or milk products, eggs, meat, poultry, fish and shellfish shall be maintained at safe temperatures (forty-five degrees Fahrenheit or below, or one hundred forty degrees Fahrenheit or above). 
E.  The washing and sanitizing of food equipment and utensils shall be in compliance with the requirements set forth in the State Sterilization Law (Article 700b, T.P.C.). 
F.  All food service personnel shall wear clean outer garments, maintain a high degree of personal cleanliness, and conform to hygienic practices while on duty. Hand washing facilities shall be provided. 
(Ord. 363 § 10.07, 1974) 
8.24.170 - Medical and nursing care. 
A.  At least one emergency aid station for each ten thousand persons or fraction thereof shall be maintained and be clearly identifiable by a prominent sign during the entire time of the mass gathering. 
B.  Each emergency aid station shall have on duty at all times at least two persons who have had, as a minimum, training in first aid either by the American Red Cross or as a medical corpsman in the armed services. One shall be in charge. 
C.  Each emergency aid station shall be provided with the following equipment and supplies: 
1.  A tent or other suitable temporary shelter shall be erected at a convenient location on the grounds of the mass gathering to house the emergency aid station; 
2.  Folding cots, six; 
3.  Blankets, eight; 
4.  Chest or box (for supplies), one; 
5.  Chairs, two; 
6.  Flashlights, two; 
7.  Pail or plastic wastebasket, two; 
8.  Paper bags for waste, twenty-four; 
9.  Paper towels (roll or package), four; 
10.  Pitcher (with cover), two; 
11.  Tourniquet (rubber tubing), three; 
12.  Adhesive bandages (assorted), four dozen; 
13.  Adhesive tape (three-inch and four-inch), four rolls each size; 
14.  Bandages (two-inch and four-inch), twelve rolls each size; 
15.  Triangular bandage (forty-inch), six; 
16.  Cotton balls (prepackaged), four hundred; 
17.  Alcohol (isopropyl), two pints; 
18.  Scissors (blunt), one pair; 
19.  Snake bite kit, one; 
20.  Splints, six; 
21.  Bag mask resuscitator with oxygen supply, one; 
22.  Stretcher, one; 
23.  Thermometer (oral), two; 
24.  Bandage compress (two-inch, three-inch and four-inch), six each size; 
25.  Four-inch-by-four-inch cotton gauze squares, one hundred. 
D.  A written plan for the evacuation of sick or injured persons shall be provided and approved by the county health officer covering the following services and a copy of the plan shall be placed in a conspicuous place in the emergency aid station: 
1.  Name, location and telephone number(s) of one or more available licensed physicians; 
2.  Name, location and telephone number(s) of an available ambulance; 
3.  Name, location and telephone number(s) of an available nearby hospital. 
(Ord. 363 § 10.08, 1974) 
8.24.180 - Final site clean-up. 
    At the conclusion of a mass gathering, the site shall be inspected by the county health officer for health and sanitation considerations. The landowner, upon notification by the county health officer of the existence of any unsanitary conditions, shall immediately cause such conditions to be corrected. 
(Ord. 363 § 10.09, 1974) 
8.24.190 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation, or any employee, agent, servant or representative of any person, firm or corporation, who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction be punished by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars. Each day shall constitute a separate basis for an offense and each particular violation of the terms and conditions of this chapter shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. 363 § 11, 1974) 
Chapter 8.28 - FIREWORKS 
Sections: 

8.28.010 - Fireworks defined. 
    "Fireworks," as the term is used in this chapter, means any contrivance made of paper, paste or other material, and containing explosives or materials combined in various proportions for the purpose, when ignited or lighted by hand or otherwise, of making a noise, creating an explosion or producing a pyrotechnic display. 
(Ord. 535 § 1, 1979) 
8.28.020 - Permit-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or civic organization to have, keep, store, sell, offer for sale, give away, use, transport, manufacture, discharge, ignite or in any manner aid, assist or abet in the discharging or igniting of any fireworks within the corporate limits of the city without first having obtained a permit as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 535 § 2, 1979) 
8.28.030 - Evidence of unlawful intent. 
    The possession of any fireworks within the corporate limits of the city, without first having obtained a permit, shall constitute prima facie evidence of an intention to violate the provisions of this chapter and shall be deemed an offense. 
(Ord. 535 § 3, 1979) 
8.28.040 - Permit-Application-Written authorization. 
A.  A person, firm, corporation or civic organization desiring to conduct a commercial fireworks display shall first apply for and obtain a permit from the city secretary permitting the same. 
B.  The city secretary shall not issue such a permit unless the applicant first obtains written authorization granting approval as to such display from the following governmental bodies and agencies: 
1.  The police department; 
2.  Tarrant County; 
3.  The volunteer fire department; 
4.  The park board; 
5.  The United States Corps of Engineers; 
6.  The city council. 
C.  Such written authorization shall certify that each such governmental body or agency has investigated and determined that all reasonable measure of precaution will be taken to insure protection from fire; that appropriate crowd control and traffic safety measures have been insured and that all other action has or will be taken to promote the public safety and well-being. 
D.  When the applicant presents written authorization from each such department or agency as required in this section, the city secretary shall then issue a permit only after the applicant presents proper written proof of having first obtained public liability insurance in at least the amount of one hundred thousand dollars/two hundred thousand dollars for bodily injury and fifty thousand dollars for property damage. 
E.  The city secretary is authorized to request such other and further information from the applicant as may be necessary to identify the sponsoring organization, the purpose of such display, its time, date and location, as well as such other information as may be incidental thereto. 
(Ord. 535 § 4, 1979) 
8.28.050 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine of not less than ten nor more than one thousand dollars. Each and every day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 691 § 1 (part), 1984; Ord. 535 § 7, 1979) 
Chapter 8.32 - HIGH EXPLOSIVES 
Sections: 

8.32.010 - High explosives defined. 
    "High explosives," as that term is used in this chapter, means any chemical compound or mechanical mixture commonly used or intended for the purpose of producing an explosion that contains any oxidizing and combustible units or other ingredients in such proportion, quantities or packing that an ignition by fire, friction, concussion, percussion or by detonator of any part of the compound or mixture may cause such a sudden generation of highly heated gases that the resultant gaseous pressures are capable of producing destructive effects on contiguous objects or of destroying life or limb. Cartridges for small arms or shotguns, signaling devices or emergency equipment such as is designated for fire prevention are specifically excluded from this definition. This definition includes, but is not limited to, liquid nitroglycerine, high explosives containing over sixty percent nitroglycerine, compounds having an unsatisfactory absorbent or one that permits leakage of nitroglycerine under any conditions liable to exist during transportation or storage, nitrocellulose in a dry condition in a quantity greater than one-half pound in one exterior package, fulminate of mercury in bulk, and dynamite. 
(Ord. 322 § 1, 1973) 
8.32.020 - Permit-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to possess or discharge explosives, as that term is defined in Section 8.32.010, in any area of the city without having first applied for and obtained a permit for such possession or discharge of high explosives. 
(Ord. 322 § 2, 1973) 
8.32.030 - Permit-Application-Fee. 
    Any person, firm or corporation desiring to possess or discharge a high explosive within the corporate limits of the city shall first apply to the fire marshal of the city for a permit to do so on the form prescribed by the city for such permit. All such applications shall accompanied by an application fee in accordance with Section 1.12.030. 
(Ord. 1032 § 5 (part), 1998: Ord. 322 § 3 (part), 1973) 
8.32.040 - Permit-Application-Required information. 
    Such application for permit shall state the full name and address of the applicant, the precise legal description of the property and area whereon high explosives will be kept or discharged, the precise description and maximum amount of high explosives to be kept or discharged during the period of the permit, and the time, date and location of each contemplated maximum load or amount of such discharge. 
(Ord. 322 § 3(a), 1973) 
8.32.050 - Liability insurance. 
    The applicant shall be required to furnish evidence of public liability insurance in at least the sum of two hundred fifty thousand dollars for each single individual, five hundred thousand dollars for more than one individual, and one hundred thousand dollars property damage, prior to the commencement of any blast or blasting operations involving high explosives. 
(Ord. 322 § 3(b), 1973) 
8.32.060 - Inspection of premises. 
A.  The fire marshal of the city shall, prior to the issuance of any permit for the discharge of high explosives, make or cause to be made an inspection of the premises whereon such explosion is contemplated or whereon such explosives will be kept, to determine the proximity of residences and other structures to the area whereon the explosion is contemplated and the precautions, if any, that have been taken by the applicant to insure the safety of the citizens and protection of property located and situated nearby. 
B.  The fire marshal of the city shall not issue a permit if the inspection of the particular premises should reveal that public safety or private property would in all reasonable probability be injuriously or adversely affected by any discharge of high explosives. 
(Ord. 322 § 3(c, d), 1973) 
8.32.070 - Permit-Term of validity. 
    No permit so issued by the city shall be valid for a period of time in excess of seventy-two hours from its issuance. 
(Ord. 322 § 3(e), 1973) 
8.32.080 - Containment of debris and protection of waterways. 
    No permit for the discharge of high explosives shall be issued unless and until adequate and reasonable precautions have first been taken to insure that no waterway will be the recipient of debris as a result of any explosion and that the blast area has been covered with a material suitable to contain from free discharge into the atmosphere the dirt, dust and other debris released as a result thereof. 
(Ord. 322 § 3(f), 1973) 
8.32.090 - Storage of explosives. 
    The storage of explosives and/or blasting caps shall be maintained in a structure which meets with the requirements of the Internal Revenue Service of the United States of America. 
(Ord. 322 § 3(g), 1973) 
8.32.100 - Compliance with Clean Air Act required. 
    All operations conducted on or adjacent to the subject property shall be conducted in such a manner as to comply with the letter and the spirit of the Clean Air Act of Texas, as amended. 
(Ord. 322 § 3(h), 1973) 
8.32.110 - Lawful hours of detonation. 
    It is unlawful to detonate explosives at any time, of any kind, except between the hours of one p.m. and four p.m., Monday through Friday of each week. The detonation of any explosives at any other time shall be unlawful. 
(Ord. 322 § 3(i), 1973) 
8.32.120 - Compliance with zoning required. 
    It is unlawful to store, possess or discharge high explosives in any area of the city which is zoned A one-family residential, or B two-family residential, unless it is clearly shown that the subject property has a legal nonconforming use that would in fact permit such activity. 
(Ord. 322 § 4, 1973) 
8.32.130 - Discharge prohibited when. 
A.  It is unlawful to discharge, or cause to be discharged, high explosives in any area of the city that results in the depositing of any debris, dirt, gravel, or other materials in any lake, stream, creek, reservoir or other waterway flowing through or adjacent to the city. 
B.  It is unlawful to discharge, or cause to be discharged, high explosives in any area of the city, the result of which would be to release into the atmosphere pollutants in the form of dirt, dust, debris, rock or other waste materials. 
(Ord. 322 §§ 5, 6, 1973) 
8.32.140 - Indemnity agreement. 
    In no event shall high explosives be discharged within one-half mile of any residence without the person, firm or corporation, intending to detonate such explosives, having first provided an indemnity agreement with corporate sureties thereon indemnifying the owner and occupant of each such residence from any loss or damage arising as a result of any negligent act or omission on the part of the owner, his contractor, lessee, employee, agent, servant or representative. 
(Ord. 322 § 7, 1973) 
8.32.150 - Enjoining of detonation by city. 
A.  Because of the inherently dangerous chemical nature of high explosives and the incalculable and omnipotent danger to lives and property from the intemperate and unregulated use of high explosives in an urban structure, the city shall and does now have the right to enjoin any further detonation of high explosives within its corporate limits when any part or all of this chapter is violated on a periodic or essentially continuous basis. 
B.  For the reasons expressed in subsection A of this section, the city shall likewise have the right to enjoin any such imminent detonation of high explosives within its corporate limits whenever such explosion would in all reasonable probability release into waterways debris or emit into the atmosphere pollutants in the form of dirt, dust, sand, rock or particles thereof. 
(Ord. 322 § 8, 1973) 
8.32.160 - Exemption from fee requirements. 
    All governmental entities or subdivisions thereof and all public utilities, while 
engaged in the construction or maintenance of public facilities or improvements thereto, shall be required only to apply for and obtain a permit from the fire marshal and furnish evidence of public liability insurance as set forth in Section 8.32.050 of this chapter, and no permit fee shall be required of such governmental entity or utility, nor shall the remaining provisions of the ordinance codified in this chapter apply. 
(Ord. 322 § 9, 1973) 
8.32.170 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine of not less than ten dollars nor more than one thousand dollars. Each and every day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 691 § 1 (part), 1984: Ord. 322 § 10, 1973) 
Chapter 8.36 - GAS DRILLING AND PRODUCTION[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1286, § 1, adopted May 21, 2009, amended former Ch. 8.36, §§ 8.36.010-8.36.200, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 8.36 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1210, § 1, 2006. 

8.36.010 - Purpose. 
    The exploration, development, and production of natural gas in the city necessitate reasonable regulation to ensure that all property owners, mineral and otherwise, have the right to peaceably enjoy their property and its benefits and revenues. It is hereby declared to be the purpose of this chapter to establish reasonable and uniform limitations, safeguards and regulations for present and future operations related to the exploring, drilling, developing, producing, transporting and storing of gas and other substances produced in association with gas within the city to protect the health, safety and general welfare of the public, minimize the potential impact to property and mineral rights owners, protect the quality of the environment and encourage the orderly production of available mineral resources. 
(Ord. No. 1286, § 1, 5-21-09). 
8.36.020 - Definitions. 
    All technical industry words or phrases related to the drilling and production of gas wells not specifically defined in this chapter shall have the meanings customarily attributable thereto by prudent and reasonable gas industry operators. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    "Abandonment" is as defined by the Texas Railroad Commission and includes the plugging of the well and the restoration of any well site as required by this chapter.
