    Except on or within parking lots within public parks, it is unlawful for any person to perform the following acts in any public park: 
1.  Smoke; 
2.  Carry a lighted cigarette, cigar, or tobacco-containing pipe; or 
3.  Light a cigarette, cigar or tobacco-containing pipe. 
4.  Use of an electronic smoking device. 
(Ord. No. 1298, § I, 11-19-2009; Ord. No. 1373, § IV, 9-4-2014) 
8.48.036 - Sale or distribution of electronic smoking devices to minors prohibited. 
    A person commits an offense if the person sells, gives or causes to be sold or given an electronic smoking device to a minor or to a person who intends to deliver it to a minor. 
A.  If the offense under this section occurs in connection with a sale of an electronic smoking device at a business by an employee of the business, the employee who committed the offense is subject to prosecution. 
B.  It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (B) that at the time of the sale, the minor presented the person with an apparently valid proof of identification showing the minor was at least eighteen years of age. 
C.  A proof of identification satisfies the requirements of subsection (C) if it was issued by the federal or state government and contains the name of the minor, and a photograph resembling the appearance of the minor. 
D.  It is not a defense under this section that the minor purchased the electronic smoking device from a vending machine or other self-service merchandising mechanism if the machine or mechanism was located on the premises of the person. 
(Ord. No. 1373, § V, 9-4-2014) 
8.48.037 - Possession of electronic smoking devices by minors prohibited. 
    A minor commits an offense if the minor possesses, purchases or attempts to purchase an electronic smoking device. 
A.  A minor commits an offense if the minor falsely represents himself or herself to be eighteen years of age or older for the purpose of purchasing or receiving an electronic smoking device. 
B.  It shall be a defense to prosecution for a violation of this section if at the time of the purchase, the minor was participating in an inspection or test of compliance in conjunction with local law enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 1373, § VI, 9-4-2014) 
8.48.040 - Violation-Penalties. 
    Any person, firm, agent or employee thereof who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined an amount not more than five hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 1214 § 1 (part), 2006) 
Title 9 - PUBLIC PEACE, MORALS AND WELFARE 
Chapters: 
Chapter 9.04 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE CONSUMPTION AND POSSESSION 
Sections: 

9.04.010 - City parks and recreation areas. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to consume, possess or carry alcoholic beverages in city parks and recreation areas except within and one hundred feet surrounding Dutch Branch Park pavilions # 1 and # 2 and in concession areas as permitted by concessionaire agreement. 
B.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. The city may also bring suit for injunction against any person, firm or corporation that shall violate or threaten to violate any of the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. 1163 § 1, 2003) 
Chapter 9.08 - ARSON REWARD 
Sections: 

9.08.010 - Designated. 
    The city offers a reward of two hundred fifty dollars for the arrest and conviction of any person or persons found guilty of committing the crime of arson within the corporate limits of the city. This reward is a standing offer, and shall be paid out of the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. 203 § 1, 1965) 
9.08.020 - Posting. 
    Placards eight inches by twelve inches in size, showing the reward designated in Section 9.08.010 as offered, must be placed in wooden frames under glass, inside of at least six different public buildings and there remain on exhibit to the public. 
(Ord. 203 § 2, 1965) 
Chapter 9.12 - LITTERING 
Sections: 

9.12.010 - Prohibited acts. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to throw, place, drop or deposit upon a street, alley, sidewalk or other public place within the city, rubbish, trash, garbage, ashes, junk or other impure, unsightly, unwholesome or unsanitary matter of any kind. 
(Ord. 200 § 1, 1965) 
9.12.020 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or individual who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction, shall be fined in a sum not exceeding two hundred dollars. Each day during which a violation continues shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. 200 § 2, 1965) 
Chapter 9.16 - ILLEGAL FILLING OR DUMPING* 
Sections: 

9.16.010 - Generally. 
A.  It is unlawful for the owner of real property within the city limits to cause or permit the dumping or filling of materials upon land owned by him within the city limits, save and except materials that are comprised totally of either dirt, rock, sand, gravel or other earthen materials as determined by the city inspector or code enforcement officer. 
B.  It is unlawful for the owner of any real property situated within the city limits to cause or permit the dumping or filling of any materials upon land owned by him within the city limits (including dirt, rock, sand, gravel or other earthen materials) without first having obtained a permit from the city inspection department in accordance with Chapter 15.48 of this code. 
(Ord. 1199 § 1 (part), 2005) 
9.16.020 - Removal of materials. 
A.  If an owner causes or permits materials to be dumped or fill deposited on land owned by him within the city limits without having first obtained the permit from the inspection department, then he shall forthwith, after notification by the inspection department or code enforcement officer, cause the same to be removed at his own expense. 
B.  Should the city determine that materials have been dumped upon property of the owner within the city limits without a permit first having been obtained, then in addition to the other remedies and penalties provided for in this chapter and not exclusive thereof: 
1.  The inspection department or code enforcement officer shall write a letter (certified or registered) to the record owner of the property identifying the location and address on where such activity has occurred and directing the true owner to remove or cause such materials to be removed within fifteen days from the receipt of such notification. If the notification from the city comes back unclaimed, the city shall have the right to enter upon or permit entry upon such real property and remove, or cause to be removed, the offending materials. The cost of removal shall thereafter be billed to the record owner of the property by certified or registered mail and the record owner shall have thirty days from date of such bill to pay the same in full to the city. 
2.  Should the owner of such real property fail to comply with the order of the inspection department or code enforcement officer to so remove such materials within the time prescribed in this chapter, then in such instance, the city shall have the right to enter upon or permit entry upon such real property and remove, or cause to be removed, the offending materials. The cost of removal shall thereafter be billed to the record owner of the property by certified or registered mail and the record owner shall have thirty days from the date of such bill to pay the same in full to the city. 
3.  Failure on the part of the property owner to pay to the city the cost of removing the offending materials within the thirty-day period prescribed in this section shall permit the city to have and thereafter file with the county clerk a lien against the real property for the full cost incurred by the city in removing or causing to be removed the offending materials. The rights of the city thereafter to satisfy such lien through foreclosure or other enforcement procedures shall be like unto any other lien holder with a valid lien against real property in the state. 
(Ord. 1199 § 1 (part), 2005) 
9.16.030 - Appeal. 
A.  The owner of real property who receives notice from the inspection department to remove offending materials as provided for in Section 9.16.020(B)(1) of this chapter shall have ten days from the receipt of such notice to appeal from such directive to the appeals commission, which such appeal must be in writing, directed to the city secretary and received by her no later than ten days from the date that the notice from the inspection department or code enforcement officer to remove materials was received by the real and true owner of the property. 
B.  If the property owner perfects his appeal within the time and in the manner prescribed in this section, then in such instance, the appeals commission shall, within thirty days from the date the notice of appeal is received by the city secretary at a regular or special meeting, provide a full and complete opportunity to the property owner to be heard by the appeals commission with respect to the removal of such materials. 
(Ord. 1199 § 1 (part), 2005) 
9.16.040 - Hearing. 
A.  The property owner shall be notified in writing of the hearing within ten days prior to the hearing. Notice in this respect shall be deemed complete when sent by the city secretary by registered or certified mail to the last known address of the owner of record. 
B.  All time sequences as set forth in this section with respect to involuntary removal and the perfection of the lien as prescribed in this section shall be abated until the appeals commission acts upon the property owner's appeal and on the day immediately thereafter shall commence to run again if the appeal is denied. 
(Ord. 1199 § 1 (part), 2005) 
9.16.050 - Applicability of appeal provisions. 
A.  The provisions for appeal to, notice of and hearing before the appeals commission shall have no application to any complaint issued for an alleged violation of Section 9.16.010 of this chapter, but rather shall apply only to the involuntary removal of the offending materials and the creation and perfection of a lien incident thereto. 
B.  Failure on the part of the property owner to perfect his appeal within the time and in the manner prescribed in this section shall constitute a waiver of the appeal. 
(Ord. 1199 § 1 (part), 2005) 
9.16.060 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  The penalty for a violation of this chapter shall be in accordance with Chapter 1.08 of the Benbrook Municipal Code (1985, as amended). 
B.  The city may also bring suit for injunction against any person, firm or corporation that violates or threatens to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, in order to prevent a continued violation of such threatened violations. 
(Ord. 1199 § 1 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 9.20 - WEAPONS 
Sections: 

9.20.010 - Prohibited acts. 
    It is unlawful and an offense for any person to fire or shoot or cause to be fired or shot, any firearm, as that term is defined in this chapter, including any rifle, shotgun, automatic rifle, handgun, air rifle, BB gun, pellet gun or any weapon designed for the purpose of firing or discharging any shell or cartridge, whether such is blank or live, in any place within the corporate limits of the city, except as otherwise permitted for self defense or other purposes under the laws of the state, or by the exceptions hereinafter set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. 991 § 1 (part), 1997) 
9.20.020 - Exceptions. 
A.  This chapter shall not apply to either military personnel or peace officers of the United States or the state or any of its political subdivisions while in the performance of their official duties. 
B.  This chapter shall not apply to the use of blank cartridges for show or theatrical productions or for signal or ceremonial purposes in athletics or sports. 
C.  This chapter shall not apply on premises owned or operated by any branch of the Armed Services of the state or nation. 
D.  This chapter shall not apply to any organization existing for the purpose of operating and maintaining a rifle or pistol firing range, providing such discharge is in the course of the regular functions of such organization; and provided, that such organization has secured and holds a permit from the city council for the operation of such facility. 
E.  This chapter shall not apply to any authorized animal control or wildlife management official performing duties authorized by the city council. 
F.  The city council may authorize additional exceptions on a temporary basis by resolution when necessary to protect public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. 991 § 1 (part), 1997) 
Chapter 9.24 - ALARM SYSTEMS 
Sections: 

9.24.010 - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them as follows: 
    "Alarm business" means a business which sells, leases, maintains, services, repairs, alters, replaces, moves, installs or responds to any alarm system, or which causes to be sold, leased, maintained, serviced, repaired, altered, replaced, moved, installed or responded to any alarm system. 
    "Alarm system" means any mechanical or electrical device which is used to summon police, fire or emergency medical assistance, or to protect buildings or premises, both residential and commercial, from criminal acts or unauthorized entry by warning persons or agencies of a fire, medical emergency, crime or unauthorized entry through the emission of a sound, or by the transmission of a signal or message. 
    "Alarm user" means any person in control of a premises who or which purchases, leases, contracts for, or otherwise obtains an alarm system, or the servicing or maintenance of an alarm system from an alarm business which is responsible to cause the proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system. 
    "False alarm" means an alarm signal received by the chief of police or his representative for which a response is made within thirty minutes and which, from an inspection of the interior or exterior of the premises, is determined not to involve a criminal offense, attempted criminal offense, fire or other emergency. 
    "Permit holder" means the individual designated in the application, as required in this chapter, who is responsible for responding to alarms and giving access to the site and who is also responsible to cause the proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fees. 
    "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 900 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1987) 
9.24.020 - Permit required. 
A.  No person shall operate or cause to be operated an alarm system within the city without an alarm permit issued by the chief of police or his representative. A separate permit is required for each alarm system. 
B.  A permit is valid for a period of two years from the date of issuance and must be renewed by submitting an updated application and payment of a fee in accordance with Section 1.12.030. It is the responsibility of the permit holder to submit an application prior to the permit expiration date. 
(Ord. 1032 § 6 (part), 1998; Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 900 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1987) 
9.24.030 - Application for permit-Issuance. 
A.  Applications for alarm permits shall be filed with the chief of police or his representative on forms provided by the city. 
B.  A fee in accordance with Section 1.12.030 shall be charged for the issuance of each permit. 
C.  Each permit application must contain the following information: 
1.  Name, address and telephone number of the permit holder who will be responsible for the proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fees assessed by this chapter; 
2.  Address, telephone number and location (if P.O. box number used) of the alarm business office; 
3.  A description by brand and general type of alarm system in use stating the manner in which the alarm will be given and, if the alarm is to be transmitted to a central office, the address and telephone number of the central office; 
4.  Other reasonable information required by the chief of police, fire chief or their representative which is necessary for the administration or enforcement of this chapter. 
D.  Upon receipt of a completed application form and the required application fee, the chief of police or his representative shall issue an alarm permit to an applicant except for one of the reasons listed in Section 9.24.050 below. 
(Ord. 1032 § 6 (part), 1998; Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 900 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1987) 
9.24.040 - Transfer of permit-Cancellation. 
A.  An alarm permit cannot be transferred to another alarm system or to another permit holder except by written authorization of the chief of police or his representative. A permit holder shall inform the chief of police or his representative of any change that alters any information listed on the permit application within five business days. No fee will be assessed for such changes. 
B.  A permit holder shall cancel a permit for any alarm system which is removed from an alarm site or which otherwise ceases to come under the permit requirements of this chapter. Cancellation may be accomplished by returning the permit to the chief of police or his representative. 
(Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 900 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1987) 
9.24.050 - Permit-Refusal to issue-Revocation. 
A.  The chief of police or his representative may revoke or refuse to issue an alarm permit if he determines that: 
1.  There is a false statement of a material matter in the application for permit; 
2.  The applicant has failed to make payment of the required application fee; 
3.  The permit holder has failed to make payment of a service fee assessed by this chapter within ten days of receiving notice to do so; 
4.  The applicant or permit holder has violated any provision of this chapter; 
5.  The alarm system directly or indirectly, either by malfunction or accidental act of the alarm user, has caused more than nine or combination of nine police/fire responses to a false alarm within a twelve-month period; 
6.  An alarm permit for the same address has previously been revoked and the violation causing the revocation has not been corrected. 
7.  The permit holder has failed to renew an expired permit after thirty days' notice. 
B.  An alarm user commits an offense if he operates an alarm system during the period in which his alarm permit is revoked. 
(Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 900 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1987) 
9.24.060 - Responsibilities of permit holder. 
A.  A permit holder shall: 
1.  Maintain the premises containing an alarm system in a manner that assures proper operation of the alarm system; 
2.  Maintain the alarm system in a manner that will minimize false alarm notification; 
3.  Respond or cause a representative of the alarm business to respond, within a reasonable period of time, to a malfunctioning alarm system, for the purpose of deactivating or repairing the alarm system, for providing access to the premises or for providing security for the premises; 
4.  Refrain from manually activating an alarm, without prior notification to the police department, for any reason other than the occurrence of an event that the alarm system was intended to report; 
5.  Notify the police department prior to activating an alarm for maintenance purposes. 
B.  A permit holder shall not utilize any alarm system which causes an audible signal to be emitted for more than fifteen minutes after being activated or which emits a subsequent alarm without being reset. 
(Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 900 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1987) 
9.24.070 - Alarm business-Responsibilities. 
    An alarm business or person who is engaged in the business of relaying alarm notification to the city shall: 
A.  Communicate alarm notification to the city immediately in a manner and form determined by the chief of police, fire chief or their representative; and 
B.  Comply with the requirements of this chapter and any rules and regulations promulgated by the chief of police, fire chief or their representative. 
(Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 900 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1987) 
9.24.080 - Service fee. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided in subsections B, C and D of this section, the holder of an alarm permit shall pay a service holder fee in accordance with Section 1.12.030 for each false alarm notification emitted from any alarm system that is in excess of five false alarms within any twelve-month period. 
B.  If the person notifies the chief of police or his representative and applies for an alarm permit before a new alarm system is put into service, no service fee will be assessed during the first thirty days after the system becomes operational, and any alarm notifications during that period will not be counted in determining when a service fee is assessed. 
C.  If the responding police officer determines that an alarm notification was caused by unauthorized intrusion, attempted unauthorized intrusion, robbery, attempted robbery, fire, medical emergency, or an attempt to take a person hostage, that notification will not be counted in determining when a service fee will be charged. 
D.  An alarm notification will not be counted in determining when a service fee will be assessed if the permittee can prove that the alarm notification was the result of a severe weather condition, such as a tornado, hurricane, earthquake or other weather condition that causes physical damage to the alarm site, or is the result of a malfunction in the telephone lines for transmission of alarm signals, proof of the latter being documented upon the telephone company work orders or time stamped records from the alarm company showing the period of interrupted service. A permit holder has ten days to produce evidence for changing the status of a false alarm to a true alarm. 
(Ord. 1032 § 6 (part), 1998; Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 900 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1987) 
9.24.090 - Permit-Appeal. 
A.  1.  If the chief of police or his representative refuses to issue or renew a permit, or revokes a permit, he shall send to the applicant or permit holder by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of his action and a statement of the right to an appeal. 
2.  The applicant or permit holder may appeal the decision of the chief of police or his representative to the city manager or his representative by filing with the city manager or his representative a written request for a hearing, setting forth the reasons for the appeal, within ten days after receipt of the notice from the chief of police or his representative of the revocation or refusal to issue a permit. 
3.  The filing of a request for an appeal hearing with the city manager or his representative stays an action of the chief of police or his representative in revoking a permit until the city manager or his representative makes a final decision. If a request for an appeal hearing is not made within the ten-day period, the action of the chief of police or his representative is final. 
B.  1.  The city manager or his representative shall set a time and place for the hearing, which shall be served upon the applicant or permit holder by certified mail, return receipt requested. The city manager or his representative shall serve as hearing officer at an appeal and consider relevant evidence by any interested person. 
2.  The formal rules of evidence do not apply at an appeal hearing. All parties to the hearing shall have the right to present evidence and shall have the right to cross-examine witnesses. The hearing officer shall make his decision on the basis of a preponderance of the evidence within fifteen days after the hearing is held. The time for the hearing of an appeal may be extended by an agreement of the parties involved. The hearing officer may affirm, reverse or modify the action of the chief of police or his representative. The decision of the hearing officer is final as to administrative remedies with the city. 
(Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 900 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1987) 
9.24.100 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  A person commits an offense if he violates by commission or omission any provision of this chapter that imposes upon him a duty or responsibility. 
B.  A person who violates a provision of this chapter is guilty of a separate offense for each day or portion of a day during which the violation is committed, continued or permitted, and each violation is punishable by a fine of not less than fifty dollars nor more than five hundred dollars upon first conviction and not less than seventy-five dollars nor more than five hundred dollars upon second and subsequent convictions. 
(Ord. 907 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 900 § 1 (part), 1991: Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1987) 
Chapter 9.28 - CURFEW FOR MINORS* 
Sections: 

9.28.010 - Definitions. 
    [As used in this chapter:] 
    "Curfew hours" means: 
(a)  11:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday until 6:00 a.m. of the following day; and 
(b)  12:01 a.m. until 6:00 a.m. on any Saturday or Sunday. 
    "Emergency" means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term includes, but is not limited to a fire, a natural disaster, an automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
    "Establishment" means any privately owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited. Including but not limited to any place of amusement or entertainment. 
    "Guardian" means: 
(a)  A person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor; or 
(b)  A public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by the court. 
    "Minor" means any person under seventeen years of age. 
    "Officer" means a police officer. 
    "Operator" means any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation operating, managing, or conducting any establishment. The term includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a corporation. 
    "Parent" means a person who is: 
(a)  A natural parent, adoptive parent, or step-parent of another person; or 
(b)  At least eighteen years of age and authorized by a parent or guardian to have the care and custody of a minor. 
    "Public place" means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities, and shops. 
    "Remain" means to: 
(a)  Linger or stay; or 
(b)  Fail to leave premises when requested to do so by an officer or the owner, operator, or other person in control of the premises. 
    "Serious bodily injury" means bodily injury that creates substantial risk of death or that causes death, serious permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member of origin. 
(Ord. No. 1296, § 1, 10-1-2009; Ord. No. 1343, § 1, 9-20-2012; Ord. No. 1387, § 1, 9-3-2015 ; Ord. No. 1428 , § 1, 9-6-2018) 
9.28.020 - Offenses. 
A.  A minor commits an offense if he remains in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during curfew hours. 
B.  A parent or guardian of a minor commits an offense if he knowingly permits, or by insufficient control allows the minor to remain in any public place or on the premises of an establishment within the city during curfew hours. 
C.  The owner, operator, or any employee of an establishment commits an offense if he knowingly allows a minor to remain upon the premises of the establishment during curfew hours. 
(Ord. No. 1296, § 2, 10-1-2009; Ord. No. 1343, § 2, 9-20-2012; Ord. No. 1387, § 2, 9-3-2015 ; Ord. No. 1428 , § 2, 9-6-2018) 
9.28.030 - Defenses. 
    It is a defense to prosecution under Section 9.28.020 that the minor was: 
A.  Accompanied by the minor's parent or guardian; 
B.  On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian, without any detour or stop; 
C.  In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; 
D.  Engaged in an employment activity, or going to or returning from an employment activity, without any detour or stop; 
E.  Involved in an emergency; 
F.  On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the residence of a next-door neighbor if the neighbor did not complain to the police department about the minor's presence; 
G.  Attending an official school, religious, or another recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the City of Benbrook, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home without any detour or stop, an official school, religious, or another recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the City of Benbrook, a civic organization, or another similar entity that take responsibility for the minor; 
H.  Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right to assembly; or 
I.  Married or had been married or had disabilities of minority removed in accordance with Chapter 31 of the Texas Family Code. 
(Ord. No. 1296, § 3, 10-1-2009; Ord. No. 1343, § 3, 9-20-2012; Ord. No. 1387, § 3, 9-3-2015 ; Ord. No. 1428 , § 3, 9-6-2018) 
9.28.040 - Enforcement. 
    Before taking any official action under this section, an officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and reason for being in a public place. The officer shall not issue a citation or make an arrest under this section unless the officer reasonably believes that an offense has occurred and that, based on any response and other circumstances, no defense in Section 9.28.030 is present. 
(Ord. No. 1296, § 4, 10-1-2009; Ord. No. 1343, § 4, 9-20-2012; Ord. No. 1387, § 4, 9-3-2015 ; Ord. No. 1428 , § 4, 9-6-2018) 
9.28.050 - Penalty clause. 
A.  A person who violates a provision of this section is guilty of a separate offense for each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed, continued, or permitted. Each offense, upon conviction, is punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars. 
B.  When required by Section 51.08 of the Texas Family Code, as amended, the municipal court shall waive original jurisdiction over a minor who violates Section 9.28.020.A of this chapter and shall refer the minor to the juvenile court. 
(Ord. No. 1296, § 5, 10-1-2009; Ord. No. 1343, § 5, 9-20-2012; Ord. No. 1387, § 5, 9-3-2015 ; Ord. No. 1428 , § 5, 9-6-2018) 
Chapter 9.32 - GRAFFITI[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1295, § 1, adopted Sept. 17, 2009, amended former Ch. 9.32, §§ 9.32.010-9.32.060, in its entirety which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 967, §§ 1-6, adopted in 1995. 

9.32.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter. 
    "Director" means the director of the department designated by the city manager to enforce and administer this chapter or the director's authorized representative. 
    "Graffiti" means any unauthorized inscription, word, signature or marking, including, but not limited to, any slogan, drawing, painting, symbol, logo, name, character or figure, which is etched, written, painted, drawn or applied in any other way to any structure, building or property of any sort or to any portion or element thereof, whether the property is public or private. 
    "Owner" means any person with the legal right of possession to tangible property. 
(Ord. No. 1295, § 1, 9-17-2009) 
9.32.020 - Offenses. 
A.  An owner of any tangible property in the city commits an offense if he fails to remove all graffiti from the property that is visible from any public property or right-of-way or from any private property other than the property on which the graffiti exists, unless the graffiti was created on the property with the owner's authorization and does not violate the sign regulations of the Benbrook development code or any other applicable city ordinance or state or federal law. 
B.  Before issuing a citation or notice for a violation under subsection A of this section, the director shall first offer to have graffiti removed from the owner's property free of charge. If the property owner refuses the city's offer to remove graffiti free of charge, the director shall serve the property owner with written notice to remove the graffiti from the property within fifteen calendar days from the date the notice is served. The notice may be served by delivery to the owner in person or by United States certified mail, five-day return receipt requested, addressed to the owner at the owner's post office address as shown on the tax rolls of the city or county in which the premises are located. If the owner cannot be found and the notice is returned by the United States Postal Service, then the owner may be notified by: 
1.  Publication two times within ten consecutive days in the official newspaper adopted by city council; 
2.  Posting the notice on or near the front door of each building on the premises to which the violation relates; or 
3.  Posting the notice on a placard attached to a stake driven into the ground on the premises to which the violation relates, if the premises contain no buildings. 
    A property owner is excluded from the requirement to remove graffiti from their property if: 
1.  The graffiti is located on transportation infrastructure; and 
2.  The removal of the graffiti would create a hazard for the person performing the removal. 
C.  The fifteen calendar days will be counted: 
1.  From the date the notice is personally served to the owner or from the sixth day after the notice is placed in the United States certified mail; or 
2.  If the owner cannot be found or the notice is returned by the United States Postal Service, from the date the notice is: 
a.  Published for a second time in accordance with subsection B of this section; or 
b.  Posted in accordance with subsection B2 and B3 of this subsection. 
D.  It is a defense to prosecution under subsection B of this section that: 
1.  No notice was served on the property owner in compliance with Subsection B. 
E.  An offense under this section is punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars. 
(Ord. No. 1295, § 1, 9-17-2009) 
9.32.030 - Abatement of prohibited conditions. 
    If the property owner fails to remove the graffiti on or before the 15th day after the date of receipt of the notice, the city may remove the graffiti and charge expense for removal to the owner of the property and assess the expense against the real estate on which the work is done. 
(Ord. No. 1295, § 1, 9-17-2009) 
9.32.040 - Assessment of expenses. 
A.  In order to assess expenses incurred pursuant to Section 9.32.030 against the real estate on which the work is done, the city shall send the owner of the property a notice which shall include: 
1.  Identification of the property; 
2.  Description of the violation; 
3.  A statement that the city abated the condition; 
4.  A statement of the city's charges and expenses in abating the condition; 
5.  An explanation of the property owner's right to request a hearing within ten days of the date of the letter; and 
6.  A statement that if the owner fails or refuses to pay the expense within thirty days after the first day of the month following the month in which the work is done, the mayor or the mayor's designee shall obtain a lien against the property by filing with the county clerk of Tarrant County a notice of lien and statement of expenses incurred. 
B.  The city manager or the city manager's designee shall conduct a hearing if the property owner submits a written request to the city manager within ten days of the property owner's receipt of the notice. The city manager may, based on a preponderance of the evidence presented at the hearing, affirm or modify the charges. 
C.  If no hearing is requested, or a hearing is held and the charges are determined to be valid, and the owner fails or refuses to pay the expense within thirty days after the first day of the month following the one in which the work is done, the mayor or the mayor's designee shall obtain a lien against the property by filing with the county clerk of Tarrant County a notice of lien and statement of expenses incurred. 
D.  The lien is security for expenditures made and interest accruing at the rate of ten percent per annum from the date of payment by the city. 
E.  When the statement is filed, the city shall have a privileged lien on that property, second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements. 
F.  The city may institute suit to recover the expenditures with interest and may foreclose on the property. The original or a certified copy of the statement of expenses is prima facia proof of the expenses incurred by the city in doing the work or making improvements, as specified in 342.007, Texas Health and Safety Code, which is adopted and incorporated into this chapter by reference. 
(Ord. No. 1295, § 1, 9-17-2009) 
Chapter 9.36 - RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS FOR SEX OFFENDERS 
Sections: 

9.36.010 - Definitions. 
A.  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following terms, words and the derivations thereof shall have the meanings given herein. 
1.  "Minor" means a person younger than seventeen years of age. 
2.  "Permanent residence" means a place where a person abides, lodges or resides for fourteen or more consecutive days. 
3.  "Temporary residence" means a place where a person abides, lodges or resides for a period of fourteen or more days in the aggregate during any calendar year and which is not the person's permanent address or a place where a person routinely abides, resides or lodges for a period of four or more days in any month and which is not the person's permanent residence. 
(Ord. 1227 § 1 (part), 2007) 
9.36.020 - Offenses. 
A.  For each person required to register on the Texas Department of Public Safety's Sex Offender Database (the "Database") because of a violation involving a victim who was less than seventeen years of age, it is unlawful for that person to establish a permanent residence or temporary residence within two thousand feet of any premise where children commonly gather, which, for purposes of the ordinance codified in this chapter, shall include: 
1.  A public park; 
2.  A library; 
3.  A public or private school, except trade or business schools, colleges or universities; 
4.  A public or semi-public swimming pool; 
5.  A licensed day care center; 
6.  A studio or facility for instruction in the arts or sports where classes are taught to four or more children at a time; 
7.  A church; 
8.  A video arcade facility; and 
9.  A public or nonprofit recreation facility. 
B.  Evidentiary Matters; Measurements. 
1.  It shall be prima facie evidence that this section applies to such a person if that person's record appears on the database and the database indicates that the victim was less than seventeen years of age. 
2.  For the purposes of determining the minimum distance separation, the requirement shall be measured by following a straight line from the outer property line of the permanent or temporary residence to the nearest property line of the premises where children commonly gather, as described herein above, or, in the case of multiple residences on one property, measuring from the nearest property line of the premises to the nearest property line of the premises where children commonly gather, as described herein. 
3.  A map depicting the prohibited areas shall be maintained by the city of Benbrook. The city shall review the map at least annually for changes. Said map will be available to the public at the city of Benbrook Police Department. 
C.  Culpable Mental State Not Required. Neither allegation nor evidence of a culpable mental state is required for the proof of an offense defined by this chapter. 
D.  Affirmative Defenses. It is an affirmative defense to prosecution that any of the following conditions apply: 
1.  The person required to register on the database established the permanent or temporary residence and has complied with all of the sex offender registration laws of the state of Texas, prior to the date of the adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
2.  The person required to register on the database was a minor when he committed the offense requiring such registration and was not convicted as an adult. 
3.  The person required to register on the database is a minor. 
4.  The premises where children commonly gather, as specified herein, within two thousand feet of the permanent or temporary residence of the person required to register on the database was opened after the person established the permanent or temporary residence and complied with all sex offender registration laws of the state of Texas. 
5.  The information on the database is incorrect, and, if corrected, this section would not apply to the person who was erroneously listed on the database. 
(Ord. 1227 § 1 (part), 2007) 
Title 10 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC 
Chapters: 
Chapter 10.04 - TRAFFIC CODE 
Sections: 

10.04.010 - Adopted-Exceptions. 
A.  The provisions of Article 6701d of Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, as amended and as hereinafter may be amended, are adopted and made the traffic code of the city, save and except those provisions, chapters and subsections set forth in this section which are expressly excluded and not made a part of the traffic code of the city. Apart from the exceptions noted in this section, all of the provisions, sections and chapters of Article 6701d of Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes are expressly made the traffic code of the city. The exceptions and exclusions of those portions of Article 6701d are as follows: 
Section 9, Section 20d, Section 26, Section 28, Section 29, Section 30, Section 44b, Section 45, Section 46, Section 48, Section 49, Section 98, Section 105, Section 106, Section 108b, Section 132, Section 136, Section 137, Section 139, Section 139A, Section 140b, c, d, e, f, g, h, Section 141, Section 142, Article 18 in its entirety, Article 19 in its entirety. 
B.  Except as to those sections which are expressly omitted and listed in subsection A, all other provisions of Article 6701d shall and are now to be the traffic code for the city. 
(Ord. 353 § 1, 1974: Ord. 318 § 2, 1972) 
10.04.020 - Amendments. 
    All future amendments made to Article 6701d of Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes and to those sections that are not excluded therefrom by Section 10.04.010 shall be automatically a part of the traffic code of the city. 
(Ord. 353 § 2, 1974: Ord. 318 § 3, 1972) 
10.04.030 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
B.  The city may also bring suit for injunction against any person, firm or corporation that shall violate or threaten to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, in order to prevent a continued violation or such threatened violation. 
(Ord. 353 § 5, 1974: Ord. 318 § 6, 1972) 
Chapter 10.08 - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES 
Sections: 

10.08.010 - Conformity with state requirements. 
    All traffic control devices, including signs, signals and markings installed or used for the purpose of directing and controlling traffic within the city shall conform with the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways, Volumes I and II (hereinafter called the manual). Article 6701d, Vernon's Civil Statutes states that all signs, signals and markings erected or used by the city shall be uniform and be located so far as practicable according to the directions shown in the manual throughout the city. All existing traffic control devices and those erected in the future by the city being consistent with the manual, state law and this chapter shall be official traffic control devices. 
(Ord. 446 § 1, 1976) 
10.08.020 - Observance of instructions required. 
    The driver of any vehicle, motor vehicle or animal shall obey the instructions of any official traffic control device, sign, signal or marking applicable thereto placed in accordance with this chapter, the manual and any ordinance directing that such traffic control device, sign or signal shall be installed or erected, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle permitted by this chapter. 
(Ord. 446 § 2, 1976) 
10.08.030 - Unauthorized signs and devices prohibited. 
A.  No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any highway, street or alley any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic control device or railroad sign or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official control device or any railroad sign or signal. 
B.  This section shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection upon private property adjacent to highways, streets or alleys of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official signs. 
C.  Every such prohibited sign, signal or marking is declared to be a public nuisance, and the chief of police is empowered to remove the same or cause it to be moved without notice. 
(Ord. 446 § 4, 1976) 
10.08.040 - Damage to device prohibited. 
    No person shall without lawful authority attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, knock down or remove any official traffic control device, sign or signal or any railroad sign or signal or any inscription, shield or insignia thereon, or any part thereof. 
(Ord. 446 § 5, 1976) 
10.08.050 - Report of installation. 
    Whenever the public works superintendent has erected and installed any official traffic control device, signal or sign at any location in the city, or has caused the same to be done under his direction, in obedience to this chapter, the manual, or another ordinance directing the erection of such device, signal or sign, he shall thereafter file a report with the city secretary in writing and signed officially by the city manager, stating the type of traffic control device, sign or signal, and when and where the same was erected or installed. The city secretary shall file and maintain such report of the traffic control signs among the official papers of the office of the city secretary. 
(Ord. 446 § 6, 1976) 
10.08.060 - Installation authority. 
    It is unlawful for any person other than the public works superintendent, acting pursuant to an ordinance of the city, to install or cause to be installed any signal, sign or device purporting to direct the use of the streets, or the activities on those streets, of pedestrians, vehicles, motor vehicles or animals. Proof, in any prosecution for a violation of this chapter or any traffic ordinance of the city, that any traffic control device, sign, signal or marking was actually in place on any street shall constitute prima facie evidence that the same was installed by the public works superintendent pursuant to the authority of this chapter and/or the ordinance directing the installation of such device, signal or marking. 
(Ord. 446 § 7, 1976) 
10.08.070 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than one dollar nor more than two hundred dollars. 
(Ord. 446 § 8, 1976) 
Chapter 10.12 - VEHICLE USE PROHIBITED IN CERTAIN AREAS 
Sections: 

10.12.010 - Prohibited acts-Exception. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate a vehicle, motorcycle or motor-driven cycle, as those terms are defined in subdivision 1 of Article 1 of Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, 6701d, on any unpaved public property, or on any public sidewalk, or on any paved or unpaved public property along a street and behind the curb, or on any paved or unpaved shoulder of any public road; provided, however, that nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the riding of such devices as described in this section on areas that are properly marked and previously designated now or as hereinafter may be designated by the city council as "cycle-riding areas" within the Corps of Engineers area of a public park or in any other area that may hereinafter be designated by the city council as "cycle-riding areas." 
(Ord. 711 § 1, 1985) 
10.12.020 - Written consent of property owner required. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to ride such a vehicle as defined in Section 10.12.010, with the exception of golf carts, but including any motor driven all-terrain vehicle, go-cart, or other motor driven vehicle which is designed for off-highway use, on any utility easement, vacant lot, or any other unpaved private property not owned by the rider or his immediate family, without the express written consent of the owner carried on his, the rider's, person. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to ride, operate, or permit the operation of a vehicle as defined in Section 10.12.010, with the exception of golf carts, but including any motor driven all-terrain vehicle, go-cart, or other motor driven vehicle, which is designed for off-highway use for recreational purposes on any property within six hundred feet of any dwelling unit that exists on an adjacent property. For the purposes of this provision, measurement shall be made in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the occurrence of the activity to the nearest adjacent dwelling unit. Such vehicles used for recreational purposes which are not internal combustion engine driven are exempt from the requirements of this subsection. 
(Ord. 1142 § 1, 2003; Ord. 711 § 2, 1985) 
10.12.030 - Permitting unauthorized minor to drive. 
    No person shall cause or knowingly permit his child or ward under the age of eighteen years to drive a vehicle, motorcycle or motor-driven vehicle, as those terms are defined in this chapter, when such minor is not authorized under this chapter, or is otherwise in violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 711 § 3, 1985) 
10.12.040 - Use of designated motorcycle area prohibited. 
A.  It is illegal for any person to propel, or cause to be propelled, two-wheel, off-road vehicles at any time in the locality known as the Corps of Engineers, city of Fort Worth motorcycle area, which is located within the corporate limits of the city of Benbrook, as the same is depicted on Exhibit A of the ordinance codified in this section, and made a part of this section for all purposes. 
B.  The motorcycle area is situated within the boundaries that may be described as follows, to wit: 
1.  West boundary: Farm Road #1043, with an area extending one thousand two hundred feet; 
2.  East boundary: the Clear Fork of the Trinity River; 
3.  North boundary: a cabled area extending one hundred feet northerly from the channel bank; 
4.  South boundary: a common boundary between the motorcycle area and Pecan Valley Golf Course. 
(Ord. 462 §§ 1, 2, 1976: Ord. 447 § 1, 1976: Ord. 440 § 2, 1976) 
10.12.050 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
B.  The city may also bring suit for injunction against any person, firm or corporation that shall violate or threaten to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, in order to prevent a continued violation or such threatened violation. 
(Ord. 711 § 4, 1985; Ord. 462 § 4, 1976: Ord. 447 § 3, 1976: Ord. 440 § 4, 1976) 
Chapter 10.16 - COMMERCIAL VEHICLES 
Sections: 

10.16.010 - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section as follows: 
    "Commercial truck" means any motor vehicle designed or used for the transportation of property, not including a passenger bus, passenger automobile, motorcycle, panel delivery truck or pickup truck. 
    "Hazardous material carrier" means vehicles transporting or designed to transport materials that by their chemical compounds or reactivity are required to display United States Department of Transportation (D.O.T.) warning placards and/or labels as directed in Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, 6701d, Article XIV, Section 139. 
    "Motor vehicle" means every vehicle, as defined in this section, which is self-propelled. 
    "Semi-trailer" means every vehicle of the trailer type so designated or used in conjunction with a motor vehicle that some part of its own weight and that of its own load rests upon or is carried by another motor vehicle. 
    "Trailer" means every vehicle without motive power designed or used for carrying property or passengers wholly on its own structures for commercial use and to be drawn by a motor vehicle. This does not apply to trailers for recreational use and/or trailers carrying recreational vehicles such as boats, motorcycles, etc. 
    "Truck-tractor" means every motor vehicle designed or used primarily for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn. 
    "Vehicle" means every mechanical device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway, including motor vehicles, commercial motor vehicles, truck tractors, trailers and semi-trailers, severally, as defined in this section, but excepting devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. 684 § 1, 1984) 
10.16.020 - Truck routes-Generally. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated any commercial truck, truck-tractor, trailer, semi-trailer, or any combination thereof, through the city in intercity travel, without a local destination or point of origin, except upon such streets as are designated as truck routes by this chapter. Such trucks with a destination or point of origin within the corporate limits of the city shall be operated only on truck routes or on the shortest street route between such destination or point of origin and the nearest truck route. 
(Ord. 684 § 2(A), 1984) 
10.16.030 - Streets subject to damage-Alternate routes. 
A.  Any residential street serving as an entrance or exit from the nearest point of destination may be deleted from truck traffic by the city if the street is in repair or subject to weight damage. 
B.  Whenever any street designated as a truck route or hazardous materials route is being repaired, subject to weight damage or is otherwise temporarily out of use, the city is authorized to designate alternate truck routes and hazardous materials routes for such period as might be necessary. 
(Ord. 684 § 2(B), 1984) 
10.16.040 - Approved truck routes. 
    Approved truck routes shall be those sections of public streets and highways located within the city where trucks will be allowed to travel within or through the city. The following streets and parts of streets are designated truck routes under this chapter: 
I-20 From the western city limit line to the eastern city limit line. West Vickery From the eastern city limit line to its intersection with Old Benbrook Road. U.S. Highway 377 From the northern city limit through the city to its exit at the southern city limits. F.M. 2871 From Highway 377 west to the western city limit line. Winscott Road From its intersection with Old Benbrook Road to its intersection with Lakeside Drive. Lakeside Drive From Highway 377 east to the intersection of Winscott Road.  
(Ord. 684 § 3(A), 1984) 
10.16.050 - Approved hazardous materials routes. 
    "Approved hazardous materials routes" means those portions of State Highway I-20 and U.S. Highway 377, located within the city and designated by this chapter as a through traffic route for hazardous materials. 
(Ord. 684 § 3(B), 1984) 
10.16.060 - Signs and markings. 
    The traffic engineer shall erect appropriate signs and markings to designate the truck routes and hazardous materials routes described in this chapter. 
(Ord. 684 § 3(C), 1984) 
10.16.070 - Use of truck routes required-Exceptions. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall operate or cause to be operated upon any public streets within the corporate limits of the city any commercial truck, hazardous waste carrier, truck-tractor, trailer, semi-trailer or any combination thereof unless such street or streets are designated as either truck routes or hazardous materials routes by this chapter; such vehicles shall be operated on a truck route wherever reasonably practicable; they shall be operated on a commercial delivery route only when it is not reasonably practicable. 
B.  Exceptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply: 
1.  To a commercial truck on a single occasion in a twenty-four-hour period traveling to or from a truck terminal, garage, place of repair, place of performing a service, or a place of loading or unloading, over the shortest practicable route to a point not on a truck route; any such vehicle shall be permitted to proceed from one such point not on a truck route to another such point without returning to a truck route, if to return to a truck route would unreasonably increase the distance to be traveled between such points; the operators of any such vehicle shall carry evidence of the location of its last stop and of its immediate destination in order for this exception to apply; 
2.  To emergency vehicle operating in response to any emergency call; 
3.  To vehicles operated by a public utility while cruising in an assigned area for the purpose of inspecting the facilities of the public utility and/or providing maintenance service to the facilities; 
4.  To vehicles operated for public service, i.e., garbage pickup, street repair, water service, and emergency vehicles. 
(Ord. 684 § 4, 1984) 
10.16.080 - Weight limitations. 
    No commercial truck, truck-tractor, trailer, semi-trailer or combination of such vehicles shall be operated or caused or permitted to be operated upon any public street within the corporate limits of the city having a weight in excess of any one or more of the following limitations: 
A.  In no event shall the total gross weight, with load, of a two-axle vehicle exceed thirty-one thousand pounds; of a three-axle vehicle exceed forty-nine thousand pounds; of a four-axle vehicle exceed sixty-three thousand pounds; of a five-axle vehicle exceed seventy-two thousand pounds; 
B.  No axle shall carry a load in excess of eighteen thousand pounds. An "axle load" shall be defined as the total load transmitted to the road by all wheels whose centers may be included between two parallel transverse vertical planes forty inches apart, extending across the full width of the vehicle; 
C.  The total gross weight concentrated on the highway surface from any tandem axle group shall not exceed thirty-two thousand pounds for each such tandem axle group. "Tandem axle group" is defined to be two or more axles spaced forty inches or more apart from center to center having at least one common point of weight suspension; 
D.  Vehicles used exclusively to transport ready-mix concrete may be operated upon the public streets of the city with a tandem axle load not to exceed thirty-six thousand pounds, a single axle load not to exceed twelve thousand pounds. 
(Ord. 684 § 5(A), 1984) 
10.16.090 - Permit for oversize or overweight vehicles. 
    Upon written application timely made by any person or corporation which desires to operate or cause to be operated on the public streets within the corporate limits of the city, overweight or oversize equipment for the transportation of such commodities as cannot be reasonably dismantled, where the total gross weight or size of the vehicle and its load exceed the limits allowed by this chapter, the city may issue a permit for the operation of such equipment or fleets of equipment for a specified period of time, over a route or routes to be designated by the city, if such routes can be determined at the time application for the permit is made. 
(Ord. 684 § 5(B)(1), 1984) 
10.16.100 - Permit-Application. 
    The application for the permit provided for in this section shall be in writing and contain the following: 
A.  The kind of equipment to be operated, with a complete description of same and a statement as to its weight; 
B.  The kind of commodity to be transported and a certificate as to its weight; 
C.  The street or streets over which the equipment is to be operated, and the date or dates and the approximate time of the operation, and the number of trips to be made, except when the nature, route, time or frequency of operation cannot be determined at the time the permit is issued; 
D.  The application shall be dated and signed by the applicant. 
(Ord. 684 § 5(B)(2), 1984) 
10.16.110 - Permit-Bond requirement. 
    Before a permit is issued under this chapter, the applicant shall file with the city a bond in an amount to be set and approved by the city. The amount of such bond shall not exceed the product of the number of vehicles for which a permit is sought multiplied by ten thousand dollars, the bond shall be payable to the city and conditioned that the applicant will pay to the city the sum of money necessary to repair any damage which might be occasioned to any public street or public-owned fixture appurtenant to such street by virtue of operation of any commercial vehicle under the permit. Venue of any suit for recovery upon the bond shall be in Tarrant County, and any bond issued under this chapter shall contain an unambiguous contractual provision to that effect. 
(Ord. 684 § 5(B)(3), 1984) 
10.16.120 - Permit-Fee. 
A.  A fee shall be charged for each permit in accordance with Section 1.12.030. 
B.  The proper fee shall accompany each application for permit and shall be made in cash or by cashier or certified check or postal money order. The fee shall be returned if the application is denied. 
(Ord. 1032 § 7 (part), 1998; Ord. 684 § 5(B)(4), 1984) 
10.16.130 - Permit-Required information. 
    Any permit issued under this chapter shall include at least the following: 
A.  The name of the applicant, the date, a description of the equipment to be operated and a description of the commodity to be transported; 
B.  The signature of an authorized member of the city; 
C.  The time for which the permit is issued; 
D.  The specified street or streets over which the equipment is to be operated, insofar as it can be determined at the time the permit is issued. 
(Ord. 684 § 5(B)(5), 1984) 
10.16.140 - Parking of trucks, buses, trailers, semi-trailers, etc., on city streets. 
    It is unlawful for the driver or owner of any bus, truck, van, truck-tractor or any other type of self-propelled trackless conveyance, other than a recreational vehicle, which is more than twenty feet in length from bumper tip to bumper tip, more than seven feet in width at its widest point, or more than seven feet in height at its highest point, to park the same, permit the same to be parked or stand on any street in the city for a period exceeding eight hours. It is unlawful for the driver or owner of a trailer or semi-trailer to park the same, permit the same to be parked or stand on any street in the city for a period exceeding eight hours. At no time shall a bus, truck, van, truck-tractor, trailer, semi-trailer, recreational vehicle or other vehicle, when parked or standing pursuant to this chapter, create a driving or safety hazard as reasonably determined by the chief of police. 
(Ord. 1204 § 1, 2006: Ord. 684 § 5(B)(6) (part), 1984) 
10.16.150 - Commercial truck parking in residential zones. 
    No more than one commercial truck may be parked in any required front yard or the side yard adjacent to the street on corner lots. The total length of the truck may not exceed twenty-four feet and shall not under any circumstances extend into or upon any right-of-way or public access easement. The parking surface in any required yard shall be asphalt, concrete or other approved hard, all-weather surface, free of litter, debris, weeds, or other objectionable material or other objects. The vehicle must have a current inspection, license plate and be totally operational and ready to use. No such vehicle shall be used for living, sleeping or housekeeping purposes when parked or stored on a residential lot or any location not approved for such use. Such vehicle shall be unloaded and empty. 
(Ord. 684 § 5(B)(6) (part), 1984) 
10.16.160 - Blocking of curb-Liability. 
    If any person intends to drive a truck over and across any curb in any public street within the city, such person shall block such curb with materials of sufficient strength to prevent any damage to the curb by virtue of driving a truck over and across such curb. If any damage is done to the curb by virtue of driving over a curb, whether it has been properly blocked or not, it shall be conclusively presumed to have been caused by the negligence of the person backing or driving over the curb and any person driving over such curb shall be liable in damages to the city. 
(Ord. 684 § 5(B)(7), 1984) 
10.16.170 - Street surface damage. 
    The turning or maneuvering of any truck upon any of the public streets of the city in such a manner as to cause damage to the surface of the street is prohibited. If any street is damaged by the turning or maneuvering of any truck upon the city streets, the owner and driver of the truck shall be jointly responsible to respond in damages to the city. 
(Ord. 684 § 5(B)(8), 1984) 
10.16.180 - Spilling or dropping cargo on streets prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated any commercial motor vehicle on a public street of the city in such manner as to permit any portion of its cargo, either liquid or solid, to fall out of, spill from, or blow out of such vehicle. 
(Ord. 684 § 6, 1984) 
10.16.190 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation, or any agent or employee thereof, who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not to exceed two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 684 § 7, 1984) 
10.16.200 - Enforcement-Liability. 
    All of the regulations provided in this chapter are declared to be governmental and for the health, safety and welfare of the general public. Any member of the city council, and city official or employee charged with the enforcement of this chapter, acting for the city in the discharge of his duties, shall not thereby render himself personally liable and he is relieved from all personal liability for any damage that might accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties. 
(Ord. 684 § 10, 1984) 
10.16.210 - Violation-Additional remedy. 
    Any violation of this chapter can be enjoined by a suit filed in the name of the city in a court of competent jurisdiction, and this remedy shall be in addition to any penal provision in this chapter or this code. 
(Ord. 684 § 12, 1984) 
Chapter 10.20 - MISCELLANEOUS TRAFFIC REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

10.20.010 - Improper start or noise prohibited-Penalty. 
A.  It is illegal for the driver of any motor vehicle to cause such vehicle to improperly start or to make an unnecessary noise by reason of operating such vehicle in such a manner as to cause the wheels thereof to spin or slide on the roadway of any street when starting such vehicle or while making any turning movement. 
B.  "Improper start," as that term is used in this section, means the practice of starting any such motor vehicle from a standing position by applying a sudden burst of power, recognized by spinning wheels and noise of tires on the surface of the roadway. 
C.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists theenforcement of, any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. 684 §§ 1, 3, 1975) 
10.20.020 - Parking near intersection-Penalty. 
A.  It is unlawful for the driver or the owner of any vehicle to permit the same to be parked for any period of time within twenty feet of any intersection of two streets within the corporate limits of the city. 
B.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
C.  The city may also bring suit for injunction against any person, firm or corporation that shall violate or threaten to violate any of the provisions of this section, in order to prevent a continued violation or such threatened violation. 
(Ord. 388 §§ 1, 3, 1975)

Chapter 10.26 - ONE-WAY TRAFFIC 
Sections: 

10.26.010 - Street segments designated. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for a driver to drive other than the direction indicated for the following street segments: 
1.  The 700 block of the alley between Mercedes Street and Cozby North Street from Park Center Street to Warden Street is designated as one-way traffic westbound from Park Center Street to Warden Street.

(Ord. No. 1334, § 2, 4-5-2012) 
Chapter 10.32 - BUS LOADING ZONES 
Sections: 

10.32.020 - Boston Street. 
A.  Boston Street, from a point twenty feet south of its intersection with Bangor Street, extending along the west curbline in a southerly direction for a distance of four hundred feet, is designated as a bus loading zone. The bus loading zone shall be so constituted from six a.m. until three p.m. on each and every school day. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to park or cause a motor vehicle other than a bus to remain motionless at or near the curbline on Boston Street from a point twenty feet south of its intersection with Bangor Street along the west curbline of Boston Street a distance of four hundred feet from six a.m. until three p.m. on each and every school day. 
C.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. 441 §§ 1, 2, 5, 1976: Ord. 432 §§ 1, 2, 5, 1976) 
10.32.030 - Park Center. 
A.  The east side of Park Center between the blocks of Cozby North and Mercedes is officially designated as no-parking, no-stopping, no-standing zone for the hours of eight a.m. until four p.m. on school days. 
B.  These parking restrictions will be in effect for the purpose of creating a bus loading and unloading zone for school days. 
C.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. 662 §§ 1, 3, 1983) 
10.32.040 - Jerry Dunn Parkway. 
A.  The north side of Jerry Dunn Parkway, beginning at the exit driveway from the Westpark Elementary School parking lot and extending in a southwesterly direction along the north curb-line of Jerry Dunn Parkway approximately one hundred fifty-one feet to the southwest corner of the Westpark Elementary School property, is designated as a bus loading zone between the hours of seven a.m. to nine a.m. and two p.m. to four p.m. on school days. Parking allowed in this zone outside the posted times. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to park or cause a motor vehicle other than a school bus to remain motionless at or near the north curb-line on Jerry Dunn Parkway, as described in Section 10.32.040.A above, between the hours of seven a.m. to nine a.m. and two p.m. to four p.m. on each and every school day. 
C.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars or more than five hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. No. 1435 , § 1, 11-15-2018)

10.34.030 - Parking in restricted areas. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, it is illegal for an operator of a vehicle to leave the vehicle unattended at any time while in the loading/unloading zone during the restricted hours; and the term "vehicle" shall mean every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street or highway, except devices moved exclusively by human power.

Chapter 10.40 - PARKING RESTRICTIONS 
Sections: 

10.40.010 - No parking anytime. 
A.  It is unlawful for the driver or the owner of any vehicle to permit the same to be parked, stand or remain for any period of time whatsoever:

12.  On both the north and south sides of Winbrook Drive from Winscott Road to the dead end. 
13.  On the north side of Bellaire Drive South from a point in the north curb line of the roadway adjacent to the southwest corner of Lot 2 and the southeast corner of Lot 3, of Block 8, Country Day Meadows in an easterly direction along the north curb line a distance of one hundred and fifty-five feet, and on the south side of Bellaire Drive South from a point in the south curb line of the roadway adjacent to the northwest corner of Lot 2 and the northeast corner of Lot 3R, of Block 7, Country Day Meadows in an easterly direction along the south curb line a distance of one hundred and eighty feet. 
14.  The south side of Jerry Dunn Parkway, beginning at the southeast corner of the intersection of Jerry Dunn Parkway and Whitestone Ranch Road and extending in a northeasterly direction thirty feet along the curb-line of said Jerry Dunn Parkway, is designated a no parking, standing or stopping zone at any time. 
15.  The south side of Jerry Dunn Parkway, beginning at the southwest corner of the intersection of Jerry Dunn Parkway and Whitestone Ranch Road and extending in a southwesterly direction thirty feet along the curb-line of said Jerry Dunn Parkway, is designated a no parking, standing or stopping zone at any time. 
16.  The east side of Whitestone Ranch Road, beginning from the southeast corner of the intersection of Jerry Dunn Parkway and Whitestone Ranch Road and extending in a southeasterly direction thirty feet along the east curb-line of Whitestone Ranch Road, is designated a no parking, standing or stopping zone at any time. 
17.  The west side of Whitestone Ranch Road, beginning at the southwest corner of the intersection of Jerry Dunn Parkway and Whitestone Ranch Road and extending in a southeasterly direction along the west curb-line of Whitestone Ranch Road approximately one hundred twenty feet to the intersection of Whitestone Ranch Road and Stonehill Drive, is designated a no parking, stopping or standing zone between the hours of seven a.m. to nine a.m. and two p.m. to four p.m. on school days. Parking allowed in this zone outside the posted times. 
B.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars, nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. 1260 § 1, 2008; Ord. 1235 § 1, 2007; Ord. 1114 § 1, 2002; Ord. 1088 § 1, 2001; Ord. 1070-00 § 1, 2000; Ord. 1060-00 § 1, 2000; Ord. 906 § 1, 1991; Ord. 758 § 1, 1985; Ord. 749 § 1, 1985; Ord. 732 § 1, 1985; Ord. 638 §§ 1, 3, 1983; Ord. 637 §§ 1, 3, 1983; Ord. 633 §§ 1, 3, 1982; Ord. 619 §§ 1, 3, 1982; Ord. 385 §§ 1, 3, 1975; Ord. 340 §§ 1, 3, 1973) 
(Ord. No. 1368, § I, 5-15-2014; Ord. No. 1435 , § 1, 11-15-2018) 
10.40.020 - No parking-School zones. 
A.  The following streets, or parts thereof, are designated as no-parking, no-stopping, no-standing zones: 
1.  The 8000 block of Carrick Street, Lifford Street, Longford Street, and the east side of the 3500 block of Westerly Street, from the hours of 7:30 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. on school days; 
2.  The north and south sides of the 8000 and 8100 blocks of Bangor Street, from the hours of 7:30 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. on school days; 
3.  The east and west sides of Boston Avenue north of its intersection with Bangor Street, north for one-tenth mile, from the hours of 7:30 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. on school days; 
4.  The west side of Boston Avenue at the designated bus loading zone, from 7:30 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. on school days, excluding the three twenty-minute parking spaces as provided in Section 10.40.040; 
5.  The south side of the 8000 and 8100 blocks of Chapin Road and the north side of the 8000 block of Chapin Road, from 7:30 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. on school days; 
6.  The east side of Boston Avenue from its intersection with Chapin Road north of its intersection with Bangor Street, from the hours of 7:30 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. on school days; 
7.  No parking, no stopping, no standing from 7:30 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. on school days on the north and south sides Rush Street. 
B.  Parking regulated by this section shall be suspended on official voting days. 
C.
