Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. 1260 § 2, 2008; Ord. 1242 § 1, 2007; Ord. 685 §§ 1-7, 9, 1984) 
10.40.030 - No parking-Fire lane. 
A.  The following streets, or parts thereof, where there exist painted red markings on the pavement or curbs, posted signs, or any other device used to designate a fire lane, are designated as no-parking, no-stopping, no-standing zones at any time: 
1.  The west parking lot of Western Hills High School adjacent to the 8100 block of Bangor Street; 
2.  The north parking lot of Western Hills High School adjacent to the 3500 block of Boston Street; 
3.  The south parking lot of Western Hills High School adjacent to the 8100 block of Chapin and the 3700 block of Boston Street; 
4.  The north parking lot of Benbrook Elementary School adjacent to the 800 block of Mercedes Street. 
B.  All other areas within the city where a fire lane designated by the fire marshal or any other statute regulating the establishment of fire lanes on such properties which are properly marked is designated as a no-parking, no-stopping, no-standing zone at any time. 
C.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. 630 §§ 1-5, 7, 1982) 
10.40.040 - Twenty-minute parking. 
A.  There are provided three twenty-minute spaces on the west side of Boston Avenue by the Western Hills High School entrance in the 3600 block. Such spaces shall be appropriately marked. 
B.  It is a violation of this section for anyone to park or cause to be parked a motor vehicle in the three designated spaces for more than twenty continuous minutes while the Western Hills High School is in session. 
C.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. 546 §§ 1, 2, 4, 1979) 
10.40.050 - No parking-Lakeside Drive. 
A.  It is illegal for any person to park any automobile, bus, truck, motorcycle, motor home, camper, trailer, boat or any vehicle along both sides, and within ten feet of the back of curb, on that portion of Winscott Road described as follows: 
    Starting at the westbound turn lane at the intersection of Winscott Road and Lakeside Drive, continuing in a northwesterly direction along Winscott Road for a distance of two thousand feet. 
B.  For purposes of this section, the term "vehicle" means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street or highway, except devices moved exclusively by human power. 
C.  Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 977 § 2, 1995; Ord. 842 §§ 1, 2, 6, 1989) 
10.40.055 - No Parking-Jerry Dunn Parkway. 
    It is illegal for any person to park any automobile, bus, truck, motorcycle, motor home, camper, trailer, boat or any vehicle along the north side of Jerry Dunn Parkway, beginning at the west right-of-way line of R.M. 2871 and extending in a southwesterly direction along the north curb-line of Jerry Dunn Parkway approximately one hundred forty feet to the entrance driveway to the Westpark Elementary School parking lot. 
(Ord. No. 1435 , § 1, 11-15-2018) 
10.40.060 - No parking-Crosslands Road. 
A.  It is illegal for any person to park any automobile, bus, truck, motorcycle, motor home, camper, trailer, boat or any vehicle within the right-of-way of that portion of Crosslands Road described as follows: 
 Starting at the southern drive approaches to Crosslands Plaza Complex on both the east and west sides of Crosslands Road and continuing forty feet in a northerly direction; and starting at the northern drive approaches to Crosslands Plaza Complex on both the east and west sides of Crosslands Road and continuing forty feet in a southerly direction and forty feet in a northerly direction. 
B.  For purposes of this section, the term "vehicle" means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street or highway, except devices moved exclusively by human power. 
C.  Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 853 §§ 1, 2, 6, 1989) 
10.40.065 - No Parking-Sproles Drive. 
A.  It is illegal for any person to park any automobile, bus, truck, motorcycle, motor home, camper, trailer, boat or any vehicle along the northeast side of Sproles Drive, beginning at the northeast corner of the intersection of McKinley Street and Sproles Drive and extending in a southeasterly direction along the northeast curb-line of Sproles Drive approximately eighty-one feet to the entrance driveway of 1007 Sproles Drive. 
B.  For purposes of this section, the term "vehicle" means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street or highway, except devices moved exclusively by human power. 
C.  Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1439 , § 1, 3-7-2019) 
10.40.070 - No parking-Cozby North Street. 
    It is illegal for any person to park any automobile, bus, truck, motorcycle, motor home, camper, trailer, boat or any vehicle along the north side of Cozby North Street from Park Center Street and Duane Street between hours of seven-thirty a.m. and four p.m. school days and along the east side of Park Center Street from Cozby North Street to Mercedes Street on school days. It is illegal to park on the south side of Cozby North Street from John Reagan Street to Duane Street between the hours of seven-thirty a.m. and eight-thirty a.m. and two-thirty p.m. and three-thirty p.m. on school days. 
(Ord. 1237 § 1, 2007: Ord. 973 § 1, 1995: Ord. 913 §§ 1, 2, 6, 1992) 
10.40.080 - No parking anytime-Vehicle without unexpired registration certificate. 
A.  For the purposes of this section, the term "vehicle" means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street or highway, except devices manufactured, built or fabricated with the sole purpose and intent of being moved exclusively by human power, and that Chapter 502 of the Texas Transportation Code, or any other applicable law in Texas or any other state, requires to be registered. 
B.  A vehicle that does not have attached to it an unexpired registration certificate and that is parked, standing, or remaining for any period of time on a public highway, street, alley, or other public right-of-way, whether paved or unpaved, within the city limits, is a public nuisance and: 
1.  Is detrimental to the safety and welfare of the public; 
2.  Tends to reduce the value of private property; 
3.  Invites vandalism; 
4.  Is a fire hazard; 
5.  Is a traffic hazard; 
6.  Is an attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health and safety of minors; or 
7.  Produces urban blight adverse to the maintenance and continuing development of municipalities. 
C.  It is unlawful for the driver or owner of a vehicle that does not have attached to it an unexpired registration certificate to permit the vehicle to be parked, stand or remain for any period of time on a public highway, street, alley, or other public right-of-way. 
D.  It is presumed that the last registered owner of the vehicle parked the vehicle. It is a defense under this section if the registered owner shows that he or she did not illegally park the vehicle. 
E.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars nor more than five hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
F.  The municipal court of Benbrook may issue any necessary orders to enforce this section. 
(Ord. 1011 § 1, 1997) 
10.40.090 - Towing of illegally parked vehicles. 
A.  Any police officer for the city shall have the authority to require the immediate abatement and removal of any illegally parked vehicle, as defined by Chapter 10.40 of the Benbrook Municipal Code. The city or a wrecker service (as defined in Chapter 5.32 of the Benbrook Municipal Code) under the direction of a police officer may, without the consent or knowledge of the owner or operator of the vehicle, remove and store the vehicle at a vehicle storage facility at the vehicle owner's expense. 
B.  For purposes of this section, the last registered owner of the vehicle is responsible for all costs incurred under or other consequences resulting from this section. 
C.  The city shall give written notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, within five days after the date of removal of the vehicle to: 
1.  The last address that the registration records of the Texas Department of Transportation show for the owner of the vehicle, or if the vehicle is registered in another state, the last address that the appropriate agency of that state shows for the owner of the vehicle; and 
2.  Every lienholder recorded under Chapter 501 of the Texas Transportation Code, as may be amended from time to time. 
D.  The notice shall: 
1.  Describe the vehicle with sufficient particularity to identify the vehicle; 
2.  Identify the location of the facility that is storing the vehicle (including a valid and working telephone number for the facility); 
3.  Inform the owner and lienholder of the right to claim the vehicle not later than one hundred seventy days from the date of the notice upon the payment of all towing, preservation, notification and storage charges; 
4.  State that the owner or lienholder's failure to claim the vehicle during the period specified in subsection D3 is: 
a.  A waiver by that person of all rights, title and interest in the vehicle, and 
b.  Consent to the disposal of the vehicle as provided by Chapter 3.16 of the Benbrook Municipal Code; and 
5.  State that the owner is entitled to a hearing pursuant to Section 10.40.100 of the Benbrook Municipal Code, as amended. 
E.  The city may dispose of the vehicle in the manner that Chapter 3.16 of the Benbrook Municipal Code, as amended, provides. 
(Ord. 1011 § 2, 1997) 
10.40.100 - Right to a hearing for owners of towed vehicles. 
A.  If, in a hearing held under this section, the court finds that: 
1.  A police officer authorized, with probable cause, towing a vehicle and storing it in a vehicle storage facility, the owner of the vehicle shall pay all towing, preservation, notification and storage charges; or 
2.  A police officer did not authorize, with probable cause, towing a vehicle and storing it in a vehicle storage facility, the city shall pay all towing, preservation, notification and storage charges, or reimburse the owner for such charges that the owner paid. 
B.  The owner of a vehicle that the city has caused to be towed and stored without the owner's consent is entitled to a hearing on whether probable cause existed for towing the vehicle and storing it in a vehicle storage facility. 
C.  A hearing under this section is before the judge of the municipal court of Benbrook. 
D.  A person entitled to a hearing under this section must deliver a written request for the hearing to the municipal court of Benbrook within ten days after the owner receives notice that the owner's vehicle has been towed. A request for a hearing must contain: 
1.  The name, address and telephone number of the owner of the vehicle; 
2.  The location from which the vehicle was removed; 
3.  The date when the vehicle was removed; 
4.  The name, address and telephone number of the vehicle storage facility in which the vehicle was placed; and 
5.  A description of the vehicle with sufficient particularity to identify the vehicle. 
E.  A person who fails to deliver a request for a hearing in accordance with subsection D waives the right to a hearing. 
F.  The municipal court of Benbrook may charge a ten dollar filing fee for a hearing under this section. 
G.  The municipal court of Benbrook shall hold a hearing under this section at the first regularly scheduled docket after the court receives the request for a hearing, or as soon thereafter as practical. The municipal court of Benbrook shall notify the owner of the vehicle of the date, time and place of the hearing. The sole issue in a hearing under this section is whether probable cause existed for towing the vehicle and storing it in a vehicle storage facility. The municipal court of Benbrook may award court costs to the prevailing party. 
(Ord. 1011 § 3, 1997) 
10.40.110 - Presumption in prosecution for offense involving stopping, standing, or parking of an unattended motor vehicle. 
    In a prosecution for an offense involving the stopping, standing, or parking of an unattended motor vehicle, it shall be presumed that the registered owner of the vehicle is the person who stopped, stood, or parked the vehicle at the time and place the offense occurred. The registered owner of the vehicle may rebut this presumption by showing that he or she did not stop, stand or park the vehicle. 
(Ord. 1106 § 1, 2001) 
Chapter 10.44 - ABANDONED AND JUNKED VEHICLES 
Sections: 

10.44.010 - State statutes adopted. 
    The provisions of the Texas Transportation Code, Chapter 683-Abandoned Motor Vehicles, regarding abandoned and junked vehicles is adopted in its entirety and by this chapter is likewise made the law of the city. 
(Ord. 1061-00 § 1, 2000: Ord. 1004 § 1 (part), 1997) 
10.44.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Abandoned vehicle" means a motor vehicle that: 
1.  Is inoperable, is more than five years old, and has been left unattended on public property for more than forty-eight hours; 
2.  Has remained illegally on public property for more than forty-eight hours; 
3.  Has remained on private property without the consent of the owner or person in charge of the property for more than forty-eight hours; 
4.  Has been left unattended on the right-of-way of a designated county, state, or federal highway for more than forty-eight hours; 
5.  Has been left unattended for more than twenty-four hours on the right-of-way of a controlled access highway; or 
6.  Has been left parked and unmoved in a city street or right-of-way for a period exceeding fifteen days. 
    "Antique vehicle" means a passenger car or truck that is at least thirty-five years old. 
    "City" means the city of Benbrook. 
    "Junked vehicle" means a vehicle that is self-propelled and: 
1.  Does not have lawfully attached to it: 
a.  An unexpired license plate; and 
2.  Is: 
a.  Wrecked, dismantled or partially dismantled, or discarded; or 
b.  Inoperable and has remained inoperable for more than: 
i.  Seventy-two consecutive hours, if the vehicle is on public property; or 
ii.  Thirty consecutive days, if the vehicle is on private property. 
    "Motor vehicle collector" means a person who: 
1.  Owns one or more antique or special interest vehicles; and 
2.  Acquires, collects or disposes of an antique or special interest vehicle or part of an antique or special interest vehicle for personal use to restore and preserve as an antique or special interest vehicle for historic interest. 
    "Special interest vehicle" means a motor vehicle of any age that has not changed from original manufacturers specifications, and because of its historic interest, is being preserved by a hobbyist. 
(Ord. 1103 § 1, 2001; Ord. 1061-00 §§ 2, 3, 2000; Ord. 1004 § 1 (part), 1997) 
( Ord. No. 1383, § 1, 5-21-2015 ) 
10.44.030 - Junked vehicle declared to be public nuisance. 
    A junked vehicle, including a part of a junked vehicle, is a public nuisance if it is visible from a public place or public right-of-way and: 
A.  Is detrimental to the safety and welfare of the public; 
B.  Tends to reduce the value of private property; 
C.  Invites vandalism; 
D.  Creates a fire hazard; 
E.  Is an attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health and safety of minors; or 
F.  Produces urban blight adverse to the maintenance and continuing development of municipalities. 
(Ord. 1004 § 1 (part), 1997) 
10.44.040 - Exceptions. 
    This chapter does not apply to a vehicle or vehicle part: 
1.  That is completely enclosed in a building in a lawful manner and is not visible from the street or other public or private property; or 
2.  That is stored or parked in a lawful manner on private property in connection with the business of a licensed vehicle dealer or junkyard, or that is an antique or special interest vehicle stored by a motor vehicle collector on the collector's property, if the vehicle or part and the outdoor storage area, if any, are: 
a.  Maintained in an orderly manner, 
b.  Not a health hazard, and 
c.  Screened from ordinary view by appropriate means, including a fence, rapidly growing trees, or shrubbery, and otherwise meeting the requirements of the zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. 1004 § 1 (part), 1997) 
10.44.050 - Authority to abate nuisance. 
A.  The abatement and removal of a public nuisance shall be administered by the code enforcement officer, or other duly designated employee of the city. 
B.  To the extent permitted by law, the code enforcement officer or other duly designated employee of the city may enter private property to examine a public nuisance, to obtain information to identify the nuisance, and to remove or direct the removal of the nuisance. 
(Ord. 1004 § 1 (part), 1997) 
10.44.060 - Notice. 
A.  Prior to an official action to abate and remove a junked vehicle constituting a public nuisance, the city shall provide ten days written notice. Notice shall be sent by certified mail with a five-day return requested to: 
1.  The last known registered owner of the nuisance; 
2.  Each lienholder of record of the nuisance; and 
3.  The owner or occupant of: 
a.  The property on which the nuisance is located, or 
b.  If the nuisance is located on a public right-of-way, the property adjacent to the right-of-way. 
B.  The notice shall state that: 
1.  The nuisance must be abated and removed not later than the tenth day after the date on which the notice was mailed; and 
2.  A public hearing may be requested before the ten-day period expires. 
C.  If the post office address of the last known registered owner of the nuisance is unknown, notice shall be placed on the nuisance or, if the owner is located, hand delivered. 
D.  If notice is returned undelivered, action to abate the nuisance shall be continued to a date not earlier than the eleventh day after the date of the return. 
(Ord. 1004 § 1 (part), 1997) 
10.44.070 - Hearing. 
A.  The appeals commission shall conduct any hearings required by this chapter. 
B.  If a hearing is requested by a person for whom notice required, the hearing shall be held not earlier than the eleventh day after the date of the service of notice. 
C.  At the hearing, the junked motor vehicle is presumed, unless demonstrated otherwise by the owner, to be inoperable. 
D.  Following the hearing, the appeals commission shall consider all evidence and determine whether the vehicle, or part thereof, constitutes a public nuisance as alleged. If the appeals commission finds that a public nuisance exists and that there is sufficient cause to abate the nuisance, and that notice requirements provided in this section have been met, the appeals commission shall issue a written order setting forth its findings and ordering that the nuisance be abated. 
E.  If the information is available at the location of the nuisance, an order requiring removal of the nuisance shall include the vehicle's: 
1.  Description; 
2.  Vehicle identification number; and 
3.  License plate number. 
(Ord. 1004 § 1 (part), 1997) 
10.44.080 - Abatement of nuisance. 
A.  In the event the appeals commission orders abatement of the nuisance, the city or duly authorized person shall abate such public nuisance by removal and disposal of the junked vehicle and/or parts. 
B.  After a junked vehicle has been removed, it shall not be reconstructed or made operable. 
C.  A junked vehicle, including a part of a junked vehicle, shall be removed to a scrapyard, a motor vehicle demolisher, or other suitable site approved by the city. 
D.  The city shall give notice identifying the vehicle or part of the vehicle to the Texas Highway Department no later than the fifth day after the date of removal. 
E.  The relocation of a junked vehicle that is a public nuisance to another location within the city after a proceeding for the abatement and removal of the public nuisance has commenced has no effect on the proceeding if the junked vehicle constitutes a public nuisance at the new location. 
(Ord. 1061-00 § 3, 2000; Ord. 1004 § 1 (part), 1997) 
10.44.090 - Offense. 
A.  A person commits an offense if the person maintains a public nuisance described by Section 10.44.030. 
B.  An offense under this section is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars. Each day an offense occurs shall be a separate offense. 
C.  The municipal court of Benbrook may issue any necessary orders to enforce this section. 
(Ord. 1004 § 1 (part), 1997) 
Chapter 10.48 - BICYCLE HELMET REQUIREMENTS 
Sections: 

10.48.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish rules and regulations to encourage and promote bicycle safety through the use of helmets and through the promotion of educational efforts relating thereto. 
(Ord. 983 § 1 (part), 1996) 
10.48.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Bicycle" means a human powered vehicle with two wheels in tandem designed to transport by a pedaling action a person seated on a saddle seat. 
    "Helmet" means properly fitted headgear that is not structurally damaged and that conforms to the standards of the American National Standards Institute, the American Society for Testing and Materials, the Snell Memorial Foundation or any federal agency having regulatory jurisdiction over bicycle helmets, as applicable, at the time of the manufacture of the helmet. 
    "Minor" means any person under seventeen years of age. 
    "Parent" means a natural parent, adoptive parent, step-parent, court appointed guardian or conservator of a minor. 
    "Public way" means any property that is publicly owned or maintained, including, but not limited to, a street, sidewalk or highway; a publicly maintained trail; any public park facility; and a public school. 
    "Riding an bicycle" means a minor is an operator or passenger on a bicycle when it is in motion. 
    "Wearing a helmet" means the person has a helmet fastened securely to his or her head with the straps of the helmet securely tightened. 
(Ord. 983 § 1 (part), 1996) 
10.48.030 - Offenses. 
A.  A minor commits an offense under this section if he or she is operating or riding a bicycle or any side car, trailer, child carrier, seat or other device attached to a bicycle without wearing a helmet. 
B.  A parent or guardian commits an offense under this section if he or she permits a minor under fourteen years of age to operate or ride upon a bicycle or any side car, trailer, carrier, seat or other device attached to a bicycle unless the minor is wearing a helmet. 
(Ord. 983 § 1 (part), 1996) 
10.48.040 - Enforcement. 
A.  If the offender is at least fourteen years of age, the officer may issue a citation. 
B.  An officer may issue a citation to the parent or guardian of a minor under fourteen years of age who violates this chapter. 
(Ord. 983 § 1 (part), 1996) 
10.48.050 - Penalties. 
A.  Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a Class C misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined an amount not to exceed fifty dollars upon the first conviction and an amount not to exceed one hundred dollars upon the second and each subsequent conviction. 
B.  The municipal court may waive the fine imposed under this section if it is the person's first offense and the person presents proof to the court that the minor did not have a protective helmet at the time of the offense, but purchased or obtained one within two weeks of the offense date. 
(Ord. 983 § 1 (part), 1996) 
10.48.060 - Defense. 
A.  It is a defense to prosecution under Section 10.48.030 that the bicycle was not being ridden upon a public way at the time of the alleged offense. 
B.  It is a defense to prosecution under Section 10.48.040 if the person charged makes presentation of a birth certificate showing that the minor was over age seventeen at the time of the offense. 
(Ord. 983 § 1 (part), 1996) 
Chapter 10.52 - ROAD HUMP POLICY FOR RESIDENTIAL NEIGHBORHOODS 
Sections: 

10.52.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Application" means the written initial request and the petition submitted by a resident or representative of a neighborhood group. 
    "Residential dwellings" means and includes single-family houses, townhouses and duplexes. 
    "Road hump" means a geometric design feature of a roadway, consisting of a raised area in the roadway pavement surface extending transversely across the travelway, whose sole purpose is to reduce the speed of vehicles traveling along that roadway. 
    "Street" means the street segment that must be petitioned. It should be a continuous street between two intersecting streets and should be a minimum of one thousand feet in length. 
(Ord. 986 § 1 (part), 1996) 
10.52.020 - Eligibility requirements. 
    Many factors must be considered in locating road humps for optimal effectiveness. Isolated humps provide only point speed reductions and do not achieve an overall speed reduction effect. Site details should be the dominant consideration in determining the actual location of each road hump rather than an exact separation distance. All of the following criteria must be satisfied for a street to be considered eligible for road hump installation: 
A.  A petition documenting that a minimum of seventy-five percent of the property owners of all residential dwellings on the street support installation of the requested road hump(s); 
B.  The street where the road hump is proposed must be composed primarily of residential dwellings; 
C.  Conditions for locating road humps, including operational and geometric characteristics of the street, are as follows: 
1.  The street must be a local residential street or a residential collector street. 
2.  The street must be paved. If the road hump is located on a street with no curb and gutter, then a special design must be used to prevent vehicles from driving around a road hump. 
3.  The street pavement width can be no wider than thirty-six feet wide. 
4.  There must be no more than one moving lane of traffic in each direction. 
5.  Traffic volumes must be more than four hundred vehicles per day but less than three thousand vehicles per day. 
6.  The street must not be identified as a primary route for emergency vehicles. Primary emergency routes include, but are not limited to, the streets identified as collectors and thoroughfares on the thoroughfare plan and are subject to change. 
7.  The street must have a speed limit of thirty miles per hour or less in accordance with state law. 
8.  Vehicle speed must equal or exceed an eighty-fifth percentile speed of five miles over the posted speed limit. 
9.  The street must have adequate sight distance to safely accommodate the hump(s) as determined by the public works and police departments. 
10.  The street must not have curves or grades that prevent safe placement of the hump(s). Road humps may be located on streets that contain curves and/or grades but the hump itself must be located not less than two hundred feet from any horizontal curve with a radius of one thousand feet or less. The vertical grade of the street may not exceed eight percent. 
11.  The elevation of property adjacent to a hump location must be above the top of the curb, or as determined by the engineering department, to minimize potential flooding due to the presence of the hump in the roadway. 
12.  A road hump must be located downstream of a drainage inlet. 
13.  A road hump must be placed perpendicular to the direction of travel. 
14.  A road hump must not be installed within one hundred fifty feet of an intersection. 
15.  A road hump should be located at property lines rather than in front of a residence; however, it must not be located in front of a property if the owner objects to its placement or, in the case of a property containing multiple dwellings, if a majority of the households on the property object to its placement. It is the responsibility of the applicant(s) to obtain approval from the property owner or majority of households to place road humps on property lines or in front of a residence. 
16.  A road hump should not be located at driveways or between ends of a loop driveway that presents an attractive run-around route. 
17.  A road hump must not be located over manholes, gate valves, utility vault accesses and similar features. 
18.  A road hump should be installed to take advantage of existing street lighting, where possible. 
(Ord. 986 § 1 (part), 1996) 
10.52.030 - Cost of road humps. 
    The city manager shall establish the current estimated cost of road humps, based on information provided by contractors and by city staff. The estimated cost shall include asphalt, markings, signage and a reasonable contingency factor, but shall not include labor. Special design features may result in additional costs. 
(Ord. 986 § 1 (part), 1996) 
10.52.040 - Cost responsibility. 
    The cost for the road hump installation (including signs, pavement markings and, if necessary, special design features such as curbing or guard rail) and/or removal is the property owner's responsibility. The property owners shall be responsible only for the actual cost, and any excess funds deposited over and above the actual cost shall be returned to the land owners. The cost for transportation engineering studies and maintenance of the road hump is the responsibility of the city. The term "property owner," when used in cost sharing, does not necessarily refer to the petitioners, but is used to define the share of the cost that is not the responsibility of the city and should be paid by one or more of the residents or from other private resources. The city council reserves the right to waive the cost in cases of financial hardship. 
(Ord. 986 § 1 (part), 1996) 
10.52.050 - Design standards and procedures 
    The city manager shall prepare and maintain current design standards and installation procedures for road humps in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. 986 § 1 (part), 1996) 
10.52.060 - Procedure for road hump installation. 
A.  The initial request for the installation of road humps must originate from the property owners on the street. A request in writing from a property owner or representative of a neighborhood group must be forward to: 
City Manager 
Re: Road Hump Program 
City of Benbrook 
911 Winscott Road 
Benbrook, TX 76126 
B.  Upon receipt of the request, a preliminary determination of eligibility based on compliance with this chapter and available traffic data will be made in a timely manner. If necessary, the city shall conduct traffic counts and speed studies to determine eligibility. 
1.  If the street is determined not to be eligible, the applicant will be notified in writing of the reason for the denial. 
2.  The decision may be appealed in writing to the city manager within fifteen days of the notification date. The city manager will review the determination and respond to the applicant within thirty days of the appeal request. Any subsequent petitions must show the reason for the original denial. 
3.  If the street is determined to be eligible for consideration of road hump installations, a meeting will be arranged between the applicant and staff to determine the petition area, the approximate road hump locations, and the total estimated cost. The petition area generally will include all property owners fronting on the affected street, plus property owners with frontage on adjacent connecting streets within two hundred feet of the affected street. The applicant will then be instructed to submit a petition containing the signatures of seventy-five percent of the property owners of all residential dwellings on the street in support of the installation of the road humps and to provide funds to cover the estimated cost of the road humps. Only petition forms (Exhibit A attached to the ordinance codified in this chapter) supplied by the city or photocopies of petition forms may be used for this purpose. The basis for the cost estimate shall be made available to the petitioners upon request. 
C.  Upon receipt of the petition and a check for the estimated road hump cost, the city secretary will verify the legitimacy of all signatures and notify all property owners within the petition area in writing of the intent to proceed with installation of the road humps. The notice will include a return form to indicate support or objection to the proposed installation. 
D.  If owners of twenty percent or more of the real property within the notification area object to the installation within thirty days of the notice, the street will then be removed from the list of streets eligible for road hump installation and a public hearing will be scheduled with the city council for further consideration. The city manager's office will notify the applicant, the owners of all property within the study area and the area neighborhood associations of the public hearing. 
E.  If objections from less than twenty percent of the real property owners within the notification area are received or the city council approves the installation after a public hearing, then the humps will be installed as scheduling permits. 
F.  Upon completion of the road hump installation, the public works department shall prepare an accounting of the actual cost for road hump installation, excluding labor. If the actual cost was less than the estimated cost, then the difference shall be refunded to the applicant for distribution among the contributors. 
G.  In lieu of payment to the city, the petitioners may request authorization to hire their own contractor to install the road humps at their own expense. Any contractor shall be approved by the city, provide appropriate bonding and liability protection, and construct the road humps in accordance with city design standards and specifications. 
(Ord. 986 § 1 (part), 1996) 
10.52.070 - Road hump removal/alteration. 
    The process for road hump removal or alteration by the property owners is the same as the process for installation. Eighty percent of the property owners of all residential dwellings on the street must sign a petition in favor of removal. The cost for removal or alteration will be determined by the city and is the property owners' responsibility to pay. 
(Ord. 986 § 1 (part), 1996) 
Chapter 10.60 - LOCALLY-ENFORCED MOTOR VEHICLE IDLING LIMITATION[2] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1277, § 2, adopted Nov. 6, 2008, amended the Code by adding provisions numbered as Ch. 10.56. In order to avoid conflicts in chapter and section numbering the editor has renumbered the provisions of Ch. 10.60 as herein set out. 

10.60.010 - TCEQ Rule adopted by reference. 
    The City of Benbrook has adopted Rules § 114.510, § 114.511, § 114.512 and § 114.517 of Title 30 of the Texas Administrative Code by reference. The provisions of the state rules are included in the remainder of this chapter, but where there is a conflict between the state rule and the provision of this chapter, the state rules shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 1277, § 2, 11-6-2008) 
10.60.020 - Control requirements for motor vehicle idling. 
A.  In accordance with 30 TAC § 114.512, no person shall cause, suffer, allow, or permit the primary propulsion engine of a motor vehicle to idle for more than five consecutive minutes when the motor vehicle, as defined in Section 10.56.030 of this chapter, is not in motion during the period of April 1 through October 31 of each calendar year. 
B.  No driver using the vehicle's sleeper berth may idle the vehicle: 
1.  In a residential area (as defined in Section 244.001 of the Texas Local Government Code); 
2.  In a school zone; 
3.  Within one thousand feet of a hospital; or 
4.  Within one thousand feet of a public school during its hours of operation. 
An offense under this chapter may be punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars. 
(Ord. No. 1277, § 2, 11-6-2008) 
10.60.030 - Definitions. 
    The terms used in this chapter have the meanings commonly ascribed to them under 30 TAC § 114.510. The following words and terms, when used in this Chapter, have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    "Idle." The operation of an engine in the operating mode where the engine is not engaged in gear, where the engine operates at a speed at the revolutions per minute specified by the engine or vehicle manufacturer for when the accelerator is fully released, and there is no load on the engine. 
    "Motor vehicle." Any self-propelled device powered by an internal combustion engine and designed to operate with four or more wheels in contact with the ground, in or by which a person or property is or may be transported, and is required to be registered under Texas Transportation Code §502.002, excluding vehicle registered under §502.006(c). 
    "Primary propulsion engine." A gasoline or diesel-fueled internal combustion engine attached to a motor vehicle that provides the power to propel the motor vehicle into motion and maintain motion. 
(Ord. No. 1277, § 2, 11-6-2008) 
10.60.040 - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of Chapter 10.60 do not apply to: 
A.  A motor vehicle that has a gross vehicle weight rating of fourteen thousand pounds or less and does not have a sleeper berth; 
B.  A motor vehicle that has a gross vehicle weight rating of fourteen thousand pounds or less, after September 1, 2009; 
C.  A motor vehicle forced to remain motionless because of traffic conditions over which the operator has no control; 
D.  A motor vehicle being used by the United States military, national guard, or reserves forces, or as an emergency or law enforcement motor vehicle; 
E.  The primary propulsion engine of a motor vehicle providing a power source necessary for mechanical operation, other than propulsion, and/or passenger compartment heating or air conditioning; 
F.  The primary propulsion engine of a motor vehicle being operated for maintenance or diagnostic purposes; 
G.  The primary propulsion engine of a motor vehicle being operated solely to defrost a windshield; 
H.  The primary propulsion engine of a motor vehicle that is being used to supply heat or air conditioning necessary for passenger comfort and safety in vehicles intended for commercial or public passenger transportation, or passenger transit operations, in which case idling up to a maximum of thirty minutes is allowed; 
I.  The primary propulsion engine of a motor vehicle being used to provide air conditioning or heating necessary for employee health or safety while the employee is using the vehicle to perform an essential job function related to roadway construction or maintenance; 
J.  The primary propulsion engine of a motor vehicle being used as airport ground support equipment; 
K.  The owner of a motor vehicle rented or leased to a person that operates the vehicle and is not employed by the owner; or 
L.  A motor vehicle when idling is necessary to power a heater or air conditioner while a driver is using the vehicle's sleeper berth for a government-mandated rest period and is not within two miles of a facility offering external heating and air conditioning connections at a time when those connections are available. 
(Ord. No. 1277, § 2, 11-6-2008) 
Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 12.04 - STREET AND STORM SEWER IMPROVEMENTS 
Sections: 

12.04.010 - Council to determine nature and extent of improvements. 
    The city council shall, from time to time, fix and determine the nature and extent of street and/or storm sewer improvements and the type of material and construction in such improvements. 
(Ord. 416 § 2, 1975) 
12.04.020 - Permit-Required. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided in Title 16 of this code, no person shall construct, reconstruct, cut or repair any street or storm sewer within the city limits, without first obtaining from the engineering department a permit to do so. 
B.  No such permit shall be granted unless the two-year maintenance bond provided for in Section 12.04.040 is in full force and effect at the time of request for such permit and the doing of the work. 
(Ord. 416 § 3, 1975) 
12.04.030 - Permit-Inspection fees. 
    Except as otherwise provided in Title 16 of this code, no person shall be granted a permit to construct, reconstruct, cut or repair any street or storm sewer on any public property, without paying certain fees to the city for inspection of such work: 
A.  Street construction, $.05 per lineal foot, measured along the gutter, with a minimum fee of five dollars; 
B.  Street cut, two dollars per lineal foot, measured along the centerline of the cut, with a minimum fee of six dollars; provided, that no permit fee is required when the applicant for permit requests the street department to repair the cut and deposits one dollar and twenty-five cents per square foot to cover the cost of such repair; 
C.  Storm sewer (including all inlets, manholes, mains and lateral lines), developer to pay for consultant inspection fees for specification compliance on drainage installation and unusual construction situations. 
(Ord. 416 § 4, 1975) 
12.04.040 - Bonds and insurance. 
    Except as otherwise provided in Title 16 of this code, no person shall construct, reconstruct or repair any storm sewer in the city without executing and delivering to the city the following bond and proof of insurance in the sum as follows: 
A.  Performance Bond. A performance bond in the amount of the total bid price shall be executed by the contractor as a principal and by a corporate surety authorized to do business in the state pursuant to Article 5160 VTCS. The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of work in accordance with the plans, specifications and contract documents and shall be solely for the protection of the city. 
B.  Payment Bond. A payment bond in the amount of the total bid price shall be executed by the contractor as principal and by a corporate surety authorized to do business in the state pursuant to Article 5160 VTCS. The bond shall be solely for the protection and use of persons supplying labor and materials in the contract. 
C.  Maintenance Bond. A maintenance bond in the amount of one hundred percent of the total bid price shall be executed by the contractor as principal and by a corporate surety acceptable to the owner. The bond shall secure maintenance by the contractor on the project made the subject of the contract for two years from the date of acceptance of the work by the owner. 
D.  Insurance. A certificate of insurance shall be filed with the owner naming the owner as additionally insured with regard to the contract project in evidencing insurance coverage of not less than the following: 
1.  Workmen's Compensation. Providing for payment of benefits as specified by the Workmen's Compensation Law of the state; 
2.  Contractor's Public Liability. Bodily injury, one hundred thousand dollars each person, three hundred thousand dollars each accident; property damage, one hundred thousand dollars each accident. 
E.  Indemnification. 
1.  The contractor shall indemnify and save harmless the city, its agents and employees from and against all claims, damages, losses and expenses, including attorney's fees arising out of or resulting from the performance of the work, provided that any such claim or damage, loss or expense: 
a.  Is attributable to bodily illness, sickness, disease or death, or to injury or destruction of tangible property, including the loss of use resulting therefrom; 
b.  Is caused in whole or part by any negligent act or omission of the contractor, subcontractor, anyone directly or indirectly employed by any of them or anyone who acts for any of them may be liable, regardless of whether or not it is caused in part by a party indemnified under this section. 
2.  In any and all claims against any party indemnified under this section, any employee of the contractor, subcontractor, anyone directly or indirectly employed by any of them or anyone who acts for any of them may be liable, the indemnification obligation provided in this section shall not be limited in any way on the amount or type of damages, compensation or benefits payable by or for the contractor, or any subcontractor under Workmen's Compensation Act or other disability benefit acts. 
(Ord. 416 § 5, 1975) 
12.04.050 - Specifications. 
    Street construction, storm sewers and related street drainage structures shall be constructed, reconstructed, cut or repaired in accordance with the specifications for the city attached to the ordinance codified in this chapter as Exhibit A, on file in the office of the city secretary and available to the contractor for a fee of twenty-five dollars. 
(Ord. 416 § 6, 1975) 
12.04.060 - Cut of improved streets. 
    No underground utility installation shall be placed under a permanently improved street except by boring or jacking such crossing from curbline to curbline. Open cuts shall be permitted only with the approval of the city engineering department in such case as it is impractical to bore or jack under a permanently improved street. 
(Ord. 416 § 7, 1975) 
12.04.070 - Supervision and approval of work. 
    All work done in construction, reconstruction, cutting and repairing of streets and storm sewers shall be done under the supervision and subject to the direction and approval of the city engineering department, whose decision shall be final. 
(Ord. 416 § 8, 1975) 
12.04.080 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
B.  The city may also bring suit for injunction against any person, firm or corporation that shall violate or threaten to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, in order to prevent a continued violation or such threatened violation. 
(Ord. 416 § 10, 1975) 
Chapter 12.08 - STREET OBSTRUCTIONS 
Sections: 

12.08.020 - Trees or shrubs-Penalty. 
A.  Except for any street trees required by Section 16.28.050, it is illegal to cause or permit the growth of any trees, shrubs, bushes or other forms of vegetation over or upon any public street or public way. The owner or owners of real property within the city abutting any public street or public way shall be and are under a duty to trim and/or remove any trees, shrubs, bushes or other forms of vegetation that may now or hereafter encroach upon, into or over any public street or public way. Authorized street trees must be maintained to provide a minimum vertical clearance of fifteen feet from the curb line to any canopy limbs overhanging the street. 
B.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars, nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
D.  The city may also bring suit for injunction against any person, firm or corporation that shall violate or threaten to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, in order to prevent a continued violation or such threatened violation. 
(Ord. 474 §§ 1, 3, 1976) 
(Ord. No. 1340A, § 1, 8-16-2012) 
12.08.030 - Parkways. 
    Parkways are defined as the area of publicly owned right-of-way located between the back of the curb or edge of pavement and the adjoining private property line. The width of the parkway typically ranges from five to ten feet. Parkways are necessary for the provision of sidewalks, driveway approaches, traffic signs, drainage facilities, utility mains, meters, valves and service lines, fire hydrants, street lights and overhead and underground wires. Parkways are subject to the following restrictions: 
A.  Except for the city, Benbrook Water Authority or other franchised public utility, no person shall construct, place or locate any structure or facility within the parkway without special permit from the city, including but not limited to fences, walls and rock gardens. Except for street trees required by Section 16.28.050, no person shall plant or allow the growth of trees or woody vegetation in the parkway exceeding a diameter of one inch at ground level or exceeding twenty-four inches in height. Exceptions to these restrictions include mailboxes and sprinkler systems; 
B.  It shall be the responsibility of the adjacent landowner to mow and trim any vegetation within the parkway and generally maintain its appearance; 
C.  No person shall restrict or hinder the activity of the city, Benbrook water and sewer authority or any franchised public utility from performing work within the parkway. The city or utility shall be responsible for performing work to appropriate city specifications, returning the ground surface to its approximate preconstruction contours (unless regrading the surface is a part of the design), replanting grass, repair or replacement of sprinkler systems, repair or replacement of sidewalks or driveway approaches, or repair or replacement of mailboxes to the minimum standards required by the U.S. Postal Service. The city, Benbrook water and sewer authority or franchised public utility shall not be required to replace structures, trees, shrubs, plantings, landscaping or elaborate mailboxes, nor shall the city, Benbrook water and sewer authority or franchised utility be liable for damages for the removal of any unauthorized structure or obstruction within the parkway. 
(Ord. 846 § 1, 1989) 
(Ord. No. 1340A, § 1, 8-16-2012) 
Chapter 12.12 - DIVERSION OF RAINWATER, FLOODWATER OR STORM WATER FLOW 
Sections: 

12.12.010 - Prohibited-Exception. 
    It is unlawful for any person to divert or change the ordinary or natural flow of rainwater, floodwater or storm water, or water flow in any creek or stream, so that it shall cause such waters to flow into or across any street or alley or upon the property of another person, except in the manner and in the place where the ordinary and natural flow would cause such rainwater, floodwater, storm water or stream to flow into or across such street or alley or upon property of another; provided, however, that this section shall not apply where any diversion or change is made under the supervision of the city engineer according to plan approved by the city council. 
(Ord. 429 § 1, 1976) 
12.12.020 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
B.  The city may also bring suit for injunction against any person, firm or corporation that shall violate or threaten to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, in order to prevent a continued violation or such threatened violation. 
(Ord. 429 § 3, 1976) 
Chapter 12.16 - PARK AND RECREATION AREA USE REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

12.16.010 - Rules and regulations. 
    The following rules and regulations shall be in force in all parks or recreation areas of the city: 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to cut or deface any park property, or to handle, pluck or injure any flower, shrub or tree, or to injure or damage any natural or artificial improvement in any park or recreation area. Firewood gathering permits may be granted in writing by the assistant city manager. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to use those park and recreation facilities for which a user fee is charged, without first having paid the fee. This includes, but is not limited to, lights on athletic fields, beach area facilities, and other facilities for which fees are collected. Use of athletic fields under lights is prohibited on weekends without consent of the assistant city manager. 
C.  It is unlawful for any person to frighten, annoy or injure, or attempt to frighten, annoy or injure, any animal or bird in the park or recreation area. 
D.  It is unlawful to bring any refuse, garbage, rubbish, trash, shrub or tree trimmings for the purpose of disposing it in the park. 
E.  Advertising by the use of billboards, signs, markers, audio devices or any means is prohibited without permission. 
F.  It is unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any goods, wares, merchandise or services without city council permission. 
G.  It is unlawful for any person to enter any portion of a park or recreation area which is designated as restricted, or to enter any area during the hours of the day the area is not open to the public. 
H.  It is unlawful for any person to bring or have horses in camping areas, picnic areas, swim beaches, athletic fields, or other developed recreational areas. 
I.  1.  A person commits an offense if the person is in possession of a pet within a public park and: 
a.  fails to keep the pet in a pen, in a cage, or on a leash no longer than six feet; or 
b.  permits the pet to enter a playground area; or 
c.  fails to remove from the park defecation deposited by the pet. 
2.  For purposes of this section "pet" means a domesticated animal, including, but not limited to, dogs and cats. 
J.  It is unlawful to swim in restricted areas marked with appropriate signs. 
K.  It is unlawful to camp overnight in all city parks and recreation areas except by permit issued by the assistant city manager. 
L.  It is unlawful to hunt in parks. 
M.  It is unlawful to fish in prohibited areas marked by appropriate signs. 
N.  It is unlawful to build a fire except in fireplaces or grills. 
O.  It is unlawful to gather wood for fuel at campsites except for dead wood on the ground. 
P.  It is unlawful to have in possession a loaded firearm, ammunition, projectile-firing devices, crossbow and explosives of any kind. This section does not prevent a person licensed to carry a handgun under Subchapter H, Chapter 411, Government Code, from carrying a loaded handgun on the premises. It is unlawful to possess bows and arrows except for organized archery events as approved by the Public Services Director. 
Q.  It is unlawful to have in possession or use fireworks in any park and recreation area except as approved for special events by the city council. 
R.  It is unlawful to hold any special event such as water carnivals, boat regattas, music festivals or other recreation events without a written permit. 
S.  Baseball and softball tournament play will be limited to nonprofit organizations. There will be no tournament reservations for athletic fields by private groups or individuals. 
T.  It is unlawful to bring glass containers into the athletic complex or the beach area. 
U.  The following definitions apply in this section: 
1.  "Personal transportation device" includes, but is not limited to bicycles, in-line skates, skateboards, and roller skates. 
2.  "Playground area" means an area within a public park that: 
a.  Is defined by a landscaped perimeter; and 
b.  Contains equipment and objects designed for play of children. 
V.  A person commits an offense if the person utilizes a transportation device while the person is within a playground area of a public park. 
W.  Events and activities that are "for profit" and located within park facilities are permitted with approval of the park board and subject to a fee of five hundred dollars or ten percent of the gross revenue of the event or activity, whichever is greater. 
X.  It is unlawful for any person to consume, possess or carry alcoholic beverages in city parks and recreation areas except within and one hundred feet surrounding Dutch Branch Park pavillions # 1 and # 2 and in concession areas as permitted by concessionaire agreement. 
(Ord. 1162 § 1, 2003; Ord. 1057-00 § 1; Ord. 698 § 1 (part), 1985; Ord. 595 § 1(1-6, 8-10, 14-24), 1981) 
( Ord. No. 1392, § I, 1-7-2016 ) 
12.16.020 - Traffic regulations. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to drive or propel any vehicle in, over or through any park or recreation area except along and upon park drives, parkways or boulevards or other areas designated for driving or parking purposes. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle upon any park drive, street or other vehicular thoroughfare at a speed greater than that which is reasonable and pertinent under the conditions then and there existing. 
C.  It is unlawful to operate off-road vehicles, including, but not limited to, motorcycles, minibikes, trail bikes, snowmobiles, dune buggies, all-terrain vehicles, and other motor vehicles designed for or capable of cross-country off-road travel except where designated. 
(Ord. 595 § 1(11), 1981) 
12.16.030 - Park hours and noise restrictions. 
A.  The parks and recreation department may establish a reasonable schedule of visiting hours and close all or any portion of a park by the posting of appropriate signs. 
B.  Quiet shall be maintained from ten p.m. until six a.m. in all park areas. It is unlawful to create excessive noise during this period, except for organized supervised recreational activities that have been scheduled through the park and recreation office. 
C.  The operations or use of any audio, sound-producing device, including, but not limited to, communications media, amplified music, motorized equipment or vehicles at any time in a manner to unreasonably annoy or endanger persons is unlawful. 
(Ord. 595 § 1(12), 1981) 
12.16.040 - Vessel regulations. 
A.  It is unlawful to operate motor-driven or sailing vessels in the areas which are designated by buoys. 
B.  It is unlawful to operate any vessel or manipulate any waterskis so as to endanger any person or property. 
(Ord. 595 § 1(13), 1981) 
12.16.050 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this chapter shall be guilty and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars. 
(Ord. 595 § 3, 1981) 
12.16.060 - Pavilion rental fees. 
    Fees for the rental of pavilions for city of Benbrook residents shall be in the amount of forty dollars. Fees of the rental of pavilions for non-Benbrook residents shall be in the amount of fifty dollars. 
(Ord. 1055-99 § 3) 
12.16.070 - Football/soccer field deposit. 
    Fees for the deposit of football/soccer fields shall be in the amount of one hundred dollars. 
(Ord. 1055-99 § 4) 
Chapter 12.20 - BENBROOK LAKE AND BENBROOK RESERVOIR AREA 
Sections: 

12.20.010 - Scope. 
    This chapter shall apply to the Benbrook Dam and to that portion of Benbrook Lake and the Benbrook Reservoir area, both surrounding the lake and below the dam, which is owned by the federal government and which lies within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. 81 § 1, 1956: Ord. 79 § 1, 1955) 
12.20.011 - Title 36 regulations. 
A.  "The Rules and Regulations Governing Public Use of the United States Army Corps of Engineers' Water Resources Development Projects," more particularly known as "Title 36 Regulations," applicable to those recreational areas of land owned by the federal government and located within the corporate limits of the city are adopted and incorporated within this chapter as if set forth fully in its entirety. The federally owned land areas stated herein currently encompass the Benbrook Dam and those portions of the Benbrook Lake and Benbrook Reservoir area surrounding the lake and situated below the dam. 
B.  The authority for Title 36 regulations are contained in 16 U.S.C. 460d, 16 U.S.C. 460d-3 and 16 U.S.C. 4601-6a. 
C.  Title 36 regulations have been printed in pamphlet format by the United States Army Corps of Engineers. These pamphlets are available for public access and can be obtained by requesting a copy of same from the city secretary. 
D.  To the extent that any portion or portions of the Title 36 regulations conflict with any provisions of this code, and more particularly Chapters 12.16 and this chapter, those regulations that are determined to be stricter in nature shall govern. The city shall have the authority to determine which conflicting provisions govern and shall administer and enforce the appropriate regulation(s) for each occurrence in violation of this chapter. A violation of any provision of the Title 36 regulations shall be punishable as provided in Section 12.20.110. 
(Ord. 919 § 1, 1992) 
12.20.020 - Boats and boating. 
A.  No boat shall be placed or operated on Benbrook Lake for any one period longer than three days unless the owner thereof, or the person in charge of such boat, has first obtained a permit therefor from the United States Corps of Engineers, which permit shall be kept on the boat at all times while in operation on the lake. 
B.  No boat shall be operated, launched or moored within three hundred feet of the dam itself, spillway structure, or any other structure of the federal government. 
C.  Houseboats are prohibited on Benbrook Lake. 
D.  Construction or installation of special boat launching or mooring facilities is prohibited, unless the person constructing or installing such facilities shall have first obtained a permit therefor from the United States Corps of Engineers. 
E.  No boat, barge or other vessel shall be placed upon or operated upon any water of Benbrook Lake for a fee or profit, unless the person operating the same shall have authorization therefor from the United States Department of the Army, or its Corps of Engineers. 
F.  Each boat being operated on the lake must at all times carry at least one life preserver, ring buoy or buoyant cushion for each occupant of the boat. 
G.  Every manually operated boat placed on the lake shall carry at least two oars or paddles, a water pump or bailing bucket, and an anchor attached to the boat by a fifteen-foot rope or chain; and any such boat operated between sunset and sunrise shall carry a lantern or flashlight capable of showing a white light which shall be exhibited in sufficient time and be of sufficient brilliance to avert collision with other obstacles or boats. 
H.  All motorboats, whether inboard or outboard, if operated on the lake between sunset and sunrise, shall be equipped with one combination light in the forepart of the boat showing red to port and green to starboard, visible from the front and sides of the boat for at least one mile, and one white light on the rear visible all around the horizon for at least two miles. 
I.  All inboard motorboats shall be equipped with a fire extinguisher. 
J.  Rules of Boat Travel. 
1.  When boats are approaching head-on, or nearly so, it shall be the duty of each to turn to the right and pass on the port, or left, side of the other. 
2.  A boat overtaking any other boat shall keep out of the way of the overtaken boat, passing to the left of it if that side is in the clear. 
3.  When boats are approaching each other at right angles or obliquely so as to involve risk of collision, other than when one boat is overtaking another, the boat which has the other on its own port side shall hold its course and speed, and the boat which has the other on its starboard side shall keep out of the way of the other by directing its course to starboard so as to cross the rear or stern of the other boat, and, if necessary, shall slacken its speed or stop or reverse. 
4.  Motorboats, when moving under power, shall keep clear of rowboats with occupants, approaching them not nearer than fifty feet. 
5.  Sailboats shall have the right-of-way at all times and shall be treated in that manner when approached by motorboats, due to the inherent slowness and ability of the sailboat to change its course as compared with the ease and speed of a motorboat in changing its course. 
6.  No person shall operate any motorboat or any vessel in a reckless or negligent manner so as to endanger the life, limb or property of any person. 
7.  When approaching or passing smaller crafts, a larger boat shall reduce its speed so that its wake does not endanger the smaller craft. 
8.  All boats, when approaching or operating in harbor and swimming areas, shall proceed at a speed of not more than two miles per hour. 
(Ord. 79 § 2, 1955) 
12.20.030 - Swimming and bathing. 
    Swimming and bathing are prohibited within three hundred feet of the dam embankment, spillway structure or any other government structure on the lake. Swimming and bathing are also prohibited in any area which may be specifically posted by sign or signs forbidding such. 
(Ord. 79 § 3, 1955) 
12.20.040 - Fishing. 
    Subject to all applicable federal, state and local laws for the protection of fish, fishing is permitted at any location within the Benbrook Lake or Reservoir area, except from or within three hundred feet of the dam, spillway structure or any other government structure on the lake, where fishing is expressly prohibited. Fishing is likewise prohibited in any other area which may be specifically posted by signs forbidding such. 
(Ord. 79 § 4, 1955) 
12.20.050 - Camping. 
    Camping is permissible, subject to the regulations of the federal authorities in charge of the lake and reservoir area, but campers shall keep their campgrounds clean and dispose of all combustibles and refuse, completely extinguishing all campfires and razing and cleaning the campsite upon departure. 
(Ord. 79 § 5, 1955) 
12.20.060 - Picnicking. 
    Picnicking is permitted in any area except on the dam, spillway or appurtenant structures, or in other areas which may be posted by signs forbidding such, but picnickers shall keep the grounds clean and dispose of all combustibles and refuse and shall extinguish any campfires before leaving the same unattended. 
(Ord. 79 § 6, 1955) 
12.20.070 - Automobile speed limit. 
    No automobile or motor vehicle shall be operated in the lake area at a greater rate of speed than thirty miles per hour, except on roads which may be designated by signs authorizing a greater speed. 
(Ord. 79 § 7, 1955) 
12.20.080 - Destruction of public property. 
    The destruction, injury, defacement or removal of public property or of vegetation, rock or mineral is prohibited. Handling, plucking or injuring any flower or shrub, thrashing any tree, or injuring or damaging any natural or artificial improvement in the lake or park area is prohibited. 
(Ord. 79 § 8, 1955) 
12.20.090 - Sanitation. 
    Refuse, garbage, rubbish or waste of any kind shall not be thrown on or along roads, in picnicking or camping areas, in the lake waters or streams or on any land of the reservoir or park area, but the same shall be disposed of only by burning or burying or depositing in trash receptacles provided therefor. 
(Ord. 79 § 9, 1955) 
12.20.100 - Advertisements. 
    The display, posting or distribution of any private advertising matter or sign in the park area is prohibited. 
(Ord. 79 § 10, 1955) 
12.20.110 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not more than two thousand dollars for all violations involving safety, and public health and sanitation, including dumping of refuse, and shall be fined five hundred dollars for all other violations of this chapter. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 919 § 2, 1992: Ord. 79 § 11, 1955) 
Chapter 12.24 - PARADES AND PICKETING 
Sections: 

12.24.010 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter: 
    "Chief of police" is the chief of police of the city or his designee. 
    "City" is the city of Benbrook, Texas. 
    "Parade" is any parade, march, marathon, bicycle race, jogging race, walkathon, ceremony, pageant, show, exhibition or procession of any kind, except picketing as defined herein, moving upon any public street in the city. 
    "Person" is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    "Picketing" is a demonstration wherein the use or display of signs that utilize pictures or messages is conducted by an individual or group of persons as a protest related to a place of employment, governmental policy or similar protest, and is conducted at a single location within the city. 
(Ord. 812 § 1 (part), 1988) 
12.24.020 - Permit required. 
A.  No person shall conduct or participate in any parade for which a parade permit has not been issued by the chief of police. Parade permits shall be of three kinds, classified as follows: 
1.  A Class A permit shall be required for all parades with less than twenty-five persons and less than three vehicles and traveling no more than ten blocks; 
2.  A Class B parade permit shall be required for all parades with twenty-five or more persons or three or more vehicles or traveling more than ten blocks, except those meeting the requirements of Class C; 
3.  A Class C parade permit shall be required for all parades with one hundred or more persons or twenty-five or more vehicles, or traveling more than twenty-five blocks. 
B.  Exceptions. No parade permit shall be required for the following: 
1.  The armed forces of the United States of America, the military of the state of Texas, and the forces of the police and fire departments acting within the scope of their duties; 
2.  Funeral processions operated in accordance with all applicable laws and ordinances; 
3.  Picketing or other orderly processions on the sidewalks, that observe and comply with traffic regulations and do not violate any other city, state or federal law. 
(Ord. 812 § 1 (part), 1988) 
12.24.040 - Application for permit. 
A.  An application for a parade permit shall be on forms provided by the chief of police. The application shall be filed with the chief of police according to the following guidelines: 
1.  Class A. No less than three days before the date on which the parade is to conducted; 
2.  Class B. No less than five days before the date on which the parade is to be conducted; 
3.  Class C. No less than fifteen days before the date on which the parade is to be conducted. 
B.  An application for a parade permit shall contain the following information: 
1.  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant and of any other persons on whose behalf the application is made; 
2.  The date requested for the parade; 
3.  The hours when the parade will start and terminate; 
4.  The specific route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point; 
5.  The estimated number of persons, animals and vehicles participating in the parade; the type of animals and a description of the vehicles and marching units, such as bands, color guards and drill teams; 
6.  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed; 
7.  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade and the time when units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area; 
8.  The type of parade permit being requested; 
9.  The purpose of the proposed parade; 
10.  The name, address and telephone number of the parade marshal. 
(Ord. 812 § 1 (part), 1988) 
12.24.050 - Fees. 
A.  Fees shall be charged for the issuance of permits in accordance with Section 1.12.030. 
B.  Parades will be conducted with an appropriate number of escort and traffic assistance peace officers certified by the state, and/or traffic control specialists employed by the city as determined by the chief of police in his sole discretion. This number shall be based upon the size of the parade, the distance travelled and other traffic control considerations and further based upon additional considerations because of the type of parade conducted, such as the need for police protection from hostile demonstrators. The applicant shall be charged at a rate determined by the chief of police for all officers necessitated by traffic control considerations but shall not be charged for officer protection recommended by the chief based upon additional considerations as provided above. 
C.  The applicant shall be assessed a reasonable fee to reimburse the city for cleanup and repair costs of city streets. A thorough cleaning of the area by the permittee shall immediately take place, particularly in the event that animal droppings are involved. Litter, debris and animal droppings must be removed within twenty-four hours following the closing of the event. Fees for cleanup and repair costs shall be determined by the street division of the city. Officer costs not previously estimated which are associated with the operation of the parade shall be assessed following the event. 
D.  All fees must be paid in advance at least five city working days prior to the event. All collected fees shall be appropriated to the general fund. 
E.  Any applicant who is unable to pay the above required fees may apply to the chief for a waiver of such fees. Fees shall be waived in whole or in part upon a showing that payment of the fees would constitute an undue hardship or would otherwise prevent the applicant from exercising his First Amendment rights. 
(Ord. 1032 § 8 (part), 1998; Ord. 812 § 1 (part), 1988) 
12.24.060 - Indemnification from liability. 
    The applicant shall agree to assume all liability and responsibility associated with the operation of the parade and the use of city streets and personnel and shall further agree to indemnify and hold harmless the city from any damage or liability occurring therefrom. 
(Ord. 812 § 1 (part), 1988) 
12.24.070 - Alternate permit. 
A.  Upon denial of a parade permit, the persons requesting same may file an amended request for the parade permit. Such request shall be marked "Alternate Permit" and shall be filed as follows: 
1.  Class A. Not less than five days prior to the date for which such parade is requested; 
2.  Class B. Not less than fifteen days prior to the date for which such parade is requested; 
3.  Class C. Not less than twenty-five days prior to the date for which such parade is requested. 
B.  No additional permit fees shall be required. 
(Ord. 812 § 1 (part), 1988) 
12.24.080 - Revocation of permit. 
    The chief of police may revoke a permit when: 
A.  The permit will result in a violation of this chapter or any other law; 
B.  The information contained in the application for a parade permit is found to be false in any material detail; 
C.  The parade fails to begin within thirty minutes of the appointed time of commencement; 
D.  The chief of police finds any condition which would result in a denial of the permit. 
(Ord. 812 § 1 (part), 1988) 
12.24.090 - Appeal. 
    Any person aggrieved by a decision of the chief of police in the granting, denial, alteration or revocation of a parade permit shall have the right to appeal the decision to the city manager or his designee. The city manager or his designee shall hear the appeal within ten working days after receipt of appeal unless extended by agreement of the appellant and the city manager. 
(Ord. 812 § 1 (part), 1988) 
12.24.100 - Conduct of parade or picketing. 
A.  All parades or picketing shall be conducted at all times in a peaceful manner and shall not unreasonably interfere with the rights of surrounding property owners, individuals not participating in the parade or picketing, or the general public. All parades must be conducted only along the route approved in the parade permit and no parade or picketing may be conducted on private property without the permission of the property owner. Where practicable, all picketing shall be confined to paved sidewalks or other areas intended for pedestrian traffic; provided, however, no person engaging in such picketing shall unreasonably interfere with the passage of individuals along such sidewalks. No participant in a parade or picketing shall employ the use of sound amplification devices or create noises of such a degree or magnitude so as to offend persons of ordinary sensibilities. 
B.  Any peace officer who observes a person or unit in a parade or picketing performing such acts in an unsafe manner or that reasonably would incite others to violence or would create a substantial risk of injury to any person, shall immediately take appropriate actions to abate such acts. To accomplish this abatement, a peace officer may stop the parade or picketing and remove the persons or unit committing the acts from the parade or picketing. If appropriate, the peace officer may also issue appropriate citations and/or effect the arrest of any such person who violates this chapter or any other laws. 
(Ord. 812 § 1 (part), 1988) 
12.24.110 - Prohibition on picketing in residential neighborhoods.
